raw_text.587: i've read several books about the iraq and afghanistan wars written by former soldiers and this is by far the most poetic and emotionally significant book so far kevin powers uses his experience on the ground to follow two fictitious young enlisted men as they patrol al tafar in nineveh province in iraq in 2005 he shares a very special perspective that i hadn't seen before these men are young naive and eager to get out of iraq led by a twenty four year old sergeant sterling they see and do what no training can prepare you to do in war with a wise beyond his years point of view sterling realizes that once your head returns home before your body once you start thinking too much of home and its comforts which one of them did the flight home is in a body bag this is the story of the path that one promises to keep to and one that another strays from in their return journeys powers' writing is very eloquent catching us off guard with poetic images at odds with one another "when the mortars fell the leaves and fruit and birds were frayed like the ends of rope " he shares a very poignant disturbing and true view of war its impact its consequences and its aftermath it is emotionally challenging to read especially the last several chapters which will leave you speechless and horrified in the end (c) 2013 kristin n p rappe
raw_text.588: this book was well reviewed and has been on my radar for a long time and i was very very moved by it the story unfolds over different time periods and you have to put together what happens to sargent murph and sargent bart the narrator as they start their tour of duty in iraq i had to do some re reading at times because i was worried i'd missed something big and lots of times i had to slow down and re read passages because they were so dense and descriptive it's lyrical vivid beautifully written the beauty of the writing was such a painful contrast to the gruesome and torturous physical and psychological war these young men are in high quality mental health care for our veterans is not a top priority in our country and it absolutely needs to be if kevin powers had and heard about these kind of events and experiences and then created this absolutely compelling novel it is a crime that we are not more respectful of what veterans give and the kind of mental health care they deserve to process and make sense of it all after reading this i feel like i've seen this modern war front that i've witnessed the downward psychological spiraling of 3 soldiers' experiences and that i've watched mothers and families fall apart over a war no one understands this would make a solid choice for an american lit class and it will be on my short list when the right kind of reader comes into the library

raw_text.591: this novel is ultimately a long elegy both for a friend lost to war and for the narrator's sense of self lost after having lived through it all powers' prose is lyrical and poetic at best at worst it is unrefined and disjointed but after you've acclimated yourself to his narrating style and forgiven him of the few descriptions or phrasings that simply don't work you're left with a powerful and multifaceted novel it's an elegy to a friendship as i mentioned before but it's also a lush evocation of a stark landscape a philosophical musing on time and memory and an existential whirl into the meaning of service and following orders probing for an answer to the question of what makes young men make the decision to have someone else decide their lives for them the meat of the story line isn't thrilling or particularly savory but as the book unfolds it reveals enough of a thread to make you start wondering at the resolution if the pains of war could really be resolved

many critics and it won several awards i'll admit that's partly why i read the book i do pay attention to what people are saying heck it was a national book award finalist so i came in really wanting to like and enjoy this book it started nicely poetically a bit oddly muted and muddled less than a quarter of the way through i was beginning to feel like there was a bait and switch going on the characters the story the scenes the writing... i wasn't connecting and i really wanted to like mr powers i'm a poet and a novelist so i know the skills he's bringing to bear here i get his writing his writing style and i can appreciate it for what he was trying to do first i didn't connect to the characters and there are only three of them they read undeveloped to me i wasn't feeling who they are so i wasn't caring for them very much as they were going through their "story " which brings us to problem number 2 there's not much story here we have 11 chapters alternating in time and space over 226 pages it is a short novel told in a first person point of view the narrator wedges in bits of his memories from the fields and odd encounters with the enemy in iraq and then back to his return and metaphors ramblings powers uses just gets in the way because of its strangeness i mean there was writing i stumbled over that really just stopped the book for me for example "clouds spread out over writing should draw me into the novel and make me experience what the characters are experiencing not make me look up and think "what the hell " there are also some bits that seem really disjointed as other reviewers have pointed out as if the text was in need of a good editor birds flying out of an orchard that's just been shelled to pieces a woman standing motionless for hours--hours --upon hearing of her son's death dark night suddenly becoming the dawn finally for me the story felt strangely heartless oddly soulless i was hoping intending to finish the book with a better understanding--a better feeling--of war a character spent a page describing his experience of war like the moment suspended before a car accident but i felt none of that while reading this book instead the book felt rushed and undone incoherent and incomplete i wanted to know more because at the end of it all at the reveal of the "big traumatic event " i felt robbed of knowing i felt the author owed me more and i felt cheated out of what should have been a good novel if not a great novel about the experience of our most modern war "did not like it"2 stars amazon1 star goodreads

intelligent and open and brave about exploring what war feels like what it does to people to everyone and everything it touches which is to say it fucks it all up in the worst way beyond imaging both in the moment and forever afterwards the story is told by private bartle a poor kid aren't they all these days would we even be in iraq if there was still a draft and the rich old men who started the war to make even more money had to send the sons and daughters of their rich old friends to their death from virginia who befriends an even younger kid private murphy in bootcamp when they get to iraq lots of bad things happen physically and psychologically including the core mystery of tale the exact fate of murphy powers jumps around chronologically but it's not some gimmick or whatever it heightens the tension and deepens our understanding but the plot itself is almost secondary to the got to be real details powers piles on men staying awake on guard duty by dropping tabasco in their eyes the thoughts that go through your mind during a mortar attack mostly get as small as you can as well as the powerful images and truths he schools us with to take just one example a soldier when an embedded journalist asks the inevitable what is battle like question replies with i'm paraphrasing it's like have you ever been in a car accident that split second when you know you're about to raw_text.617: i respect kevin powers i respect his service to the country despite what he would think about that i respect the way he captures the terror the boredom and the discomfort of battle but this book if it had to exist should have been a memoir because it doesn't work as a novel powers takes us inside his mind as he did his time in basic in battle and as a postwar civilian the problem is that one can see all too clearly the joints where he has glued on the other characters and incidents in an attempt to convert a personal story into something more cosmic these additions are just not credible to co opt his own metaphor he should have let the yellow bird fly around instead of smashing it on the head i must also say that powers's writing style was distracting to say the least he frequently sacrificed clarity in his quest for lyrical sentences made poor word choices and wrote scenes where the action and settings were internally inconsistent one could ascribe these failures to sloppy editing but who knows how much of this sort of thing was already edited out to arrive at the product which was published after all the hype including enthusiastic blurbs from some writers i admire the book was disappointing

raw_text.650: the war tried to kill us in the spring everyone is ga ga over this line when in fact the war tried to kill them in the spring summer fall and winter but perhaps i am too literal maybe spring refers to the time in the young men's lives this is the story of two young americans being destroyed in different ways by what they experience in the war in iraq bartle the main protagonist narrates the story of his friendship with murph through a series of meditations flash forwards to bartle's homecoming and backwards to the battle the book is not linear but makes an awful kind of sense when considering that bartle is remembering and trying to get his life back to gether and find some meaning or resolution in what he has experienced the writing is lyrical and skillful though repetitions and needlessly wordy there are descriptions that go on for a page and some of these are gratuitous and could have been cut but i suspect that it was puffed out for the novel market because in truth this is an extended short story or perhaps a novella to be sure the writing is often lovely but in other places it borders on purple prose and is over written and far too self consciously artistic the book has been compared to o'brien's the things they carried i think not powers is no o'brien and this book although a worthy war narrative is nowhere near o'brien's masterpiece it's worth reading however for its sense of authenticity

raw_text.658: 6 30 2013 this is a rough intense read but it should be required for us all i heard roxana robinson speaking on npr last week about her new novel called sparta about an iraq war veteran trying to reintegrate into civilian life she said there is no bridge no language no way to communicate one world to the other and that description fits tyb extremely well except that it seems to me that powers has found a language and uses it to articulate the senselessness and horror that he and others many of whom did not make it home endured in iraq and then has to endure again in coming home and not only does he manage to convey the brutality the misery and the absurdity of both his time there and his return he also does it with extraordinary beautiful language and he spins out a great suspense story to boot john bartle 21 returns home from a tour in iraq and tells his story in chapters that alternate between what happened there and what is happening back home as he tries to recover from his experience powers is an iraq vet and while tyb is labeled as fiction that doesn't really matter as it is abundantly clear that the author is writing about and from his own experience and man can he write for experience that is so hard to communicate he nails it there are a number of passages i'd love to include here but they are so intense that it's hard to take them out of context so i'll just say take my word for it very hard to read i often had to force myself to pick it up again but so worth it should have won the national book award it was a finalist in 2012

raw_text.670: in a word perfect this is more of a poem than a novel as the words combine and explode in a burst of great color and smell and sound like molecules in an exothermic reaction i'm in awe of powers' talent how could this be someone's first book written in his late 20s as a late 30 something writer i find this astounding there are few works in which i scrutinize each sentence and every paragraph and not find a way to adjust or alter it in some way every so often to perhaps heighten emotion and clarify meaning this is one of those cases powers' writing is unimprovable as one of the front cover blurbs states as for the story i found it heart breaking and gripping and immediate and important like the military cadence the book is named after these young boys are lured into war only to have their heads bashed in literally and figuratively and this account makes me realize why it's so unfair for a civilian to ask a veteran what was it like over there it requires a work of high art to answer that question and this novel provides it while there is a story here and it contains a well concealed treasure of a secret the only way to appreciate this novel is to enjoy the journey that takes you into the heart of this secret and what it means this is 40 year old scotch to be sipped for pleasure not early times to be slugged for getting wasted this is indeed a work of art not the type of thing that lends itself easily to imagining upon the silver screen it is so sensual the descriptions of people and scents and desert and bodies and sewage and lamb all coalesce until you feel like a ghost floating above the scene of war and homecoming if you appreciate amazing writing read this if you care about what's happening to the thousands of soldiers who've been broken by this war read this if you want to catch a glimpse of what this war would be like if circumstances conspired to put you there read this

raw_text.673: one of the most beautiful yet brutally raw books i have read in a very long time powers thrust you into the turmoil and conflict of a fractured soldier's conscience unable to connect fully with with people or places around him john bartle the protagonist battles with the daily duty of survival in both iraq and his home america the jumps in time are used cleverly to show the spirally sequence of events for a man who appears to want to do good but becomes perhaps irrevocably lost the prose is lyrical and beautiful in a powerful contrast to the hideous and destructive scenes of death and violence powers explores the fierce differences of this modern war and the role of a soldier well i loved the way that he examines interactions between language perception and audience showing how all affect history and therefore truth there were certainly some very philosophical concepts that forced me to interrogate and further consider areas life that we may sometimes find it easier to ignore i found the ending extremely powerful this book will stay with me and continue to stoke my thinking for a long time a dramatic but very intelligently written read

raw_text.678: a vivid book i won't ever be able to thank a vet with the same glibness as i have the text illuminates some things i think we'd rather not know about war it is most comfortable for those of us who have not served to edit our understanding of a war into something manageable certainly we know that it's hell and all the other cliches but when powers writes of the return from war and the constant acknowledgement of them as heroes and the many thanks it is something of an uncomfortable reduction for his protagonist bartle has other baggage but there rings something very true in the text about something i imagine must be very hard to relate to those who don't share the experience it was a job the job required some surrender of your self the army attempts to take some of the responsibility off of you to reduce the agency but there are costs that powers paints well vividly in a particular passage bartle must complete the out processing forms and he has to describe the way killing makes him feel it was a really poignant moment for me and describes that surrender well framed as something of a whodunnit there is a reveal at the end that i have no intention of disclosing i finished the book wondering if it didn't diffuse some of the general message of the text but after a few days of digestion i find that i'm not less inclined to believe that the effects of the war would have been substantially different if the events in the end of the book weren't in play that's a confusing sentence but i hope that it will work better after you've read it in short there is a problem with the main characters but i feel that the things they experience in the novel do not need that problem to be true this is a great trip outside of yourself but be prepared for the things about a person you may not really want to find

raw_text.681: at the will of a good friend i cracked this book open after finishing 369 paged me before you this year's tear jerking you must read this before the movie comes out romance novel over a holiday weekend the transition from that book to this one was uncomfortable and it grew increasingly clear to me that this 226 page book cannot be devoured in three days like a box of saltine crackers or a bag of your favorite chips rather it must be savored like an expensive cake or an exotic fruit something rich and rare and slightly detrimental to your personal well being i work as a receptionist and regular visitors keep up with my literary escapades as they come in and out so having this book in front of me for a whole month really surprised people i typically don't take longer than a week to polish something off but i kept telling them that it would be worth it and i tell you what it was i was a virgin to the war novel genre except for a high school level study of all quiet on the western front and the first thirty pages of slaughter house five so this novel was and remains a bit out of my depth however i don't feel like i've ever had my perspective changed so much by a book in my life i went into this expecting heroism exasperated death soliloquy and tearful sacrifices but what i got was a candid and self deprecating novel of survival kevin powers connects the chalk line stories of privates bartle and murphy in a way that reads like a classic novel that is to say there is something significant in every line if one looks hard enough but tells a story that is relevant in today's social climate i foresee this becoming required reading in the next few years my love for the characters grew silently i did not know that it was there until they started falling apart by the last few chapters i was so invested in each one that i found myself gasping at the mention of one's hypothetical suicide flinching at their mistreatment and crying at their destruction so little goes right so little is good it's such a hard reality to face and yet it is reality for many soldiers powers' style of writing is phenomenal each word in a sentence is selected carefully not a single one's precise meaning is neglected his manipulation of language can so vividly transcribe the emotions of the author to the reader that it's unsettling his panics became my panics his sorrow became my sorrow reading this book is like reading something very private something that you're not supposed to see briefly in the book the antagonist if one could call him that bartle talks about the hardest part of being a returned soldier is that people are constantly thanking him for his service when in reality all he did was survive and there was nothing glorious about that that got me thinking i've never really been one to celebrate war or war heroes and yet i still feel inclined to thank the men and women i see dressed out in fatigues at the grocery store it's no social construct i don't think i do genuinely appreciate their service but i had never dissected why i think it's a common belief that when we say thanks we are saying thank you for your bravery thank you for defending us thank you standing up for our country but when i thought about that some more i think what i am saying and what many others are saying is not thank you for your bravery in defending me thank you for risking it all for me thank you for going through this for me because wars are going to be waged it was their idea sterling said don't forget that it's their idea every time they ought to kill themselves instead of us 42 and soldiers will always be needed so it's a thank you for being a sacrificial lamb a common theme in this book is glad it's you not me and that message eerily resonates with the reader the whole way through to summarize this book was powerful and genuine all the makings of classic that will be revered for time to come and yet i have a bad taste in my mouth i think it's supposed to be like that

raw_text.686: i thought that the book the yellow birds was interesting and it expressed the details about the hardships of war private bartel a 21 year old soldier and a teenage soldier named daniel murphy meet for the first time at a boot camp while training to go fight in iraq they go to iraq and have to face challenges like fighting the taliban and just trying to survive in the harsh area they were fighting in this book sends a message to all readers that war is brutal and disturbing in iraq there are no games or parties for soldiers like bartel and murphy as they have to go to the front lines of battles and kill their enemies the book was often depressing and sad because of what the soldiers had to go through daniel murphy only 18 years old was fighting for his country with a huge risk of dying at only the age of a teenager private murphy was sensitive and not as strong as bartel as he watched his comrades and civilians get killed the yellow birds was a harsh but well written book about the war that we only hear about in iraq and describes the obstacles that the soldiers have to face i would not recommend a book like this to younger kids because it has intense and graphic violence i would recommend this book for people who are interested about what war is like and what the soldiers have to face i would rate this book 8 10 stars because it was very intense and interesting but i wasn't a fan of some of the scenes in this book as they were too graphic
raw_text.687: i have always avoided novels about contemporary wars they often appear meretricious and sensationalist with gaudy covers u0026amp hyberbolic jacket blurbs war novels often need a distance a time delay if you like before they really detonate their potentially explosive effects 'the red badge of courage'or 'all quiet on the western front' spring to mind still resonating down the years but kevin powers confounds this notion setting his powerful novel in iraq u0026amp on the home front where the leading protagonists face separate domestic u0026amp private demons during the very recent conflict powers captures brilliantly the mind set of ordinary u0026amp undistinguished squaddies confronting the harsh brutal realities of warfare in an alien environment with near strangers on both sides u0026amp the terrible realisation that their experiences will scar them for life even if they survive to suffer the nightmares u0026amp fits of despair in the safe arms of mother america bartle the main character explores his relationship with the younger murphy who is fated to be a sacrificial lamb his innocence u0026amp his vulnerable 'physic integrity' torn asunder and it is bartle who must deal with the consequences of an act of mercy which will dog him howling all the way back to the lonely hills u0026amp deep woods of virginia i would recommend this novel as an antidote to a whole barrage of films covering the same kind of vicious terrain often with their none too subtle sub texts u0026amp phantom moral messages this novel has a poetry which transcends the subject u0026amp reads well enough to qualify as something more than a war story

raw_text.695: this is the first time i've given a 2 and i feel i need to defend it clearly i'm in a minority here versus some heavyweight critics while powers is capable of some gorgeously crafted writing the reason i opted for it's ok instead of i liked it is that to be honest i didn't like it not because of the subject matter but because i didn't feel it worked as a novel this was written as a novel not a memoir so i judged it in terms of the story it told not the truth it might have been conveying i read this back to back with pynchon's the crying of lot 49 which i'd give a 4 5 and there you have a brief novel with the wingspan to take on and invent a whole new world order in contrast for me it felt like the yellow birds took a central incident that had the makings of a short story and rolled it out thin till it became a novel i also felt powers kept us at arms length throughout the book maybe that's a comment on how it feels to witness a war but i didn't get the feeling that was the point he was making instead i got the feeling that this was someone who didn't have enough control over his material that's in contrast to books about war that i admire like the things they carried and catch 22 so on this one i'll agree to disagree with the critics

raw_text.717: this debut novel was written by a young man who joined the army at seventeen and served as a machine gunner in mosul and tal arar iraq in 2004 and 2005 it is the story of two soldiers private bartle age twenty one and private murphy who is eighteen their platoon is involved in an intense battle for the city of al tafar iraq the author's wartime experiences must surely have influenced his descriptions of battle scenes the bloody horror of what happens to the human body when it is blown up by a roadside bomb or riddled with bullets and most especially what goes on in the minds of young men who are tired and terrified in a foreign land so very far from home powers is a michener fellow in poetry at the university of texas at austin and his writing is indeed poetic which is a strange thing to say about a war novel that really tells it like it is i abhor war while i support our troops and the battles they are waging i wept for these young men for the awful things they saw and did for the memories that will be with them forever for the losses they suffered and for the sometimes impossible task of readjusting to civilian life the most poignant scene for me was when bartle arrived home after his tour of duty waiting for his mother to pick him up at the airport he falls into a drunken sleep and dreams of the wood planks on his mother's porch how they held the sun's warmth long after sunset and the sounds made by bullfrogs and cicadas he hopes to dream only of that sound when his mother arrives her reaction to seeing him is visceral and heartwrenching she grabs him hard around the waist pushing and rubbing his body her grasp was firm and she touched me hard as if to prove i was not a fleeting apparition i have three sons who thankfully have not gone off to war so i can only imagine how fiercely i too would have held them when they returned and i think i would then have done what this mother did she began to cry saying his name over and over again i received an arc of this novel at bea it will be published this september by little brown and company i believe this will be an important book not just for the subject matter but also for the author's intimate eloquent and yes poetic writing
raw_text.718: i usually don't choose this type of books for reading most of the time i feel they're too crude too dramatic and to be honest way too sad for me however after reading that this is going to make a movie and i have a thing where i read all the books before they become a movie i decided to give it a chance i'm so glad i did it the book goes back and forward between the time when the main character is at war and when he is back home in both situations you clearly see and feel how our character is developing he changed from a honestly a quite annoying young man around 20s to a much more mature and broken man he changed from not caring and actually avoiding to have any type of friendships during his deportment to be affected 100% by a situation he had nothing to do with he could not avoid it but at the end he felt that he could have helped somehow it has crude scenes descriptions and feelings that i usually don't see very often in my pretty normal life however the overall feeling is that this book is not defined by the war itself the massacres guns and explosions but about the people who are stuck in there both sides and how it affects them for the rest of their life so this is a good book and now i'm looking forward to the movie and i don't usually watch war movies either

raw_text.727: haunting and deeply affecting i will not soon forget what i have read to be honest this was my first selection in the modern war genre and i wasn't expecting to like it but i ended up liking it very much this beautiful yet tragic story is so poetically told in a way that only a veteran of the war could tell it my appreciation for the men and women who serve and sacrifice so much of themselves and their families who also give up so much is great deepened as a result of reading this novel following are some of my favorite quotes from the book like i said i will not soon forget what i've read i was not surprised by the cruelty of my ambivalence then nothing seemed more natural than someone getting killed we only pay attention to rare things and death was not rare our biggest error was thinking that it mattered what we thought it seems absurd now that we saw each death as an affirmation of our lives nothing made us special not living not dying not even being ordinary freedom is not the same thing as the absence of accountability my missing him became a grave that could not be filled or leveled just a faded blemish in a field and a damn poor substitute for grief as graves so often are and the foreshadowing of this statement sends shivers down my spine the details of the world in which we live are always secondary to the fact that we must live in them

raw_text.730: this book was billed as having a very similar style to the things they carried by tim o'brien and to some degree that seemed true powers tells an important story about a war many don't know that much about and does so with a degree of surrealism it is somewhat unfortunate however that so many readers and critics make the o'brien comparison because powers' novel while significant simply cannot live up to the masterful narrative structure of tttc the yellow birds lacks the raw emotion present in o'brien's work although powers still manages to bring us closer to the front lines in ways that differ from other war novels i recommend this book to anyone looking for a new perspective on the war in iraq as well as those familiar with tttc most everyone can get something out of reading the yellow birds and i commend powers for having the courage to write about an experience that undoubtedly must have changed his life forever

raw_text.735: kevin powers can write that was my first impression after the first page or so writing about war boxing and crime have certain elements in common and when the author has in fact either been immersed in such things as either a direct participant or in such intimate proximity that they might as well have been killing fighting stealing head busting etc a certain kind of lyricism an impressionist surrealism can emerge denis johnson comes immediately to mind as the greatest practicioner of this hyper real experiential art some of the great boxing writers also hit very similar notes kevin powers' prose soars most vividly in those in between moments just before or after combat when the conscious mind is still operating in a more or less conventional manner but from past experience the adrenaline and other body enzymes start to flow the lymbic system switches into surrealism mode and the narrator enters what may as well be a parallel existence here's a little sample and then it started it seemed as if the movement of one moment to the next had its own trajectory a thing both finite and expansive like the endless divisibility of numbers strung out on a line the tracers reached out from all the dark spaces in the buildings across the field and there were many more bullets than streaks of phosphorescence we heard them tear at the air around our ears and smack into the clay brick and concrete we did not see malik get killed but murph and i had his blood on both of our uniforms when we got the order to cease fire we looked over the low wall and he was lying there and there was a lot of blood around him i didn't think about malik much after that he was an incidental figure in my continuing life i couldn't have articulated it then but i'd been trained to think war was the great unifier that it brought people closer together than any other activity on earth bullshit war is the great maker of solipsists how are you going to save my life today dying would be one way if you die it becomes more likely that i will not you're nothing that's the secret a uniform in a sea of numbers a number in a sea of dust having been involved in some horrific violence myself i have an affinity for this sort of writing powers has written a modern gem on the reality of war in all its stupidity and horrific folly a book like this is one of the best antidotes to militarism too bad so few of the let's bomb 'em back to the stone age actually read books i have lots of favorite sections in this book passages that i'll be rereading in the years to come as i keep this book on a shelf within easy reach it's not perfect one of the combat descriptions just did not work for me in a particularly violent encounter bartle goes around the bend feels his soul slipping away maybe forever powers uses such long and complicated sentences the prose seemed over wrought and inappropriate but such off key moments are rare kevin powers can write powerfully i look forward to the next one

raw_text.741: this was pretty good although 10% of its pages and cover space was taken up by sentences in speech marks telling me how it was going to change my bloody life so it had a lot to live up to and didn't interesting that there was a plot rather than simply description of what had happened in al tafar the best part for me was actually the description in the whorehouse in germany it seemed horribly vivid and overlit and intense powers has good powers of description but relies quite unsubtly on the 'and this and this and this and that and this' technique when he's describing a particularly intense moment to communicate concertina'd time and lack of coherent thought this novel did make me understand to what extent the immense majority of people in europe and the us are not directly affected by the recent wars in iraq and afghanistan they happen far away on tv and we always win anyway the main character comes home to the us and ends up in prison standing on a pile of books he looks out of his barred window and beyond the tree line the dull world that ignored our little pest of a war rolled on
raw_text.742: heard mpr interview with powers and was really impressed powers draws out his story as slowly and round about as thread being unwound from a spool a thread with a few breaks snags and knots in it splicing subdued interior monologue together with acid dialogue and sudden bursts of violence the author opens the reader to the pride shame confusion camaraderie and dark nights of the soul faced by in country and returning soldiers powers pulls the reader in to the rooftop landscape of al tafar iraq as his unit waits through a long restless night and into morning for their instructions really fine writing elongates the minutes and gives the reader a sense of time stalling and circling like the dusty landscape a bit catch 22 as the guys tick off the number of deaths that will place the body count at 1000 us combatant deaths i must say that reading yellow birds really brought home to me that the iraq and afghanistan conflicts are real wars it is easy to watch the televised moments where troops celebrate thanksgiving or the 4th of july with a donated meal and a chance to speak to loved ones at home via skype from inside the relative security of the american compounds and see things as somehow safer and more civilized and less remote that earlier wars but like wwi and wwii there is still shelling and the need to drop and cover like korea there are cold unsheltered nights and like vietnam there are muddy trenches and night patrols where it is impossible to tell friend from foe not all soldiers ride in armored vehicles or attack forward positions from behind the anonymity of a drone there are still foot soldiers in the era of modern warfare and that is who's story is told in yellow birds powers alternates between the hard stock of the rifle gripped in the hand the tough love of his hard as nails slightly crazed sargent and again and again to the blurred form of tress obscured by smoke dust fog rain at the core is an un keep able promise

raw_text.758: this is a hard book to review parts of the writing were beautiful parts were over written the meat of the book is the dreamlike or rather nightmarish way that the narrator experiences things rather than the book's plot the narrator's viewpoint is somewhat random and disjointed the reader never really has a concrete grasp of events but is able to get a feel for the how random and disjointed it must be to face death on a daily basis the book is valuable in that it seems to give non veterans some idea of what is being experienced by thousands of young men and women fighting in iraq and afghanistan with the large numbers of people that have fought and re entered society it is useful to have some small way to relate to their experiences i have recently read two books set in the 1950s in which the plots hinged on how changed the men are when they come back from fighting in world war ii and that made me wonder how our current society is being changed by the fact that so many young people today are also coming back profoundly changed by their war experiences

raw_text.761: initially i found this novel a little difficult to get into and thought the first chapter was almost style over substance but after a bit i settled down into what turned out to be a good book it is mostly set in iraq in 2004 concerning two young soldiers john bartle and murph on a tour of duty that sees a lot of confrontation the overwhelming feeling of the book was that there are a lot of these young men or boys as john refers to himself and the others who having made the decision to join up are desperate to get home with no real idea about how awful life as a combat soldier would be or the terrible things that they would witness on an almost daily basis the iraq set storyline and it's sense of impending tragedy is broken up with chapters describing how john meets murph at the training camp and when john returns home to virginia after his tour ends death and destruction are never very far away from the group of soldiers and it is the impact of this upon their fragile states of mind and the lack of consideration by their superior officers which causes a breakdown in their abilities to function as required by the military there is a definite poetic feel to a lot of the book especially when john is describing his thoughts and feelings and this contrasts with a more straightforward prose style during the combat scenes kevin powers has written an affecting and honest book sometimes shocking as all good war novels should be and often moving in its depiction of the effects the war has on soldiers and their families

raw_text.776: kevin powers the yellow birds is a powerful novel about the war in iraq but it is broader then that and uses the iraqi conflict to illustrate the general horror of armed conflict i read this book during hurricane sandy's assault on the nj ny area i was fortunate to be hiding out in upper manhattan effectively untouched by the storm happily my own home at the jersey shore also escaped the wrath of the storm the sheer horror of what was happening around me somehow had a way of diminishing the violence of powers novel at the same timethe narrator of powers novel bartle refers regularly to the random craziness of the war and the fact that death selects some while shielding others struck me as a powerful metaphor for the arbitrary random destruction of the storm powers is a very skilled writer bartle's ruminations jump from iraq to the usa in an altered sequence that the reader can still absorb bartle is the unreliable narrator who tells greater truths in his narrative then a mere recitation of the bloody facts would provide the book is a sad elegy for those who fight our wars often in absurd conditions winning hearts and minds on monday dodging mortar rounds from the same people on tuesday and butchering the lot by thursday his character sterlingis an amalgamation of ahab and sargant barnes from platoon and murphy the casualty of war is billy budd and elias platoon and queequeg i think i will reread this book something i rarely do but in this instance probably worth doing i will be interested to see if powers writes about the next time in the mean time put this one on your list

raw_text.785: the yellow birds is a first person narration of the iraq war the protagonist bartle is a young man 21 who has made friends with a man in his unit named murphy 18 he was sort of coerced into saying he'd look after murphy by murphy's mother before they shipped out that promise begins to haunt him as he realizes that there is no way he can keep it and how unfair it was of her to ask him to do something so impossible the story covers the horrors of the war--the smells the blood the terror--as two boys are thrown together in a desperate fight for their lives the chapters alternate from al tafar during the fighting to the states after the fighting we follow murhpy and bartle through battles heartfelt chats close calls and ultimately insanity why did they join the war effort in the first place perhaps it was to prove masculinity because they had no other direction in life or some other reason is the greatest enemy in war your own mind how can you protect someone from their thoughts especially in such a high stress environment when bartle returns to the states and is faced with "normal" things like friends family etc he hates all of it and feels excluded he no longer has a home not because home has changed but because he has he feels guilty and angry home has become an unreachable ideal so he turns to alcohol and isolation kevin powers is a poet and that really comes through in this novel the book seems like one long poem at times its dreamlike quality can be confusing and frustrating especially since the plot is not that strong the yellow birds is more of a poetic tragic portrait of life for a soldier--not a story the prose definitely comes before the plot that said i think the dreamlike quality is very true to memory and especially bartle's memory no one ever remembers exactly how something happened there are always pieces missing or ones that don't quite fit together especially with traumatic events this book has come under some criticism for having archetypal characters i think this is definitely true of the borderline psychopath sargent who is relentless crude and violent however he was the only character that i thought was a little over the top this is one of the first novels about being a soldier in iraq told by a soldier the yellow birds had a similar but less intense effect on me as the things they carried one of my favorite books of all time and definitely my favorite war book o'brien was a soldier in vietnam and has written fictional stories about the war his entire life the situations that soldier's find themselves in are inhuman and so awful that the darkest part of the human psyche is revealed "a true war story is never moral it does not instruct nor encourage virtue nor suggest models of proper human behavior nor restrain men from doing the things men have always done if a story seems moral do not believe it if at the end of a war story you feel uplifted or if you feel that some small bit of rectitude has been salvaged from the larger waste then you have been made the victim of a very old and terrible lie there is no rectitude whatsoever there is no virtue as a first rule of thumb therefore you can tell a true war story by its absolute and uncompromising allegiance to obscenity and evil " - tim o'briena true war story is never moral that is something that really sticks out to me i don't think the yellow birds is moral by any means but i do think that bartle was redeemed in the end--the thing he was hiding from everyone wasn't actually that bad and he doesn't find forgiveness but he does find some kind of understanding from murphy's mother this is why the yellow birds didn't make it to 4 stars the ending wasn't heart breaking enough what does that say about me

raw_text.811: war as they say is hell it is insanity carnage ruin and heartbreak it steals the finest of every generation who are called or who have volunteered to do their part one of the few positives that emerges out of this stygian morass is the fine body of literature each produces from past conflicts we have the red badge of courage all quiet on the western front guadalcanal diary fields of fire the things they carried going after cacciato and dispatches to name but a few the recent conflicts in afghanistan and iraq are no exception they have brought forth both fine fiction and non fiction which includes sebastian junger's war restreppo joydeep roy bhattacharya's the watch and now this fine novel the yellow birds by kevin powers powers served in mosul iraq in circumstances that mirror the novel so he knows about that which he speaks of it provides a view of the daily life of a private and his platoon buddies on the front line soldiers are dealing with long periods of hyper vigilant boredom intermixed with the intermittent fire fights that are intense and vicious they rarely see the enemy face to face in the end they are not fighting for an ideal for democracy in iraq but for themselves and each other the hope that they can get back home in one piece where they are sure to face the psychological ghosts that will visit them regularly for years to come

raw_text.818: full review when i get back from northern wisconsin in short a thoughtful book that tries just a bit too hard to be profound and moving just a few thoughts now that i'm back from up north i've never met another person who didn't really like mitch albom's tuesdays with morrie not only did i find it emotionally manipulative but i also felt like the author was trying so so hard to infuse every page with transcendental wisdom and i remember finding that really really tiring now tuesdays with morrie doesn't have a whole lot in common with kevin powers's the yellow birds but i feel that powers like albom was just trying too hard i'll give it to powers the book is lyrical at times and he's able to create powerful imagery and powerful prose in general but dang it powers's desire to line every page with lyrical power takes away from the plot this is a book about war where not much happens and no i don't think that this is powers trying to illustrate the juxtaposition between crushing boredom and overwhelming sensory input that modern war creates it's just poorly paced powers gets lost in trying to create emotion but emotion needs to be driven by action too i would also argue in addition to the prose being overbearing that the structure of the book could be more thoughtfully constructed there's a passage from the book that i think speaks meaningfully to what powers was attempting to do in creating a very episodic nonlinear structure so i'm going to go ahead and quote that oh spoiler alert the character here is in prison and making marks every time he recalls something from his time in iraq eventually i realized that the marks could not be assembled into any kind of pattern they were fixed in place connecting them would be wrong they fell where they had fallen marks representing the randomness of the war were made at whatever moment i remembered them disorder predominated entropy increased in the six by eight food universe of my single cell the story is structured much like the marks in bartle's cell there doesn't always seem to be a clear reason for chapters being where they are though of course there is a reason the structure of the book in some way reflects the randomness of the war and the stress bartle feels as a result of that war formally then the structure works but i also felt like it took away from the dramatic structure as a whole all in all this isn't a bad novel i actually think it's quite good at illustrating just how morally disorienting going to war is and it's also quite good at illustrating just how hard it is for soldiers from the middle east wars to adjust to the world when they get back i actually think a chapter or two from this book would without the rest of the novel students would likely get frustrated by the apparent lack of action inner dialogue in the vein of hamlet wouldn't count as action for them maybe an independent novel for students interested in the topic i'm still looking for a novel that'll work for students about the iraq afghanistan wars though i'll find it someday powers's the yellow birds gave an old college try for sure sadly that's my biggest critique too

raw_text.820: what a perfect little book real without generalized over dramatization sentimental without being maudlin or nostalgic violence without idealization and richly sincere this was clearly written by a poet as it felt like a terrence malick film throughout so far the only book i've read this year that in my opinion could reasonably win the pulitzer highly recommended
raw_text.821: i got this book at bea and decided to read it first because i had seen the media blitz both there and on shelf awareness despite the author's poetic writing style and his flowing descriptions this book describes horrors of war that are disturbing and gruesome bartle the narrator is asked by his sargeant to keep a watch on the new soldier murphy the two become inseparable during the war while both slowly slipping into madness over the things they've had to both see and do i was taken aback by the fact that while this is a novel there are so many people experiencing these same things the story continues past the point where bartle is released from duty living a life taken over by ptsd waking up floating in rivers seeing signs of a childhood he can't quite remember and drinking himself into a hole while the book a debut novel isn't the most perfectly written piece of literature at times he seems to purposely be describing something horrifying in a beautiful poetic way which can seem contrived for shock value the book is still powerful and well worth the read it will make you look at war and soldiers in a different light
raw_text.822: powers' prose style can be a little hard to penetrate at first the sentences occasionally meander and the hyper poetic language sometimes obscures meaning however it is also muscular and unflinching and proves to be the ideal vehicle for this devastating account of young male friendship savagery and spoiled innocence the juxtaposition of images of arcadia hyacinths minarets orchards with the horrors of the battlefield shouldn't be shocking we all know that nature is beautiful and war is hell but powers' descriptions are so precisely rendered so particular that he makes you want to come with him even though you already know the things he wants you to see will be terrible and polluting the structure of this book sections alternate between the battlefield and the world before and after seems to sharpen the sense of beauty and goodness rendered irrelevant by the exigencies of war even where it survives as it does even in a mutilated body in a foul smelling river

raw_text.838: the yellow birds by kevin powers has been hailed as the all quiet on the western front for modern times it is the story of a young man who ventures off to war iraq charged with a duty and a promise to look out for his best mate and return him to his mother safely a promise he should never have made and had no hope of keeping reviewers have been so resoundingly positive about this novel that i am slightly nervous in adding my own thoughts lest they be construed as blasphemous because something about the flow did not resonate with me the story is told in a series of stilted interior monologues which although incredibly powerful in and of themselves seem to dominate to such a degree that the plot naew is entirely subjugated furthermore the monologues are disjointed shifting back and forth in time such that a person has to work unnecessarily hard to keep up as a rule i wouldn't normally mind this because i think this is an accurate reflection of how we actually experience our lives perhaps even more so when suffering from ptsd as john bartle clearly is life is lived backwards and around and circles as much as it is a linear experience and certainly powers can write you won't get any dispute from me on that point the depictions of the anxiety of war the pure state of constant stress and alertness that these young men live under are truly harrowing there is an honesty brutality but above all a genuine power for observation that shines through powers' writing but for all of that something in the authenticity of john bartle's voice just didn't ring true for me perhaps cumulatively the effort involved in following the various threads and piecing them together in their correct time sphere created a distance between us but whatever it was i just didn't connect with him i empathised but i wasn't always convinced he was telling me or himself the truth but maybe that's the point john bartle himself does say i felt like i was looking at a lie but i didn't mind the world makes liars of us all i sometimes wonder if an essay by kevin powers wouldn't have been equally or even more powerful certainly sebastian junger's non fiction title war had a profound impact on my view of the iraq war or perhaps all that is needed is a second reading and a little more faith next time naew not an evil word

raw_text.841: john a young soldier in his early 20s has just returned home after a year overseas in combat in northern iraq his days are occupied with thoughts of murph an even younger soldier who was just 18 when they shipped out murph was told to "put himself in john's back pocket" and that he did and john saw it as a duty to look after murph murph who was tiny looking more like a child than a man john also did something he should never have done - he promised murph's mother that nothing would happen to him that john would look after him that he would bring him home john cannot escape the memories they're everywhere he huddles up in his room only coming out to walk up to the liquor store and buy himself some beer despite the worry and pleadings of his mother he can't get what happened out of his mind and the role he played in it he knows it's only a matter of time until they come to find him the yellow birds had a little bit of a buzz around it on the internet and i have to admit it was the cover more than the story that interested me another novel on 'what it's like' to be in the middle of a war wasn't really my cup of tea but i was curious about the cover and slowly the good reviews and words of praise won me over it's a slim book i'd read it in less than two hours i was assured so i thought why not on one hand this book is wonderful - it's raw and honest and i can only assume that it might be what it's like to be in the middle of a war in a godforsaken place like northern iraq forced to shoot at women and kids young men anyone anything before they shoot you it's an area where small no tiny steps of progress are made and then lost as the enemy retreats regroups and then surges again it speaks of an exercise in futility of groundhog day hours and days spent doing the same thing to little or no result john and murph form a bond that seems through necessity or order rather than design but it seems to stick until murph struggling with the horrors of what he is seeing and experiencing begins to distance himself from john it is john's search for him to find out where he's been going that gives him the front and center view for what happens next but in other ways this book disappointed me perhaps that's once again my own fault for taking in high expectations and placing weight on many other opinions it jumps around in time starting in 2004 back to 2003 ahead to 2005 and then mostly jumping between 2004 and 2005 that's never my favourite way to find out what actually happened in a book to be jerked around in time - someone reminiscing about something jumping back there to explore that then leaping forward again without actually finding out what the big event was it could be argued that leaving the big reveal for very late in the book built the tension and the wondering but for me it actually did the opposite in the end i was aimlessly turning pages as i read about john drinking himself ridiculous in his childhood bedroom in 2005 until i got back to their tour of 2004 although i appreciated the glimpses into john's state of mind upon returning home to the us how uncomfortable he felt at the heroes welcome he received i still wanted to know what had happened in iraq this review is making it sound like i didn't enjoy the book at all i appreciated the book and i think i see the merit in it and the story it's telling and the way that it was written it will be the sort of book that resonates with many people but to be honest i just don't think that i'm one of those people it seems like this will be a book that helps some people understand just what it's like to be over there making friendships out of necessity that become strong and then losing them a war that seems like it's going no where that just keeps swallowing up young people from countries far away as well as obliterating a local population john is damaged when he returns damaged to the degree that he did something that he shouldn't have something that will see people in charge coming looking for him it's hard to really begrudge him the choice he made he no doubt believed he was doing something that would save someone agony or at least put it off a while his state of mind is actually quite well done - quite believable although my experience with veterans of any kind is limited i think in the end that it comes down to the fact that i appreciate this book and i understand what it is doing but it just isn't exactly for me it's not something i can see myself reading again but i think overall i'm glad i read it sounds sort of like how i feel about classics sometimes

raw_text.867: the quote on the cover compares this novel to all quiet on the western front though i found it closer to the things they carried though it is not postmodern like tttc it does contain some of the same motifs and themes of war reality memory and truth may never reflect what actually happened acts of bravery can come from our effort to hide our cowardice etc powers' story centers on two young privates one sworn to protect the other as they try to survive their tour of duty in iraq chapters alternate between private bartle's recollections of their tour and his attempt to reintegrate into his post war life the story is passionate and honest but also beautifully written and easy to read it is as if powers has finally been able to put into words the unimaginable what it is like to experience war although this is his first novel his experience and expression as a poet is evident on every page some of my favorite quotes grief is a practical mechanism and we only grieved those we knew all others who died in al tafar were part of the landscape as if something had sown seeds in that city that made bodies rise from the earth in the dirt or up through the pavement like flowers after a frost dried and withering under a cold bright sun 124 nothing is more isolating than having a particular history at least that's what i thought now i know all pain is the same only the details are different 132 you want to fall that's all you think you cant go on like that it's as if your life is a perch on the edge of a cliff and going forward seems impossible not for a lack of will but a lack of space the possibility of another day stands in defiance of the laws of physics and you can't go back so you want to fall let go give up but you can't 134

raw_text.870: the ten year anniversary of the war in iraq just passed a good time to look back by reading kevin powers' the yellow birds which some critics have called the best novel yet on that conflict the yellow birds is to be sure a powerful and masterfully written account of war trauma of young men who simply do not have the psychological resources to do battle in iraq's frightening cultural and geographical landscape we are not here in the claustrophic jungles of vietnam but in the searing desert where everything moral boundaries included whites out the three main characters the narrator private bartle his younger companion private murphy and their harsh sargeant all for quite different reasons are ultimately destroyed they are a poignant reminder of the human price we have paid in the search for those illusive weapons of mass destruction yellow birds is a somber but important read and one knows from the first sentence that kevin powers is an exciting new literary talent the war tried to kill us in the spring

dark to see into it but the images were there like an etching through the night the stench of the dead had cut itself free from the odors coming from al tafar the trash fires and sewage the heavy scent of cured lamb the river above all this was the stink of decay from the bodies themselves a shudder ran through my shoulders a quick shake as i hoped not to step into the slick mess of one of them as we marched to the fight " "when the mortars fell the leaves and fruit and birds were frayed like ends of rope they lay on the ground in scattered piles torn feathers and leaves and the rinds of broken fruit intermingling the sunlight fell absently through the spaces in the treetops here and there glistening as if on water from smudges of bird blood and citrus " "or should i have said that i wanted to die not in the sense of wanting to throw myself off of that train bridge over there but more like wanting to be asleep forever because there isn't any making up for killing women or even watching women get killed or for that matter killing men and shooting them in the back and shooting them more times than necessary to actually kill then and it was like just trying to kill everything you saw sometimes because it felt like there was acid seeping down into your soul and then your soul is gone and knowing from being taught your whole life that there is no making up for what you are doing you're taught that your whole life but then even your mother is so happy and proud because you lined up your sight posts and made people crumple and they were not getting up ever and yeah they might have been trying to kill you too so you say what are you gonna do but really it doesn't matter because by the end you foiled at the one good thing you could have done the one person you promised would live is dead and you have seen all things die in more manners than you'd like to recall and for a while the whole thing fucking ravaged your spirit like some deep down shit man that you didn't even realise you had until only the animals made you sad the husks of dogs filled with explosives and old arty shells and the fucking guts and everything stinking like metal and burning garbage and you walk around and the smell is deep down into you now and you say how can metal be so on fire and where is all this trash coming from and even back home you're getting whiffs of it and then that thing you started to notice slipping away is gone and now it's becoming inverted like you have bottomed out in your spirit but yet a deeper hole is being dug because everybody is so fucking happy to see you the murderer the accomplice the at bare minimum bearer of some responsibility and everyone wants to slap you on the back and you start to want to burn the whole goddamn country down you want to burn every goddamn yellow ribbon in sight and you can't explain it but its just like fuck you but then you signed up to go so it's all your fault really because you went on a purpose so you are in the end doubly f so why not just find a spot and curl up and die and lets make it as painless as possible because you are a coward and really cowardice got you into this mess because you wanted to be a man and people made fun of you and pushed you around in the cafeteria and the hallways in high school because you liked to read books and poems sometimes and they'd call you a fag and really deep down you know you went because you wanted to be a man and that's never gonna happen now and you're too much of a coward to be a man and get it over with so why not find a clean dry place and wait it unsure push of cause showed only that a fall is every objects destiny it is not enough to say what happened everything happened everything fell " "i took my woobie out of my pack and covered him i couldn't look anymore most of us had seen death in many forms the slick mess after a suicide bomber headless bodies gathered in a ditch like a collection of broken dolls on a child's shelf even our own boys sometimes bleeding and crying as it became apparent that the sound of a casevac was thirty seconds too far in the distance but none of us had seen this "

raw_text.905: his is a first novel by an ex soldier who fought in the iraq theater for a two year tour of duty in the al tafar region powers has since earned an mfa from ut austin this powerful novel was short listed for the national book award this year the story revolves around the friendship that develops between the hero twenty one year old private battle and eighteen year old private murphy the two men meet each other at boot camp and develop their the yellow birds 2012 kevin powers 1 2 tthis is a first novel by an ex soldier who fought in the iraq theater for a two year tour of duty in the al tafar region powers has since earned an mfa from ut austin this powerful novel was short listed for the national book award this year the story revolves around the friendship that develops between the hero twenty one year old private battle and eighteen year old private murphy the two men meet each other at boot camp and develop their bond as their service continues in iraq the pivot of the story is an unthinking promise made by battle to murphy's mother at their boot camp that he will look after murphy and bring him home safe murphy's mom asked for that promise thinking that battle being older would naturally be mindful of murphy's safety the book alternates between scenes in iraq in 2003 and 2004 and scenes afterwards in the states in 2005 and afterwards we really only get to meet one other member of their squad - their hardened sergeant - with most of the action being carried forward by our two main characters the novel is highly introspective the characters try to learn who they are as a result of the war but do not dwell on the reasons for the war itself in all this is an excellent novel that makes me look forward to what the next effort might be highly recommended

raw_text.907: powers has an mfa in poetry and it guess what it shows this personal narrative of the iraq war brims with succulent language and shocking imagery the story alternates back and forth between the protagonist's experiences during the war and back at home to the aftermath it is not long but it is also compulsively readable i finished it over about a 36 hour period reading it at night although you get a glimpse into a heartbreaking psyche one guesses this is very close to the writer's the most tantalizing reason to read this is powers words you just want to roll around them here is the very first paragraph the war tried to kill us in the spirng as grass greened the plains of ninevah and the weather warmed we patrolled the low slung hills beyond the cities and towns we moved over them and through the tall grass on faith kneading paths into the windswept growth like pioneers while we slept the war rubbed its thousand ribs against the ground in prayer when we pressed onward through exhaustion its eyes were white and open in the dark while we ate the war fasted fed by its own deprivation it made love and gave birth and spread through fire seriously many compare it to tim o'brien's the things they carried which is on my shelf but alas unread at this point leafing through it the comparison seems apt powers sense of compassion and human contradictions shine through here and the reader feels as if they have traveled half a lifetime in the span of 226 pages this may well be the definitive novel of the iraq war

raw_text.913: wow this is a fictionalized account of the war in iraq that is written by someone who was there the author has stated in interviews that he wrote the book to answer the question that is most often posed to him about his war experience--"what was it like over there " the short answer is that it was as bad as you would think it would be and worse the book is the narrative of a soldier witness still numbed by what he's seen private bartle is not filtering what he says to us in his account of his time in al tafar iraq his story is a beautiful and horrifying trance of a book as he takes us again and again to a dream like battlefield where unimaginable cruelties are inflicted upon combatants and civilians alike the men fight in al tafar in a setting that is dante esque in the broadest possible sense of that word the men of bartle's squad go there to see sin and to suffer and perhaps to survive and be somehow redeemed the torments they find in al tafar are described with a spare haunting lyricism that is both cilling and memorable on this battlefield in iraq private bartle finds himself caught between the conflicting demands of his role as soldier becoming the ruthless killer his commanding officer sgt sterling expects him to be and being the protector that the weakest member of the squadron needs him to be his inability to reconcile those contradictions is pulling him apart -- while ideas language and memory are the glue holding him together in the end private bartle loses his battle to be human and to remember and integrate what he did and saw in iraq with who he needs to be to be a well adjusted civilian he can fake it at times sometimes he even feels it but ultimately he has left a part of his ability to be happy and well adjusted on the ground in iraq a sad sobering and powerful book that serves as a well placed reminder that war is hell

raw_text.919: the yellow birds is the third book about war experience i've read recently that doesn't glorify it but describes it for what it is - a dehumanizing experience that more and more is grinding up young men's lives for dubious political mistakes and leadership failure the other two books were the excellent matterhorn and billy lynn's long halftime walk kevin powers indicates that the title for this book was taken from a traditional army marching cadence rhyme about a yellow bird getting it's f g skull crushed while sitting on a windowsill the verse reflects the type of de sensitization that occurs to people serving in war time during the time i was on an aircraft carrier in 1967 viet nam one of my buddies gave me a copy of a very similar poem about this same yellow bird getting it's same f g skull crushed while singing on a windowsill the brutality of war crushes any beauty we may wish to see in the world powers was a machine gunner who served in iraq in 2004 5 so he knows of what he speaks yellow birds is his first book and is powerfully well written it is the story of two young soldiers pfc bartle and murphy and their sergeant sterling and what happens as they are again sent out to clear an area of jihadists in the town of al tafar these are not the large scale battles of wwii or even viet nam but small engagements with largely unseen enemy who inflict most of their damage remotely through ied's and where soldiers are thrown into situations with civilian populace that they are ill prepared to deal with bartle has reluctantly given his pledge to get murph back to his mother safely and worries about him constantly through the prodding of their sergeant then following a tragic event murph wanders off into town and bartle and sterling go off to bring him back the story of what happens is grim and believable given the all too frequent news accounts of the types of things our forces in iraq have gone through

raw_text.953: i think this book made all the year end best lists for its status as the first novel about the iraq war the author is a veteran with an mfa and the story explores masculinity guilt depression and ambivalence so it places itself solidly in the war book genre the main character bartles is an enlisted soldier and his story is told in chapters that alternate between the war and his return home to richmond va and tells a slowly unfolding story about what happened to murph his best friend during the war that has bart so tangled up kevin powers' book starts with an amazing first line and he is clearly enamored with language however metaphor and language play should not be the enemy of clarity and unfortunately powers' book suffered from sentence length sentences and prose that when read aloud sounded beautiful but when i tried to actually parse the meaning there really was none i am a 40 something lifelong passionate reader i was an english major and english teacher and both a teacher and student of writing i have read widely and appreciate challenging beautifully written books while reading this book i had a revelation for the first time i realized that if i cannot follow what is going on the problem is in the writing not in the reader i sincerely think that powers is talented and think the story he has to tell about the horrors of modern war in the middle east are important and thus i look forward to reading his work once he has an thoughtful editor guiding him

raw_text.963: john bartle is a private in the us army during the iraq occupation bartle is implicated in an act that while committed with the best of intentions almost destroys his mind and any moral sense he retains after his experiences in iraq like his narrator powers served as a soldier in iraq he says that the yellow birds began as 'an attempt to reckon with one question what was it like over there ' he discovered that he couldn't answer the question because 'war is only like itself' in spite of the inadequacy of words powers presents us with a highly sensitive and perceptive portrayal war and its effects the novel is fractured moving from place to place and jumping from past to future over the space of six years this serves several purposes to underscore bartle's concept of retelling the war as being like 'putting a puzzle together from behind' to make the reader move in and out of the narrative thereby becoming somehow complicit and to show how war destroys not only bodies and buildings but also the mind this disordered narration alongside the discordant vernacular of powers' characters situates this novel firmly in an american tradition of war writing the power of the novel is not merely that it bears testament to this particular war but that it retains a lingering humanity despite the incomprehensible violence and devastation bartle's memories are the emotive heart of this story making the reader look at what they would rather ignore

raw_text.1001: i am not generally one for war books but if you are going to make an exception for one this is a good choice the story is told by one private john bartle it is a story of his time in iraq of his return home and of his loss of a good friend it is a story of guilt and of brutality yet in that i do not feel this book makes a judgement on this particular conflict so much as a judgement on the nature of war in and of itself the author is a poet and it's evident throughout the passages some so dazzling lyrical you find yourself swimming in them more than reading and comprehending yet they add depth to our narrator's character both emotionally and intellectually it's not always enjoyable reading it's heavy and there are times when you want to shake the main characters heartily moreover i'm not fond of what i feel the writer wanted me to see as the bigger tragedy view spoiler i'm supposed to be more upset that murphy's mutilated body was sent down the river to save his mother a last look at a deformed son than the fact that sterling shot and killed an innocent man with bartle in silent agreement that man's death deserved more than the couple year stint in jail that was served we can argue over the mercy of what was done with murph's body but there is no conscience in what they did to that man further separation of seeing the enemy as less than human hide spoiler therefore the ending did not resolve as nicely for me as it may for some regardless though this book looks at a lot of the realities of war the tight bonds formed the unquestioning loyalty for people that may be less than savory but who will save one's ass when needed the utter burn to go home and yet the utter disappointment with knowing how to exist once one returns something resembling ptsd or at least survivor's guilt and so much more to me this is commentary on the great equalizer more than any specific conflict and does that quite beautifully

raw_text.1004: i did not want to read this book it was my library book group's selection for may i generally like to read happy books and i really did not want to experience the war in iraq through the pages of a novel kevin powers was a soldier in iraq and that gave the novel credibility to me it was not someone writing about war just to sell books but because they had experienced it and perhaps writing about it was therapeutic i found myself feeling obligated to read it many men and women have gone to war and died or been permanently altered so i may live the life i do i felt i owed it to them to take a small glimpse at what they may have gone through i could not in good conscience continue to hide from what i didn't want to know the writing is often very lyrical and beautiful even when the subject matter is not you feel bartle's isolation pain and moral conflict in nearly every page the book bounces back and forth in time and is sometimes hard to follow most of the book group agreed it would be good to go back and read it again to grasp more of the story and all the implications of the soldiers' actions my heart aches for the soldiers and their families for all they go through in service to our country it is hard to believe a book i didn't want to read and can't really say i enjoyed is now on my need to read again list
