raw_text.1006: this book this book i have never taken so long to read such a short book not because it was one of those books not worth the time but because this book is worth the time not a page went by i didn't take in a breath and go back and read it again even more slowly sometimes many times before i could move on it is a beautifully written mesmerising book it is also utterly devastating it should be essential reading for anyone responsible for starting a war and for anyone thinking of starting one and for everyone in between it is about the intimate experience of war about the failure of memory to make sense of it and about the necessity of trying to do just that it is a psychological journey and is also a philosophical one - about choice about memory about trying to live and live on but most of all it is about the disintegration war reaps at every level while there may be some faces missing from the last pages which i felt should have also been present in the shadows beneath the trees or traced along the lines of a map this book leads you on an unforgettable journey along a path of fires burning in the dust

raw_text.1026: the yellow birds by kevin powers is narrated by john "bart" bartle a 21 year old virginia kid trying to survive a stint in the 2004 iraq war the opening line "the war tried to kill us in the spring " sets the tone for a beautifully written grippingly realistic novel where we find ourselves immersed in the place and time that is "over there " powers an iraq war veteran himself is an unusually good writer of setting he makes us feel the unbearable heat has us choke on the continual dust and submits us to the "orchestral whine of falling mortars " the narrative weaves back and forth in time between the war the time before the war when bart joins up and his struggle to find his footing back at home after the war in december 2003 at fort dix nj bart meets a new recruit 18 year old daniel "murph" murphy who is immediately assigned to "get in bartle's back pocket" and to stay there bart makes a promise to murph's mother to bring him home safely and thus their stories become intertwined and inextricable there is no mystery about who survives and who dies in the book but the horrific details of how murph unravels and bart's reactions and momentous decisions are revealed slowly throughout the story bart's difficulties adjusting to life after the war are only enhanced by his strong ties to the kid he had promised to bring home safely bart's main conclusion about war is that there is really nothing to conclude there is no order everything is random and there is only so much soldiers can do to survive intact you can "find that nasty streak" inside yourself and follow orders and make yourself small when you are in a tight spot but each bullet and mortar could have anybody's name on it the war "tried to kill us every day but it had not succeeded not that our safety was preordained we were not destined to survive the fact is were not destined at all the war would take what it could get it was patient and i knew the war would have its way " this beautiful horrific war story was a 2012 national book award finalist

raw_text.1028: this is an achingly well written book murph is a friend a fellow soldier in iraq murph took a photograph from his helmet and placed it over the letter using it to cover the words that would come next giving each line its due attention the way that old men do when reading obituaries of friends learning late the small measures of their lives and wondering how it was they came not to know these things wow powers packs so much into his images and they worm their way into my psyche to change my impressions of war soldiers young men smoking iraq and re entry into american life this book is told from a soldier's perspective as he tromps his way through basic training on to iraq and then to a town for repeated battles the chapters alternate between the time of the war and the time after the war when he finds himself physically at home but mentally in hell this book reminds me of a separate peace and also the things they carried maybe with a bit of hemingway thrown in his writing though is magnificent he ends one chapter a battle with the red and the purple of the desert evening rising to paint the scene in their lovely languid colors like billie lynn's long halftime walk this is a book that all americans should read in order to understand and offer solace to those who have spent time in this unending set of wars

raw_text.1034: a little late to this review i am still reeling from this book several months later the yellow birds tells the first person account of private bartle and his friendship with private murphy as they go from basic training to the dangers of war in al tafar iraq given the job of protecting murphy as they navigate the physically and mentally exhausting reality that is war bartle takes drastic action as murphy begins to detach from the reality around him i read this book as a buddy read with my son for his high school english course being his choice book i was a little let down when he brought the book home but after only a few chapters found myself at the bookstore buying my own copy to annotate as we read dark and poetic the prose left me breathless at times and saddened by the reality of the effects of war on families at home and its lasting effects on our young protagonist this book was beautiful yet heartbreaking essentially a puzzle piece mystery the book jumps around in time and place however it was not difficult to follow each story line from the last all leading up to a dramatic conclusion that i did not see coming of course it was bloody and graphic during the scenes of war but was also poignant and heartwarming during bartle's time at home with his mother these moments were especially difficult for me i will admit i got choked up as my son had at one time expressed an interest in enlisting this book is hands down depressing and suspenseful and was difficult to put down we had a hard time reading only the assigned reading each week we constantly wanted to jump a head the yellow birds has become a new favorite and one i anticipate revisiting in the near future
raw_text.1035: spoilers plot questions in attached comments no spoilers in review heartbreaking you will want to gather up bartle in your arms and hold him for hours on end until you are somehow able to impart to him the transfusion of serenity he so desperately needs and heartbreakingly beautiful prose we were lined along the ditch up to our ankles in a soupy muck it all seemed in that moment to be the conclusion of a poorly designed experiment in inevitability everything was in its proper place waiting for a pause in time for the source of all momentum to be stilled so that what remained would be nothing more than detritus to be tallied up the world was paper thin as far as i could tell and the world was the orchard and the orchard was what came next but none of that was true i was only afraid of dying p 115 stunning stretches of prose reveal an author with tremendous potential his writing conjures up terrence malick like imagery evocative simultaneously dreamy yet full of stinging barbs for the time being though it's a three star after all the buildup the ending just did not work for me this reader requires more explanation a bit more guiding into home port i'm gonna chew on things a while and allow for the possibility that i just need the big wrap up to simmer on the back burner for a bit update still have nagging questions two days later see my questions major spoilers in the comments

raw_text.1066: if you want to reinforce the futility and the human cost of war then kevin powers debut novel is a modern benchmark as powers himself served in iraq in 2004 and 2005 its a moot point as to how much of his primary character john bartles is autobiographical powers was is a poet and its his gritty descriptions of the brutal day to day war mongering that make the yellow birds a modern day war classic think iraq's version of hemingway's a farewell to arms or stepehn crane's the red badge of courage yes it's that good and i certainly haven't read a book so personal and graphic about the daily grind and emotional damage that the us soldiers deal with bartles relationship with his buddy murph is the focus of the story both during their tour of duty and on bartles return to his hometown of richmond virginia to use the term post traumatic stress syndrome doesn't go anywhere near recognising what these guys go through one of the touching aspects of john and murph's relatiosnhip in the field was counting down to the 1 000th us fatality in iraq and hoping it wasn't them not an easy read but that's war not many winners lots of losers

to his own experience as a soldier in iraq there are not happy moments in this book for it is about war man's greatest inhumanity to man the scene alternates between richmond virginia and al tafar nineveh province iraq private bartle carries the war inside himself wherever he is the main characters are 21 and 18 when they meet in basic training at the end of the book the 21 year old is damaged forever and the 18 year old is dead kevin powers the author joined the army at the age of 17 later serving as a machine gunner in iraq in 2004 and 2005 as we know from the death notices war is fought by young people that in itself makes war an abomination we disparage foreign countries that have "child soldiers" without acknowledging the similar role of the united states military i am used to people being killed in books about war but i had a strange shock from this book the "casualty feeder card" kept by each field soldier under his helmet liner it is the military being bureaucratic at the top of the card in the appropriate boxes murph had written the requested information his name murphy daniel his social security number his rank his unit below that were other boxes left blank in case the need arose to record an assortment of information with a quick x in ink there was a box for killed in action for missing in action and for wounded in action either lightly or seriously there was a box for captured and for detained and for died as a result of wounds there were two sets of yes or no boxes one each for body recovered and body identified there was a space for witness remarks and for the signature of the commanding officer or medical personnel murph has placed an x in the box for body recovered "just in case " he said when he caught me looking both of our cards were signed already strangely the yellow birds has a certain elegance you can see that the words have been carefully chosen the book is both lyrical and distressing the war tried to kill us in the spring as grass greened the plains of nineveh the weather warmed we patrolled the low slung hills beyond the cities and towns ...then in summer the war tried to kill us as the heat blanched all color from the plains needed another distressing book about war as long as we insist on fighting them people will continue writing about them this one is well written and caused me to think about how people deal with the ultimate tragedy of war when they meet it face to face maybe we each need to see for ourselves that "his eyes had been gouged out the two hollow sockets looking like red angry passages to his mind " or maybe the colonel back at the operation center needs to see it we keep trying to hide the crass ugliness of bodies made unrecognizable in war and the damaged minds of those who survive four stars

raw_text.1108: in a war novel there are a few givens detailed geographical descriptions of areas you will never go to and a great deal of rumination from soldiers punctuated by brief episodes of intense action that show war to be terrible and life to be nasty brutish and short someone really should write a pro war novel just to mix it up a bit although he doesn't stray much from these well established tropes kevin powers tells the story of his particular war iraq where he was stationed in 2004 and 2005 in a way that transcends the genre with writing that's visceral compelling poignant and painful the yellow birds which won the 2012 guardian first book award is told in fragments and semi remembered moments all fogged by the sleep deprivation of the war and the drunken haze that pvt john bartle finds himself in constantly after returning home bartle makes an ill advised promise to the mother of another soldier pvt daniel murphy "murph" to bring her son home safely and from the outset we're told that he failed to do so although you know this from the outset powers keeps things mysterious and confusing providing a trail of just enough clues to keep the reader actively involved in unraveling the mystery of what happened to murph and the extent of its effect on bartle the most powerful parts of the novel are its ability to make fiction feel like non fiction its depictions of violence the pointlessness of that violence the mindsets the soldiers use to make it all as impersonal as possible the difficulties in returning home and the small details like soldiers rubbing tabasco in their eyes to stay awake or that months after returning home bartle finds his hands instinctively clenching an imaginary gun there are a few too many overly introspective passages gilded with ornate phrases that combine the worst of hallmark sentiments and dime store philosophy e g "though it's hard to get close to saying what the heart is it must at least be that which rushes to spill out of those parentheses which were the beginning and end of my war..." there's too much space given over to describing the lush lakes mountains and other geographic features of bartle's and powers' native richmond and bartle's occasional use of words like "apse" and "fricative" feel like a bit of a stretch for a character who enlisted at 18 but the novel's driven pacing and fragmentary style prevent any of these moments from lasting too long or detracting too much from the overall result this style also serves the novel's substance the broken non linear narrative reflecting bartle's broken state and the destructive powers of war powers also manages to play with the expectations readers bring to the genre as he does in one particularly memorable scene where the soldiers in his unit all gather around a comrade who's dying from a stomach wound the soldiers all want to be present to hear the dying man's last words in part because we all expect those words to provide some sort of meaning the moment otherwise lacks when he dies without saying anything the soldiers all wander off dejected in a new way they can't quite describe even if you sort of know what to expect it's heartbreaking poetic haunting and one of the more memorable books of the year

raw_text.1112: there were a few acclaimed novels released last year about the war in iraq being one of those the yellow birds can easily be marketed as a book of the times the connection to the war is not the reason for its relevance although it does accentuate its connectedness to the present something about powers' debut reminds me of two other wonderful and recent examples of american fiction teju cole's open city and aleksandar hemon's love and obstacles both of those books contend with isolation resultant from immigration although cole's like powers' also has a traumatic guilt inducing event that infects every detail of the protagonist's journey maybe forced immigration precipitates emotions similar to those felt by the veteran upon his return home and with the same disparity between self image riddled by guilt and shame and the unknowing care and interest inflicted by regular folk i read a criticism of the yellow birds condemning it for its flimsy story the narrative story is indeed flimsy almost non existent but only the shallowest of readers can condemn a book for that there is a compelling emotional story told here just as in open city and maybe it's not for everyone you will not feel good while reading this and you may at times cringe at the gross self consciousness of the overly crafted language but the overblown language is endearing and honest in its way the soldier is reaching to explain truths simple straight forwardness may have been more effective but it would also be a different book

raw_text.1135: fantastic phenomenal outstanding i wanted to follow the life of the main character inside and outside his mind for years to come rarely during my six years of counseling veterans with the va was i able to tolerate film or literature about war whereas previously i was compelled many times during and since veterans or others have said you should read this it will tell you what it was like i had the honor and privilege of hearing what it was like from veterans in my office every day of the week for six years a colleague gave me a copy of the yellow birds this year on thanksgiving and i passively accepted thinking here's another one until i like many was hooked by the first paragraph and continued on with the poetic unfolding of one young man's journey into the military war and a life forever changed kevin powers is able as he notes in the author interview at the back of the book to transcend the mere details of the story and elevate the experience to transcendental heights that echo the archetypes of the human experience of pain confusion hope hopelessness connection disconnection disillusionment and survival i thank him for writing this book which i think will give civilians some level of access to the inner world of a traumatized soldier i look very forward to more of his works to come his service continues powerfully and meaningfully through his literary contributions to our nation and the world

raw_text.1151: the yellow birds by kevin powers tells the story of two soldiers' who served in iraq to say it is powerful haunting and memorable seems inadequate for this stunning debut novel two young soldiers private bartle 18 and private murphy 21 are sent to iraq with the same unit and stationed in al tafar immediately immersed in a bloody battle for the city surrounded by death and destruction they follow orders protect each other and do everything they can to stay alive responsibility becomes a key issue - exactly what are a soldier's responsibilities beyond the orders when reading some of the battle scenes or the scenes in the village i could almost hear them because of powers' exquisite description - the artillery children in the streets dogs barking the commander shouting orders the cries the humvees engines and the explosions this novel is stark beautiful and gut wrenching as we find more about private bartle's emotional upheaval after he returns home we see he doesn't fit in his former life nothing fits nothing works he has too much guilt too many overwhelming memories he can't function we see the never ending military machine pursue him pursue a truth relentless in its search for a justice that will close an official book bartle is swept up and away powers is an iraq war veteran he served in the army in mosul and tal afar he just received his m f a in poetry from the michener school of writing in austin this year this book stands up there with tim o'brien's the things they carried karl marlantes matterhorn and remarque's all quiet on the western front and three day road by joseph boyden and nick arvin's articles of war i look forward to reading more of his work

raw_text.1155: while i was reading this short novel i got caught up in the lovely prose and the vaguely stream of consciousness style there is a lot of emotion here if not a ton of story after finishing it and thinking about it a lot though i'm a left a little wanting the three main characters bartle murph and sterling end up as vague sketches though i guess in a way that's the point bartle reflects on how little he really knew murph and how sterling has certain traits he projects but seems to be something else entirely saving private ryan comes to mind how the crew would have never guessed that tom hanks was a schoolteacher in his real life but iraq is not wwii and the circumstances surrounding why we as a country and they as enlisted men with their own reasons for joining up are even there are staggering in their contrast an impossible not to consider though the book is not overtly political the author is a poet and i don't really get poetry while i appreciated his ability to place me into the fog of modern war i can't help but feel like so much could have been clarified for the sake of an understandable plot what did sterling do to the body in the orchard that they left behind what was the deal with bartle's letter to murph's mom did he explain at the prison what happened with murph and why he and sterling did what they did it seemed to me that what they did was a mercy well they did also murder a guy to cover up what they did and that was absolutely reprehensible but in the story bartle seems less worried about that than the murph issue in the scene with sterling at the bar brothel it seemed they were talking about murph rather than the hermit and wtf did happen with murph the verdict i guess a quick and effecting if not very satisfying read

raw_text.1165: there is no dearth of cultural representations of the abrasive effects of war fuelled by a healthy dose of hindsight bias short sightedness is an enduring feature of every war and the yellow birds brings it into sharp focus with prose that is as poetic as it is devastatingly sad it is a little too descriptive at times with an obtuseness that at its worst reminded me of conrad but persist and it is a deeply rewarding experience the book elects to follow just three individuals in the iraq war with no allusions to the grander designs of people who run nations we see them up close witness their slow deterioration in an alien land and the eventual disillusionment with a war they have no incentive to fight anymore there are no heroic deeds no daring rescues and no spine tingling table thumping speeches there is no outright denouncement of the war but what would the point of that have been anyway even more heart wrenching is the struggle to adapt to society on one's return the war clings like a leech that can't be shaken off there is the slightest glimmer of hope in the end and given the raw power of this novel it is sorely needed

raw_text.1170: this book absolutely took my breath away this book written by an iraqi war vet about two young men fighting in the iraq war is absolutely breathtaking i know that i have never read a book like this one ever it left me bereft and sad at the end the book was a finalist for the national book award for 2012 the writing is lyrical and intense at the same time i knew as i read this book that i was allowed to be privy to the innermost thoughts of a real human being i don't know what kevin powers' war was like but i would guess from this book that it was life altering scary and heartbreaking the two young men in the book private john bartle and private daniel murphy are best friends and inseparable from the spring to the fall of 2004 but war forever changes people as it changes murphy and bartle so that neither one is really recognizable to the other by the end of october that same year most of the action of the war takes place on a specific rooftop and in the streets of al tafar iraq this was the war theatre for these two boys and they didn't see much else for those 5 or 6 months sometime in september of 2004 murph seems to withdraw as he's trying to fight his own private demons john can't understand what murph is going through but sergeant sterling explained to him that murph has his head in the states while his body was still in iraq and this wouldn't end well for him the writing in the book is graphic and lyrical at the same time it's definitely not an easy book to read because of the sadness and despair of war which is so well depicted in this book but it's definitely a book that should be read a modern day classic

raw_text.1181: mesmerizing prose twists and turns the reader through time and events so deftly that we find ourselves in a situation similar to those of the main characters in this brutally beautiful novel we haven't got a sense of the larger picture because we're so focused on our moments our lives and making it through to the end this is a soldier's eye view of war cynical terrified and sick with a jaundiced eyeball cast briefly at morality legality and patriotism far from humanizing the so called enemy or even soldiers in general through specific characters this novel makes others of everyone but the three most important to the tale the narrator daniel murphy the soldier he promised to take care of and sergeant sterling the one with the means to actually get them through their tour in iraq this isn't an anti war novel though it is insofar as the truths illuminated should be heeded by those considering declaring or fighting a war nor a defense of the soldier but a tale of disassociation dissolution and the near impossibility of returning from being turned to sand and blown across the desert

raw_text.1187: although this is only one man's perspective and experience as a us soldier in iraq i do think this is a book that every person or at least american needs to read i have no doubt there are countless other memoirs or even novels like this one that have important things to say either about what the war was like or just what it feels like to return from war i think this one may be different at least for me because the story was told by a poet powers' language and descriptions were sometimes lovely sometimes harsh but what always seemed honest it's not just about being a soldier but about friendship loss and grief this review will never do the book any justice so all i can do is urge you to just read the first 5 pages that's all you'll need to want to know what happens to private bartle and private murphy i hope you give it a chance

raw_text.1191: for me this was a flawless book the narrative story alone is worth every star but it was the poetic voice and rhythm that made it a reading experience i will never forget i've read many reviews lauding the first sentence the war tried to kill us in the spring and though it is a sort of i am an invisible man it was passages like this that had me rapt i set my duffel on the ground and got a fire going and took my boots off and hung them on a branch near the fire my feet were in the water and the river ran docilely by and i was hardly a speck on the landscape and i was glad and egret flew just over my shoulder and skimmed the water so close and i thought there was no way a body could be so close to the edge of a thing and stay there and be in control but the tips of its wings skimmed along the water just the same the egret didn't seem to mind what i believed and it tilted some and disappeared into the glare of the gone sun and it was full of grace it's almost a biblical passage i often felt reading this as if the whole novel was in verse there were dozens of passages like this i was reminded of charles frazier's cold mountain except the story pushed through and ultimately became as important as the themes ideas and wonderful prose i can't wait for more works whether volumes of poetry or novels

raw_text.1200: the yellow birds starts with the most effective line i've read in a while the war tried to kill us in the spring it's also one of the best books i've read about a subject i can't care less about if i tried it's not war i have problems with i have no issues reading book after book covering world war ii it's a war i understand i know why it had to be fought not so with iraq this book didn't help me suddenly realize that subduing iraq was important it's not that kind of book tom wolfe calls it the all quiet on western front of america iraq war and that's perhaps the most accurate description of the book it describes two soldiers who aren't as close as they'd like to be one of them dies after drifting off once he feels the full horror of what he's enlisted into the other one does some stupid things but things he feels to be important and necessary at the time he gets back tries to assimilate but it seems the world has moved on without waiting for him and the gratitude of non service men grates in the face of what he has been through the stupid things catch up with him he's tried and he feels safer in captivity and isolation than he ever will without the plot doesn't sound revolutionary indeed it isn't it's been done before what makes powers' book different is the outstanding prose he has a beautiful lyrical voice even when speaking off messes made by exploding grenades the book evokes time and place wonderfully as well it does matter when reading a book about the futility of war that the author have served that he knows and has been there it does have a few problems ones i discount as minor the mystery surrounding the death of one of the soldiers the stupid things that the other one did the trial a letter that was falsely written all mcguffins to the point of concern which is futility and isolation which points are powerfully made i am going to keep my eye out on whatever powers writes next

raw_text.1205: on the day i finished this book and decided it was one of the most overrated things i've read in ages it won the guardian's first book award for 2012 ha i am obviously in a minority with my opinions about the yellow birds i can find few negative reviews certainly none from critics and it seems none of those who dislike it do so for all the same reasons as me the yellow birds is a vague hazy story about two american soldiers john bartle and his young naive friend daniel murphy known as murph when the pair are sent to iraq bartle makes an ill advised promise to murph's mother that he will protect her son as far as the book has a plot this moment forms its backbone the reader knows from the beginning that murph dies before the army returns home split between virginia the home state of both men in 2005 and iraq in 2004 the narrative progresses towards an explanation of what happened to murph and why bartle feels so guilty about it as well as examining bartle's difficulties in adjusting to civilian life powers was a soldier himself and fought in iraq so there is a sense that this is a thinly veiled autobiography particularly as bartle's story is told in first person because the background of this story is the iraq war i expected it to actually be about the iraq war rather than just war generally and it's barely about that anyway i thought the narrative would have questions to ask why these men were there what they thought they were doing what their personal justifications were for fighting in fact there's none of this the characters just go ahead and do what they're told to be fair i suppose that's probably true of the mentality of soldiers otherwise they wouldn't be good soldiers but it isn't what i wanted from this book there is no examination of the war itself as the focus is all on bartle and murph's relationship when powers touches on the psychological aftermath of war it's only with reference to what happened to murph with barely an acknowledgement of all the other killing bartle has done i couldn't muster much sympathy for the characters partly because they knew what they were going to iraq to do and partly because i just didn't believe the two protagonists could really be all that close i also don't think this book is as well written as a lot of people think it is it's florid that's all and sometimes the description works and sometimes it doesn't at points the narrative is so heavily descriptive it stops making sense by the time i finished the book i was absolutely sick of all the hyperbole all the laboured metaphors and supposedly 'poetic' language reviews quoted on the jacket of the yellow birds laud it as 'deeply compelling' and 'inexplicably beautiful' i found it dull annoying and vague i wasn't moved or shocked or anything like that not a bit this is the first time in ages that i have not only disliked a book but have also completely disagreed with the critics that it's well written i've read plenty of much praised novels i haven't liked but usually i can still appreciate the skill involved in creating them see skippy dies and the sea for example i am getting a sense from some reviews in the press that is not from readers that there's a reluctance to criticise this book because it was written by a real life war veteran in any case the rest of the world and the guardian and i are just going to have to agree to disagree about the yellow birds

raw_text.1211: this is quite a valuable read it's perfectly structured and beautifully written no surprise that powers was a michener fellow in poetry at ut austin on one of the cover blurbs tom wolfe compares yellow birds to all quiet on the western front and i think that's fair while the anti war sentiment is palpable all the way through what the novel is really about is one young man's inner struggles his name is bartle especially his struggles consequent to the death of his best army friend a man named murph and we know almost from the beginning that murph has died strange for a war novel especially a war novel that shows war action it's a very quiet book one focused much more strenuously on the interior moments of bartle's struggle rather than the violent unpredictable action indeed according to one important sargeant character the fates of the various soldiers in bartle's unit are hardly unpredictable at all in any case the sad elegiac tone the way in which all of existence seems to have overwhelmed bartle to the extent that it is difficult for him to even get up in the morning to even move feels reminiscient to the exquisitely painful and introspective all quiet on the western front this isn't like tim o'brien with his cast of eccentrics and his metafictional pyrotechnics this is just a terribly somber straightforward look at the psyche of one person badly injured by war i mentioned the structure that might be the most eloquent thing about the novel yellow birds moves back and forth between 2004 in iraq and both earlier and later episodes in bartle's life we see bartle and murph in training we see them graduate from training and hear the terrible promise murph's mother extracts from bartle we see bartle pass through germany and go temporarily awol on his way back home after his tour we see his first lonely hours and days back in the states we see him fall apart under the weight of what can only be termed ptsd and finally we learn that he is being pursued by the army for possible criminal actions in regards to his friend's death each of these episodes is interspersed with the 2004 action in iraq and so there's a building mystery in the book what exactly happened with murph accurate to say that powers delays showing us as long as human possible perhaps because powers is himself a veteran of the iraq war his bio says he was a machine gunner none of what we see of the war seems ridiculous or beyond belief just very very dreadful it's not a book that is without hope but neither is it a bag of laughs you just feel this beating heart of hurt all the way through expressed in language so poetic it almost redeems the subject

raw_text.1223: as i finished this book last night and exhaled heavy hearted i told my brother i must be a terrible person because i did not see the wonder of this book my brother just told me it's because i am my own person and i do my own thinking well whatever the reason this book is a three star book i wanted it to be a four but there is nothing to keep one tethered to this story i read several reviews and one said absence of a strict plot does not a bad novel make i would agree but absence of any plot and characters does a bad novel make i wanted to love these soldiers and i wanted to feel some of what they feel and to walk a day in their shoes but what i got was paragraph after paragraph describing an iraqi city a tree a body a river there didn't seem to be an inanimate object that wasn't entitled to a paragraph description the book is poetic and some of that poetry is beautiful much of it is however wasted some of the descriptions are so bizarre and abstract it bordered on silly by the time the truth is revealed about why the main character is a wreck post deployment i didn't even care and there in lies the weakness of this book when the truth secret is revealed it is a let down it's simply not gripping enough to justify the pages and pages of literary poetry i just waded through i once heard someone say that the best stories have small plots and i would tend to agree but this plot was so small and the characters so underdeveloped that it felt forced both the writing and the flow of the story felt contrived and insincere

raw_text.1230: a remarkably haunting lyrical novel about fighting in the us army in the recent conflict in iraq so much of it is almost the exact opposite of what i expected from a fictional treatment of this subject matter it's like a dreamy prose poem interrupted by horrifying jagged moments of brutality the bits of war in other words that we try to avoid thinking about i keep asking myself what people would think of this book if the author's bio read something like kevin powers has an mfa from stanford and lives in brooklyn but no powers was there right there and it seeps through every page the sheer trauma and weirdness of it there's a tiny cast of characters really the young narrator his 18 year old fellow soldier murph and their psychotic sergeant who's hardly any older than the two of them but the book doesn't need much more than that it's intimate and so many of the tiny details stick with you for days afterwards i don't know enough about the genre of war fiction to be able to rate this with much confidence but i'd be amazed if there's a more compelling novel written about this particular conflict
raw_text.1231: great read short terse powerful poetic and completely capturing the author's intention of answering the unanswerable question when he returned "so what was it like over there " i don't want to give anything away so i will keep this short but it amazes me that he could fit so many different sides of his experience into 227 pages his narrative has chapters that fluctuate back and forth in time from 2004 in iraq to 2005 outside of iraq and it really is the best way to tell this story to capture not only the experience of training and the battles themselves but the after war experiences the families' experiences the traumatic return home to a world where no one understands there was one passage that perfectly encapsulated the pts symptoms we all hear about but never really understand others that tackle the flirtations with suicide we all discard so easily another that portrays a moment of beauty in the midst of the shit - all of these function so well in tandem with the plot i feel like i had been standing next to bartle the whole time it's a very dark book but what can you expect when you deal with the iraq war there's not much of the rest of the war no march to baghdad to 2007 insurgency to fight but the portrayal powers gives us is concise each scene perfectly showing us an aspect of war that is unforgettable yet unavoidable and so emotional that it will stick with you forcing you to look at the non fictional news reports with a new mindset

raw_text.1235: okay full disclosure did a tour myself so i'm a little biased and a lot interested when another veteran takes his shot at the iraq novel i can say that this is the best one i've seen so far and powers came back from tal afar in 2005 so i'd say it's had enough time to marinate before he put pen to paper yellow birds takes place in iraq but the novel runs deeper in its examination of war the socialization of young men into cohesive units ptsd atonement for sins is it omission or commission fate mother son relationships and ruminations on why did i survive when x didn't there is a character in the book too sergeant sterling that is so powerful and instrumental in the plot that he like the judge in cormac mccarthy's blood meridian will inspire a lot of thought long after the reader puts the book down there are scenes and events in yellow birds that resonated quite a lot with me i also did pre deployment training at dix came home through kuwait and am pretty familiar with kaiserslautern though admittedly i've never visited the whorehouse powers describes especially the passage on flying back to the us and how the transition from ocean to coast to green heartland is so inspirational when capping off a trip downrange the defining scene in the book though is its climactic event which the author has infused with images of blood dirt valhalla and indiscriminate again with the fate death yellow birds is pretty short but though powers is economical with his words he studied poetry at ut austin nothing seems left out the book jacket has tom wolfe whom i respect implying that this is the all quiet on the western front for iraq and afghanistan but i've never been real jazzed about these comparisons i e calling billy lynn's long halftime walk the catch 22 for iraq the book stands on its own as a literary examination of war like mailer's homer's and hemingway's did and karl marlantes two recent books are also quite respectable in this regard like i said this is the best one i've seen so far and i have no reservations about recommending it
raw_text.1236: this is one of the best books i've read lately and i've read some great ones with my recent romp through contemporary literary fiction i wasn't expecting to like it so much actually because i'm not big on war stories but there's so much more going on here the alternating narratives of the author's time in iraq and spoilers in virginia kept me hooked and both had sufficient emotional resonance to stand on their own much of the book is the main character seemingly waiting for something to happen but somehow it doesn't drag at all there's more than enough going on around him and inside his head and the author drops sufficient tidbits of information to move the story along without hitting the reader over the head with what friends of mine call a clue by four there are several distinct and equally vivid settings presented iraq germany virginia the characters are great as well distinctive realistic and so clearly drawn that i could hear their voices the prose is solid with some beautiful and striking turns of phrase that only rarely interrupt the flow of the narrative my only nagging issue might be the ending i'm still torn on that but in the grand scheme of the main character's experiences i'm not sure it even added that much to his mental landscape without spoiling anything and the broad outlines are revealed very early on it's clear that he would have suffered the same emotional trauma even without that final experience that's why this book is so effective it doesn't rely on one major event it builds very realistically the layers of conflict and trauma that wrack the main character and leave him totally isolated and desolate

raw_text.1240: i had some trouble while i read this book i was expecting to get thoroughly absorbed in it but somehow i failed to connect with the narrator or any of the main characters i also had trouble figuring out the basis for the bond between the narrator and murph and for me the writing was almost overdone too beautiful and too lush i thought i was going to give it two or three stars yet i feel a bit haunted by this story after having finished it earlier this week i think overall despite my complaints above powers managed to tell an awful story in an incredibly deft manner war is conflict but it's not just the conflict between two warring sides there is all this other conflict conflict terrible choices and unfortunate and tragic consequences and since the end of the draft it is true that a huge nearly unbridgeable gulf has developed between civilian society and those who are part of military society here we are with these seemingly endless wars overseas creating a large population of combat veterans who we in civil society maybe don't really understand luckily for us who care the current generation of veterans includes a number of gifted writers who have made the decision to share these things with us powers is one of them and the day after i finished his book i listened to this fresh air episode with a couple of writerly vets who co edited a volume of short stories by iraq and afghanistan veterans listening to them helped me reconcile my ambivalence about yellow birds and made me want to read more from these writers

raw_text.1248: the yellow birds is a book that i found hugely impactful written in the first person of an enlisted soldier in iraq all the issues are addressed which might make the average american take a realistic look at the foibles of war the book is written loosely based on the author's experiences in al tafar iraq the protagonist is pvt bartles who like most other enlisted men joined up following completing high school in an interview the author powers says that he found himself without direction young people look at their options and in their minds this is perhaps the best or only one recruits are brainwashed beginning in basic training with march songs a yellow birdwith a yellow billwas perched uponmy windowsilli lured him inwith a piece of breadand then i smashedhis fucking head traditional u s army marching cadence the job of the army is to make killers out of very young persons who have been brought up with thou shalt not kill the new mantra is thou shalt kill they learn to distance themselves from trauma and just observe it from the corner of the eye these changes first met with confusion then morph into complicity the horrors of the experience both emotional and physical are presented vividly on completion of a tour the soldiers are presented with a brief questionnaire asking in part if they felt mentally traumatized and would like to stay in iraq for some rehabilitation following the combat veterans recent experiences all he can think about is going home questions are presented in such a way that the greatest percentage deny emotional trauma damaged souls there are 100% casualties some visible some not visible but just as deadly on returning to the united states the soldiers are all treated as heroes our brave young men thank you for your service they may be humiliated but dare not show it following discharge the soldier just begins to deal with the mental and moral repercussions of the experience the confusion must be enormous of course the government encourages this attitude of making them all heroes since we as yet do not have a draft the book deals with the grim reality that is war all wars unspeakable horrors i believe this book is a must read for all americans between the covers of this book is an incredible message

raw_text.1253: with sentences like this that it would have been ok for him to have a favorite place to walk with satisfaction down the long straight boulevards of whatever post he may have gone to next to admire the uniformity of the grass green and neatly shorn beneath a blue limitless sky to bury himself in a sandy shoal in the shallow of some clear cold stream and let the water wash over the pitted skin of his scarred body i don't know what his favorite place would have been like because i don't believe he would have let himself have one i couldn't help but fall in love with this book despite its immense sadness sure there might have been parts that could have focused more on character development but the writing is so clear and precise and just beautiful that all is immediately forgiven powers nails not just descriptions but also the voice of the narrator and his observations you want to fall that's all you think it can't go on like that it's as if your life is a perch on the edge of a cliff and going forward seems impossible not for a lack of will but a lack of space the possibility of another day stands in defiance of the laws of physics and you can't go back so you want to fall let go give up but you can't and every breath you take reminds you of that fact so it goes

raw_text.1267: a post memorial day review of a pre memorial day read this book recounts the travails of private john bartle first in nineveh province iraq and upon his return home this is not a happy book bartle is getting ready to live his war when a new man eighteen year old daniel murphy joins his squad bartle makes a commitment that turns out to be his downfall when he promises murph's mom to bring him home to her when sergeant sterling learns about this sterling knocks bartle to the ground and gives him a pair of solid punches to the face apparently the sergeant did not approve of such commitments the details of what happened to murph flesh out the story but that is not the story the story is how bartle is haunted by the circumstances of murph's death the aftermath some less than conventional follow up the return home the zombie like existence feeling unworthy of the small thanks showered upon a returning soldier as i said above this is not a happy story so i'm not recommending this book to my veteran friends because they do not need to be reminded about this stuff it's not exactly ptsd but it's similar and it's terrible who needs to read this book are the millions who think that voting for the winner on "america's got talent" is more important than who got killed this week by an ied you won't like it but we need to eat our vegetables if we are to grow up to be big and strong

raw_text.1307: i was awed at some of the beautiful imagery and the deftness of power's prose the figurative language he employs merits a read i also loved the jarring juxtaposition of poetry and harsh combat vernacular i enjoyed the plot and character development but i wanted a dash more of hope to temper the existentialism bottom line in the end i couldn't rationalize a fourth or fifth star for the same reasons i give this book a three at times the poetry is overkill and borders on the melodramatic sometimes less description would have been more some passages felt self indulgent and over written still this book is excellent and i do see parallels between remarque and crane although i don't think power's work here exceeds their efforts

raw_text.1310: war is cruel dark and ugly and this novel with its often beautiful lyrical language shows us no different it's a story of a young 21 year old soldier private bartle stationed in iraq who has made an impossible promise to look after 18 year old private murphy and make sure he returns home the story flashes back and forth in time between when private bartle is home and his time of war the author kevin powers captures the feel and pain of war effectively he's a poet and it shows but you do wonder would a real life private john bartle from virginia express himself in this manner the author is however an iraq war veteran and the truth of that shines in this book this is a fairly short novel or it feels more like a long short story its narrative is directed by private bartle and it has a very limited cast of characters which gives it a very intimate feel it however does not have a very strong plot and is more of a stream of consciousness story than anything else it may be the reason why while i liked this story i never fell in love with it

raw_text.1313: kevin powers is a poet and boy don't you know it by the time you've reached the end of this book there's a fine insightful illuminating book in there somewhere but it would have been a whole lot better if he had restrained himself from so much overblown and arbitrary imagery here's a sample paragraph clouds spread out over the atlantic like soiled linens on an unmade bed i knew watching them that if in any given moment a measurement could be made it would show how tentative was my mind's mastery over my heart such small arrangements make a life and though it's hard to get close to saying what the heart is it must at least be that which rushes to spill out of those parentheses which were the beginning and the end of my war the old life disappearing into the dust that hung and hovered over nineveh even before it could be recalled and longed for young and unformed as it was already broken by the time i reached the furthest working of my memory i was going home but home too was hard to get an image of harder still to think beyond the last curved enclosure of the desert where it seemed i had left the better portion of myself as one among innumerable grains of sand how in the end the weatherbeaten stone is not one stone but only that which has been weathered a result an example of slow erosion on a thing by wind or waves that break up against it so that the else of anyone involved ends up deposited like silt spilling out into an estuary or gathered at the bottom of a river in a city that is all you can remember it was a bit of a struggle to wade through all this kind of stuff in the end i'm still glad to have read this book but it could have been so much simpler and better
raw_text.1314: the yellow birds is another novel about the wars in the middle east the title refers to a us army marching cadence a yellow bird with a yellow bill was perched upon my windowsill i lured him in with a piece of bread and then i smashed his fucking head tom wolfe called this book the all quiet on the western front of america's arab wars it is just that told from the perspective of john bartle a very young soldier in iraq it is an eloquent and very real description of what war does to the men who fight it i don't know if i've ever read a book that made me feel so vividly or feel so sorry that war is such a common experience john bartle went to war over the strong objections of his mother he met an unsophisticated kid named daniel murphy and they became buddies bart looked after murph he was trying to keep a promise he made to ladonna murphy daniel's mother before they shipped out the book opens with a story about malik their interpreter who wore a cloth bag over his head so he wouldn't be recognized and shot by his neighbors for collaborating in a careless moment malik exposes himself by standing as is killed instantly life in iraq goes on however and bart and murph do what they have to do killing and watching people be killed gradually they lose their emotional connection to others they do things they are ashamed of that they know they ought to be punished for but that's all in a day's work in iraq eventually the emotions overwhelm the naive 18 year old murph who falls platonically in love with a young nurse he doesn't know he spends all his free time watching her after his girlfriend breaks up with him by mail and begins to withdraw from bart who notices but is almost relieved to be free for a while from his obligation to watch out for murph bart doesn't understand that this is the first sign that murph has lost his bearings the precursor to an early death powers' characters including mostly officers and family of the two major actors are perfectly drawn sergeant sterling holds a special place and makes a special contribution to the book that is truly affecting what happens to the boys as a result of their war service is both expected and unexpected when bart eventually goes home he falls apart and refuses to see anyone he stays drunk for days on end he knows he will soon be arrested for what he's done in iraq so he waits trying to decide whether it was the right or the wrong thing and if it matters the prose is incredibly descriptive the feelings powers portrays so genuine and raw that i couldn't put it down this one will stick with me for a while

raw_text.1370: i re read this for our book group and am glad i did because i could appreciate the poetic quality of the prose the descriptive detail and the book's themes on my first reading i was struck by how small scale and chaotic this form of modern warfare is small bands of soldiers fighting through the streets of towns with indiscriminate brutality very scary it's a powerful and authentic portrait of the horror of war and the terrible inescapable shock and disillusionment suffered by all who are forced to participate indeed the theme of the profound impact on the individual is the most moving and dispiriting the awful challenge of returning to the normal world and the incomprehensible gap between those who've been there and done it and those who haven't and even more telling the loss of faith in any reason for what life is or could be but things happened the way they happened without regard to our desire for them to have happened another way despite an age old instinct to provide an explanation more complex than that something with a level of profundity and depth which would seem commensurate with the confusion i felt it was really that simple it is an inevitable reaction to the arbitrary lottery of life and death in war the helplessness our biggest error was thinking that it mattered what we thought that there was any cause and effect in our behaviour and life that there was any morality to the choices we made and the results a short but memorable reminder of why we should never believe that war should be anyone's option or lot this book makes an interesting companion to billy lynn's long halftime walk which highlights the gap between the political view of war as heroic from those back home who do not have to participate and the reality of doing it in the latter book you do not see what it is they do over there it is implied by the reaction of those involved simply imagine the war of the yellow birds to fill in the picture

raw_text.1401: review crossposted to my 238 books in 238 days challenge the yellow birds offers glimpses into a young man's time in the u s army serving in iraq and surviving back home kevin powers has been lauded for his poetical writing style to contrast the gritty reality of war and it is true there is a dreamlike quality to his writing even though it feels sparse we get impressions of the things he sees but there isn't much talk about feeling there isn't a lot of action certainly less than i would have expected instead we get to experience sleep deprived boys waiting for something anything to happen and yet knowing that it probably won't matter anyway how many times have we been through that orchard through this town sir a pcf from third squad asked the army yes sir this makes three all in the fall yeah seems like we're fighting over this town every year maybe they'll make it an annual thing i had often wondered what motivated boys to enlist and for our two main characters the answer is frighteningly simple there wasn't much else to do for the author himself it was a way into university it is hard for young boys and their parents when they know that they've made the right choice in the circumstances yet there is no way to prepare for what might happen the narrative of the yellow birds jumps around in time i don't know if i care much for the mystery surrounding our soldier's friend but i suppose it is necessary to create a plot that helps the reader to follow a journey what it means though is that we get to see the lives of the families back home and even our main character trying to understand ordinary life again after he is discharged his thoughts move too fast for him to be able to talk and at one time he literally goes on for pages without a break this section felt more heartbreaking than the scenes of war possibly because i can understand not being able to master your own thoughts or possibly because even after all the pictures i've seen on the news and descriptions i've read in books i'm still unable to comprehend the reality of war our main character knows that his experiences will make him an outsider even when he's still fighting in iraq he would seem like frodo saving something for others when that same thing has been lost to him if he was still able to feel enough to make sense of it i was an intruder at best a visitor and would be even in my home in my misremembered history until the glow of phosphorescence in the chesapeake i had longed to swim inside again someday became a taunt against my insignificance a cruel trick of light that had always made me think of stars no more i gave up longing because i was sure that anything seen at such a scale would reveal the universe as cast aside and drowned and if i ever floated there again out where the level of the water reached my neck and my feet lost contact with its muddy bottom i might realize that to understand the world one's place in it is to be always at the risk of drowning i wonder if writing this book helped kevin powers to deal with his own demons i hope it did there's been a lot of praise for it and rightly so there's been even more talk in the press about the reasons behind this war and i feel it is important to push the politics to the background for a few moments and see real people whose lives have been afflicted by it i can't help but think what would have happened and how soldiers would be treated back home if the war had not happened thousands of miles away when our main character gets back to the u s he does a short psych evaluation and then goes back home meeting people who see him as a hero or people who are angry with the enemy on his account he is detached from all that just wants to be forgotten and it seems to me that that is just too easily done i'd been trained to think war was the great unifier that it brought people closer together than any other activity on earth bullshit war is the great maker of solipsists how are you going to save my life today dying would be one way if you die it becomes more likely that i will not
raw_text.1402: short synopsis a personal war story of the conflict in afghanistan the author is a veteran of the conflict and although many events are reflective of his time there the narrative is fictional in one word i can only describe this novel as 'heavy' all of the events of the novel occur with weight and gravity and there are few moments that break the tense grip this novel generates you are drawn into a mind that reflects and in doing so brings for itself great suffering and regret at the events that take place i usually like that kind of writing what struck me most was how little humor breaks the grip there are few moments and i think it was intentional this way where any sort of lightheartedness makes the characters seem more human more like american kids in their teens and twenties and less like static emotions with names attached to them the author clearly impresses a point but did not render me empathetic with the main character or supporting characters they were not believable a hard four stars to give to be honest but a good read nevertheless and the first i've read in the backdrop of the afghanistan conflict

raw_text.1421: the author is a veteran of the wars in iraq the yellow birds is a novel following a warrior returning home broken and finding he doesn't fit in after knowing the horrors of war it can be published today without ptsd being a major theme i admire these writers for coming home and writing about their experiences but i really want to know are they writing about what they want to say or what we are prepared to hear when did post traumatic stress disorder dominate over other aspects of war when i think of other literature from past conflicts there are other narratives in the iliad warriors are preoccupied with becoming immortal by the renown of their glorious acts the red badge of courage focuses on well courage gone with the wind the civilian side of war joshua on loyalty to god war and peace all's quiet on the western front and a farewell to arms gave us realistic depictions of battle but little about the aftermath catch 22 the absurdity of the military what i categorized since vietnam i've been told that in the past the sufferers of ptsd were marginalized their bravery questioned their voices silenced clearly that was wrong and it would be better to fully raw_text.1432: my first reaction was to award this book 5 stars but after some reflection i think i might have been influenced by all the hype and stellar reviews it's close to being a 5 but i felt it unraveled a bit at the end and was inconsistent just enough to come up short the language is the primary driver behind the novel the hemingway comparisons are apt and many of the passages are littered with brilliance this is certainly the best fiction i've read to come out of the iraq afghan wars and it's also one of the best books period considering how much great reportage is out there it effectively captured what i most imagine about war the long stretches of idleness and boredom the unending stress and malaise interrupted by quick staccato bursts of terror and adrenaline the pain of random chance this is a novel that can and should be read in one or two sittings to fully maximize the efficacy of its themes and delivery it makes my shortlist for 2013 and i would not be surprised to see it on my top ten at year's end powers is a young writer to watch and i look forward to seeing what he does next

raw_text.1438: to be unable to praise this book wholeheartedly is a disappointment powers' novel depicts a vast unhealed sadness and only the most callous reader could fail to experience the weight of that but it is not a great book often in fact it's not even good writing to be sure the yellow birds sets out to describe emotional trauma and the burden of conscience but its oneiric qualities often generate more incoherence than empathy powers' protagonist bartle in fact is not necessarily "passing through the fields of memory " as jacket copy would have it at times he is simply raving and not just raving - raving in purple prose the most self indulgent passages of which would have benefited from a reduction in adjectives by about a third and in similes and metaphors by well more than half in that sense the yellow birds feels like student writing--assuming a student writer with stupendous material and a voracious but untrustworthy eye for detail here are two specific examples of the failure both of power's imagination and of powers' editors sidereally both are descriptions of the appearance of the sky in one the light at dawn is "the color of unripe oranges" in the other 50 pages later the sky is "the color of unworked iron " well what is the color of unripe oranges they are lime green does powers really mean that the morning sky was lime green and what is the color of unworked iron what for that matter is the color of worked iron lapses like these are self conscious get in the way of the reading and they pull the reader out of the narrative there are far too many of them but what makes the yellow birds most unsatisfying are first its slavish aping of tim o'brien's the things they carried particularly in the opening chapters where the voice is identical to o'brien's and second a major plot point that rings false spoilers follow powers asks us to believe that bartle's decision to float the mutilated body of his friend murph away down the river rather than allow the corpse to be transported home is motivated by fear that murph's mother might open the coffin and see the extent of her son's injuries bartle wants to spare her both that sight and the true story of murph's horrific death after murph is dead bartle even writes the boy's mother a letter pretending to be her son this might be an intriguing dilemma though its value as a moral quandary is significantly reduced by the fact that in order to maintain the secret bartle and his companions murder an innocent civilian but if the coffin were closed and murph's mother had been told as she surely would have been to leave it that way why would she have looked inside do people do that how would she even have had access to the coffin the reader however must believe this was a real possibility--or at least that bartle believed it to be otherwise his actions are not arguably kind they are merely vile what ensues predictably is that murph's mother is unsatisfied by the lack of a corpse and by the conflicting explanations for her son's death she presses for an investigation and the military in due time produces scapegoats but no actual information powers never makes it clear whether she does or does not learn from bartle's lips the entire story beginning with the fact that her son's death was a sort of assisted suicide and that too is vaguely unsatisfying bartle acknowledges that he had no right to make choices for murph's mother which any reader with a conscience had long ago worked out for himself but does he hold to the lie or doesn't he the arc of the novel almost seems to demand that powers not leave the answer vague nonetheless it is in the book's last chapter that powers hits his narrative stride and the scene of a meeting between murph's mother and bartle becomes a powerful discourse on the differences between forgiveness and living with what bartle calls "a justified resignation " if there is not precisely a sense of earned wisdom in the scene there is the resounding ring of truth would that this compelling and beautiful sound had encompassed the entire book

raw_text.1449: kevin power's debut war novel the yellow birds aptly features jacket praise comparisons to hemingway's all quiet on the western front and o'brien's the things they carried these are fitting and lofty comparisons and the sentiments within the novel echo both seminal works power's prose is more verbose than hemingway though nearly everyone but hemingway himself could be described as such and is more effervescent at times the author's background in poetry is clear as his descriptions are beautiful painted but at times they prove too vaporous to grasp likewise the story is less significant than the things they carried and power's characters less memorable this is a somewhat intentional effect as the novel is meant to reek of the loneliness and alienation of warriors however one cannot help but feel that the story would be improved if it wasn't so slight

raw_text.1462: i was aware of how much attention this book was getting in the popular press as well as the fact that it had won the guardian first book award 2012 and was a ny times bestseller in its first week of publication not being a fan of 'war books' however i had decided not to read it then a friend who had had the book recommended to her recommended and lent it to me and as a vocal proponent of personal recommendations i couldn't very well refuse i could instantly see why the yellow birds had drawn so much attention not only does this book bring the reality of armed conflict into focus and put a face on each and every person in our armed forces but there are moments of sheer literary brilliance in this novel powers certainly has a way with metaphors ten months it may seem like a short time but my whole life since has merely been a digression from those days which now hang over me like a quarrel that will never be resolved and i found some of his more philosophical reflections quite profound i'd never have to make a decision again that seemed freeing but it gnawed at some part of me even then eventually i had to learn that freedom is not the same thing as the absence of accountability i did feel that at times powers took his poetic proclivity a little too far one minute i'm on the ground in iraq with him and the next he has apparently lost his train of thought and i am thinking about what to have for dinner when he stayed focussed on the events to hand however even in lengthier tirades i remained wrapt private bartle's rant on pages 144 145 was a particularly mind blowing example of this i could vividly picture him being overwhelmed with self loathing desperate but unable to justify his actions or inactions within the context of war it continually distressed me to not know how much of this novel was a version of the truth based on powers own experiences in iraq and how much was fiction there are details in this book that i simply don't want to believe someone would make up for their shock value i realise that this then implies said details are based in truth but somehow this is preferable to my perception of the mind that dreamed it up i have always thought of the victims of war as those killed or physically injured and their families soldiers and civilians alike and those left destitute or displaced now i know of another type of victim those that survived physically unharmed but mentally broken sadly it's my belief that the injuries we can't see are the hardest to treat and i can only imagine how difficult this must be for those directly affected chris cleave said that this book reaffirms the power of fiction to tell the truth about the unspeakable indeed it does
raw_text.1463: i wrote this brief review three years ago but left it unfinished and buried with some other reviews in an archived folder i'm posting it now to fulfill a promise i made to write more reviews and for better or for worse to make more of them public kevin powers' the yellow birds is narrated by john bartle a young private who fights in iraq in 2004 and 2005 the novel takes place primarily in iraq and virginia the blurbs on the book jacket describe the yellow birds as "a book i've been waiting for" and "urgently necessary " i came at this novel as most readers probably did with no experience of its subject matter the character i identify with most in this novel is the airport bartender who tries to comp bartle's beer guilty a little misguided wanting to connect but with a few exceptions the narrator largely denies the reader that satisfaction of easy identification and understanding this is a novel that asks for some work from its readers one of the exceptional passages is the run on sentence covering pages 144 145 where more clearly than at any other point in the novel bartle describes his reasons for enlisting his anger at those who welcome him back home and his guilt over murph's death not coincidentally this moment of vulnerability and exposure ends as bartle lies down in the james river in a kind of attempted suicide that mirrors the passage of murph's body down the tigris nakedness bartle knows is equal to death although the two novels couldn't be more different in tone yellow birds' structure reminded me of catch 22 the gradual unfolding of events until the moment of a painful and significant death is revealed to the reader--in catch 22 this is snowden's death and in this novel murph's because yellow birds is narrated in the first person the reader is positioned as a kind of counselor listening to the recollection of a traumatic memory bartle insists he's not looking to murph's mother for forgiveness for betraying his promise to keep murph alive but to the reader for assistance in forgetting "all i knew was that i wanted to return to ordinary if i could not forget then i'd hope to be forgotten" 222 there are a few places in the novel where bartle's observations felt closer to incomprehensible than mysteriously profound for example midway through the novel we have this paragraph "the rest is history they say bullshit i say it's imagination or it's nothing and must be because what is created in this world or made can be undone unmade the threads of a rope can be unwoven and if that rope is needed as a guideline for a ferry to a farther shore then one must invent a way to weave it back or there will be drownings in the streams that cross our paths i accept now though in truth it took some time that must must be its own permission " a more capable reader might be able to untangle this passage but it left me scratching my head ultimately though i felt that the rewards of the novel were well worth the occasional frustration i experienced as a reader

raw_text.1470: coming homethe friend who encouraged me to read this book swears that it is not a war novel i can't think why not from its very first scene as a group of us soldiers huddle on as rooftop in tal afar in northern iraq red eyed from a 72 hour deployment it is grounded in the grit and texture of the second gulf war even more than helen benedict's impressive sand queen the only other book i have so far read about that war powers conveys what it was like to serve and survive in that dust and heat facing an ill defined and elusive enemy in a way than no amount of television reporting managed to do as well he might for he was there perhaps my friend meant that this is not a book about ground gained and battles won it is a grunt's eye view going from day to day with no concern for the overall picture and surprisingly no heroics when towards the end a major arrives to distribute medals and citations the exhausted soldiers are too indifferent even to come to proper order in many ways this is a small book at least in the iraq scenes which take place in a small area over a short period of time and essentially concern only three soldiers john bartle his buddy murph and their battle hardened sergeant sterling but to call it small is to miss its moral implications which are immense and even here powers' concern is human not political he is not interested in denouncing the folly of this particular war except by implication by showing the toll it takes on a single serviceman and those nearest to him before shipping out bartle makes a rash promise to murph's mother that he will bring her boy home as we learn early on he will fail to do so shorn of its details that is the entire story but it is enormous one of powers' most brilliant strokes is to alternate scenes in iraq with those in germany and virginia as bartle finally comes home finally no for there is nothing final about the trauma that john bartle suffers alienating him from his mother and former friends but nothing is overstated these are gentle rural scenes that nonetheless speak volumes such as one picture of young men and women john's former classmates swimming from some rocks while john walks naked into the river lower down meanwhile back in iraq we come closer to the day of murph's death and the events that will so affect private bartle and sergeant sterling they are horrible yes but no worse than much else we have read about that war and what john suffers from in himself is not the discovery of some latent brutality but simply the consequences of his humanity and that perhaps is ultimately what my friend meant in not calling it a war novel this is a deeply human book and also an unbearably poetic one powers went on to become michener fellow in poetry at ut austin let me end with a vignette murph has taken to going up to the casualty clearing section to watch from the distance a young female medic that place those little tents at the top of the hill the small area where she was it might have been the last habitat for gentleness and kindness that we'd ever know so it made sense to watch her softly sobbing in the open space of a dusty piece of ground and i understood why he came and why i couldn't go not just then at least because one never knows if what one sees will disappear forever
