raw_text.1485: when i was 17 i became friends with a vietnam vet he dealt with his shattering experience by refusing to talk about it in my mid 20s i met another veteran from the war in vietnam who had also developed a mechanism to cope with his own gruesome experiences in the war he talked about it with anyone who would listen these two relationships have informed my perspective on how to view war and the unspeakable horrors experienced by soldiers i believe it is my responsibility to not look away from the grim truths that we as a country visit upon the young women and men that serve our country in wartime kevin powers is one of those men boys really that joined the army young and served in the war in iraq although i can't know what his personal torments arising from his year at war are he has presented a stunning fictional account of just how deeply deeply damaging combat is on the psyche the protagonist in the yellow birds a 21 year old army private tells his story of losing an army buddy and the repercussions of the choices he makes in the wake of that loss in a series of jump cuts in time returning to the past again and again to reveal the nightmare events surrounding the death of the fellow soldier whose safety he was entrusted with in al tafar iraq and several locations in the united states private bartle attempts to assess his culpability in the death of his friend private murphy bartle inches up to the pivotal scene over and over alternating between bare staccato analysis and stream of consciousness descriptions backing away and returning to it repeatedly as he tries to understand truth with a capital t what is said is never quite what was thought and what is heard is never quite what was said but the truth does not depend on being believed this is a book about what it takes to survive a war and the costs exacted by those actions it is written in some of the most evocative prose i've ever read beautiful in a way that i don't think i expected in a book about warfare on the brink of yet another year in two wars citizens of the u s owe it to the people acting on our behalf to not look away from what is going on over there reading this book is a small step in that direction the book i read and reviewed here was an advance review copy arc provided to me by the publisher via my local indie bookstore i did not accept any payment in exchange for a review and was in no way influenced to provide a positive review i now consider my ass covered ftc
raw_text.1486: this was definitely a worthwhile read but i wanted to like it more than i actually did it's interesting to see narratives about the more contemporary wars in iraq and afghanistan build into a deeper canon particularly when they're being told by men and women who actually served there as kevin powers did the story itself is interesting and he is a very talented writer this works against him at some points the opening 50 75 pages were a little hard to get through because his writing was a little too florid and overdone it wasn't unbelievable that the narrator could be as literate and articulate as he was but in the early going it was a little distracting from our introductions to the characters and setting the language was beautiful throughout and this served the story much better later in the book once the narrator returns to the states those scenes have less action than those set in iraq understandably and powers' prose fills them out quite nicely those scenes are reminsicient of the great ifc show rectify from last year quiet and languid but filled with amazing imagery i definitely recommend this to anyone interested in seeing the current war in iraq represented in narrative fiction and i'm curious to see more work from the author in the future

raw_text.1497: i was underwhelmed with this book i think in part because it was propped up so pompously it seems as though american readership were craving a hemingway esque novel about the 2003 iraq war and since this was the first widely published account of realistic fiction they latched on and didn't let go what annoys me the most about the book is the author's assumption that you will empathize with his characters immediately and irrevocably his nonlinear narrative actually detracts from a natural introduction to the characters though it makes you curious to find out what happened the book is absolutely plagued by metaphors i whisked through them unaffected it is hard to put a finger on it but i just did not feel that this book provided anything that would stand the test of time interestingly enough although the title is derived from a u s army marching cadence i actually thought it was referring to canaries in a coal mine in the story murph's father released canaries into the mine and they slowly died in song a darkness inevitably enveloped them in silence together in a way i felt that those canaries were murph and bartle drifting in a kind of sleeping consciousness or aware coma of their intertwined fates to end on a forgiving note i did enjoy the following opening of a chapter clouds spread out over the atlantic like soiled linens on an unmade bed i knew watching them that if in any given moment a measurement could be made it would show how tentative was my mind's mastery over my heart

raw_text.1509: yellow birds by kevin powers was the one book pick in philadelphia in 2014 i didn't read it at the time but it came up often in book club and other circles after reading it i can see why it was chosen and why it continues to be a topic of conversation yellow birds tells of one young soldier's experience in the war in iraq in 2004 it is fiction but the author spent a tour in iraq and wrote the book from a "desire to look for some truth that i hoped could be found of that most extreme of human experiences "powers' prose is beautiful and touching not surprising when you learn he is a poet as well and the story is told through a series of flashbacks bouncing between iraq and the us before and after the main character's tour private bartle is 21 years old when he meets private murphy at fort dix for basic training and then head off to al tafar iraq together as they are leaving murphy's mother asks bartle to take care of her son bartle promises and is haunted by that promise the rest of the novel bartle and murphy experience both boredom and absolute fear during their combat and are effected because of what they see and do in battle "we hardly noticed a change when september came but i know now that everything that will ever matter in my life began then perhaps light came a little more slowly to the city of al tafar falling the way it did behind thin shapes of rooflines and angled promenades in the dark "luckily powers descriptive language and the story of bartle and muphy help prevent the novel from becoming voyeuristic or an overt political statement we know from the beginning that murph does not survive the war and bartle does not live up to the promise he made mrs murphy you get the sense that murph's death was due to becoming broken under the pressure of the war and the atrocities he saw compounded by a letter from his girlfriend and a feeling that he had nothing to return home to but it is not until the end that you learn more about murph's fate read the rest of my review at https whatwouldjoannaread wordpress

raw_text.1516: it's beautifully written full stop it is the most lyrical novel i've read in years kevin powers' words are better than all your favorite author's words very little prose in yellow birds is anything short of staggeringly gorgeous powers' account inevitably gets compared to other great war novels western front things they carried etc and that's fair it summons the same hypnotic effect that those two books conjure in bart's narrative and in his narrator's voice and which nonfiction accounts of war suggest is typical of experience in combat situations it's easy to get lost inside bart's head maybe even to a fault i sometimes had a hard time tracking where we actually were in time and space although it's not so much a complaint there is a clear purpose for this drifting phenomenon which we realize as we see how untethered to reality bart's post war self has become there's so much to like here and very little of it is sympathetic characters there are as with most accounts of war that feel honest and unglamorized no saints powers' version of the war in iraq has a corrupting touch for anyone it comes into contact with there's a really interesting parallel with billy lynn's halftime walk which is so deeply character driven and creates a true protaganist i might argue that bart is barely even a protaganist just the unlucky voice chosen to tell us this story and not that authenticity is the only important note for fiction to strike but powers served in the iraq war this is somehow even more disconcerting about how real this world and bart's loss of his grap on it feels recommended for anyone who likes lyrical fiction wants to understand the psychology of warfare veterans and who can doesn't mind wading into the dark grim waters of this novel's subject matter

raw_text.1519: the yellow birds is a novel that sets out to show the hardships of war and the conflict between personal and national concerns it is hard to criticise novels like this without seeming to support the suffering ok let's break rank the yellow birds worthy though the subject matter might be is confusing and opaque kevin powers is a poet and it shows much of the narrative feels overwritten floweriness for its own sake it appeared inauthentic to put these words into a soldier's first person narrative i know that kevin powers is a war veteran himself so the voice is technically authentic but the trouble is it just doesn't convince it doesn't feel like a narrative from the heart so what is the story that's a good question we have a soldier john bartle who enlists for various personal reasons chief of which is to prove to himself and others that he is not a coward so far so good and in the army he fights alongside various colleagues including murph and sergeant sterling alas the short novel doesn't really allow much space for characterisation they are really just ciphers the details of the war are well done and convincing but it soon becomes clear that there are multiple stories not all of which can be true some of these stories are just in john bartle's mind or in his dreams this is at best confusing and at worst frustrating i guess there is some kind of deep metaphor at work but as so often with poetic novels one soon tires of trying to work it all out the law of diminishing returns and all that and there is plenty of navel gazing too particularly in the sections set in 2006 away from the iraqi battlefields the cod philosophy drags the pace down and seems to serve really just as padding for what would otherwise be a thin story overall the yellow birds does have its moments and it does provoke thoughts however it is far from perfect and the hazy dreamy plotting is not as profound as it tries to be some of the metaphors feel simultaneously heavy handed and misjudged yellow birds for example that will sit on top of the cage when released and then happily pop back into the cage for food and shelter explained in detail but of little obvious relevance to the novel claims that the yellow birds will be studied for many years to come seem somewhat hubristic but i guess time will tell

raw_text.1557: my review for the chicago center for literature and photography which you can find here http bit ly xdevh2 there's a long stream of consciousness passage toward the middle of former soldier kevin powers' haunting disturbing and downright gorgeous debut novel about the iraq war that acts as something of a thesis really cowardice got you into this mess says his narrator 21 year old john bartle speaking about himself in the second person because you wanted to be a man and people made fun of you in the cafeteria and hallways in high school because you liked to read books and poems sometimes and they'd call you fag and really deep down you know you went because you wanted to be a man the unsettling sentence that quotation comes from is more than a page long the book takes the form of a fractured narrative taking place both during before and after the war hurtling toward and away from the traumatic event at the book's center and in the passage in question bartle is back home in virginia and reflecting in the war his friend murph has died and the circumstances surrounding his death have pushed bartle to the brink where he will either come to terms with the legal and psychological consequences of his actions or let those actions define and destroy him forever i chose that passage to highlight for a few reasons first it states very simply what the yellow birds is it's a novel about a poet an awkward smart artsy kid who loved books just as much as you and me who enlisted in the army at seventeen witnessed the horrors of war and returned to tell the tale the second reason i chose that passage is that it's far from perfect it's hard not to get lost in a page long sentence and hard not to question whether there wasn't a more concise and to the point way to express the emotions driving the prose that's the way the yellow birds as a whole is too it has its flaws it moves at a very meandering pace and powers sometimes seems to get a bit lost in longer passages giving the words themselves the run of the show and drawing too much attention to the writing but to get stuck on these imperfections is to miss the point the fact is this sharp little novel's existence is something of a miracle and i don't believe that's overstating it reading kevin powers felt like reading justin cronon's the summer guest last year or kingsley amis's lucky jim some years before that or blood meridian or the sportswriter or hemingway's nick adam's stories in other words reading it felt like a seminal event and i knew before i was halfway through that it would eventually find its way onto my life list of favorites the reasons why are simple enough just yesterday for example the new york times broke a major story about the use of drones in pakistan revealing that the cia made a deal with the pakistani government to kill a pakistani enemy of state in exchange for airspace it might take a second to sink in but when it does it's almost impossible not to double take or recoil in horror since when did the u s government become an assassin for hire the problem with putting this undeniably messed up state of affairs into fiction though is almost that it's too easy of course it's messed up it's obvious but what justifies writing a whole book to tell us about it billy lynn's long halftime walk by ben fountain the other great war novel of 2012 which was a good and entertaining book but will not end up on my life list of favorites or in my opinion in the canon answers this question i e justifies its existence by making the story about more than just the war drenching its narrative in a glitzy if somewhat repulsive americana and pointing the finger outward to the state of the country and the world it's not just the war fountain enthuses it's all messed up but again is this news see a more comprehensive review of fountain's book here at the website this wednesday powers' book on the other hand answers the question in the right way he ignores the politics the state of the world ideas about what exactly america is at the current moment and instead presents us with a laser focused view of what the war is or what it looked like to a poet accidentally caught up in it his concern is with what it is to be human and what coming face to face with the horrors of war can do to a young man's perspective if that sounds old fashioned it is if that sounds like it has been done before it has but it hasn't been done about this war and it hasn't been done in quite this way the obvious comparison to the yellow birds is hemingway's war novels and intentionally or not powers invokes hemingway again and again in these pages but this is much more than facsimile powers allows himself a structure that it's hard to imagine hemingway using includes sentences that hemingway would likely have cut for being too flowery and gives his narrator the freedom to slip into stream of consciousness it's brutal unflinching and beautiful we all have our opinions about hemingway but one point that can't be argued is that the man was a worker he believed in his writing as art and he strove for the eternal he slaved over his sentences here is powers describing a firefight noctiluca i thought ceratium as the tracers began to show themselves sifted in twilight two words learned on a school field trip to the tidewaters of virginia that appeared as i was shooting at the man paying no attention then to the strange connections made inside my mind the small storms of electricity that cause them to rise and then submerge then rise again a fleeting thought of a young girl beside me on a dock back there the twilight coming on the crack of tracers as i shot and shot again the man crawling from his weapon until he stopped and his blood trickled down the river in its final ebbing tide brief as bioluminescence look we all know the america we live in it's a giant shopping mall full of glittering lights and subdivisions it's a post industrial empire in perpetual recession and decline and we all know what we know about the war it's messed up it isn't quite right but america and the war on terror also make an easy target in my mind the easier war novel to write would be one that looks at military service from that lens i e what does it say about me as a soldier that i am serving this embarrassing eyesore of a country but powers takes the opposite approach we all know what we know and he doesn't argue for or against it what he does instead is approach his material with the will to transform it into art this is significant because this devotion implies that a life bartle's life or powers' life or the life of any given soldier even in the age of the internet endless strip malls kim kardashian and yes drones is still worth carefully expressing by taking as much care with his sentences as hemingway or cormac mccarthy richard ford marilynne robinson and aiming to create something eternal powers has made a profound statement america circa the present is worth this slavish devotion to detail the current war is worth the work it takes to express something so complex as art and its heroes the young men and women fighting it deserve to be elevated in the same way that hemingway elevated the heroes of his wars this book made me sad that powers had to fight in this war but very happy that he was there to bear witness and bring this story back with him it also made me feel patriotic proud of the tradition of american letters and proud to be participating in it as a reader

raw_text.1597: in the last decade or so one would be hard pressed to find anyone left untouched in some fashion by iraq or afghanistan whether it be through a family member friend neighbor colleague or acquaintance to be honest i'm really not sure why i chose to read this book maybe it was because my brother was deployed for twenty two months and never really talked too much in depth about it he did express a deep and abiding hatred of the enemy "hajji" in a classic "us" vs "them" mentality if my brother did speak of some experience or another sometimes i felt like covering my ears like a child and shouting "la la la la " because i didn't want to truly know i don't think i was ready to fully process my brother's experiences as he experienced them and this book afforded me a way of doing so without being too close prior to deployment to northwestern iraq pvt john bartle's sergeant introduces him to pvt daniel murphy and leaves murph with the instruction "all right little man i want you to get in bartle's back pocket and i want you to stay there " bartle is in his early twenties and murph is still a teenager but bartle comes across as a worldly more experienced older brother powers doesn't delve too much into the friendship between the two in the context of such a harsh setting partly because bartle has the benefit of hindsight and doesn't want to get too close one of the most striking aspects of the story is these soldiers are so young and they are being forced to make hard decisions about life and death on a daily basis this is a story of truth in war told through a series of bartle's flashbacks almost 90% of the story takes place in bartle's mind in which he tries to make sense of things that have happened to him the funny thing about memory is it cannot be controlled some experiences are just too immediate and intense what is "the truth " does the truth really lie in memory where "facts" have become jumbled overlapped and hazy throughout the book bartle seeks to make sense of things - to make his experiences add up through his damaged memory bartle tries to reconstruct murph and he fails powers isn't aiming for accuracy in war but to paint a picture of when memory fails and things are simply unfixable while i argue the book could have used more character development the secondary characters of the mothers were beautifully written families are courageous in their own unique way and must deal with loss and the powerlessness of what happens when a loved one returns home damaged powers addresses the difficulty veterans have when returning to "normal" life once they return home from war i found the flashback method difficult to follow at times powers is a poet war isn't poetic or flowery it is horrifying gritty and tragic i wasn't looking for a thriller but i could have done without so much pretty language with that said the yellow birds is a powerful and moving debut novel i saw powers speak early on his book tour when he made a stop at the blue willow bookshop in houston one of the more interesting points to come up was "why a novel instead of a memoir " powers is an iraqi veteran himself after serving in 2004 and 2005 as a machine gunner surely he would have more than enough to present first hand powers responded that he was able to process his experiences through his imagination for him writing this book provided distance and clarity it also gave him much more freedom of expression and creative control to say things that he normally would not he is an "artist ordering the universe " had powers written a memoir he would have been responsible for the story of all those serving with him - and that takes time so what's next for mr powers first a collection of poetry and his next novel powers was a bit more speculative but he hinted that he was at the note taking stage of a story of a plantation owner during the civil war era he threw out that it could involve a "love triangle" and "murder " but warned it could "go anywhere " this could be interesting... update january 2014 so i was browsing the interwebs and powers' collection of poetry letter composed during a lull in the fighting poems will be out in april i normally don't read poetry but the title has me curious

once brought some canaries home from the mine they'd done their duty so he let them out of their cage they flew about a bit then returned to their cage it's tempting to think that murph is the yellow bird who was lured into the war over his mother's objections and who indeed got smashed by the war we're told early in the book that murphy did not make it and the canaries who return to their cage bartle did get home but is certainly not free he is caged by his memories and his guilt for what precisely and suffers from severe post traumatic stress there are three major characters in this story private bartle the narrator age 21 private murphy age 18 and sgt sterling tough and battle scarred but only 24 both bartle and murphy's mothers play smaller but important roles each character has to come to terms with the war in his or her own way if coming to terms is what they did war is hell yes and the evocative prose makes that hell seem even more hellish it's not a blood and guts story raw_text.1623: this is a superb moving and insightful book about war and its effects on the men and women who take part in it the author kevin powers is a veteran of iraq in 2004 where this book is set and is now a poet this combination of first hand experience and ability with language coupled with great insight and honesty creates something quite remarkable the book is narrated in the first person by private john bartle on his first tour of duty in iraq the language is heightened throughout often poetic and sometimes almost hallucinatory the timescale moves between his time in iraq his pre tour training and his homecoming and after the story is really that of bartle's psychological journey and is quite stunning in its evocation of the war itself and of the state of mind of the young man who went through it it is deceptively quiet in tone with even the violent action of which there is relatively little described without hysteria and this lends it a remarkable power to convey things like fear exhaustion the rush of excitement and the dreadful problems of reintegrating once home all this may sound forbidding turgid or preachy but it isn't at all this is an engrossing readable book which is quite short but has immense impact and which will stay with me for a very long time i think this genuinely belongs among great war books such as all quiet on the western front and dispatches i could give a long list of examples of how thoughtful insightful and honest it is but i will just say that i recommend that you read it it is truly exceptional and you will never forget it

raw_text.1640: wow this is an intense book of the kind that makes your stomach turn even as you drink in the sharp visceral imagery it is an account of a soldier's experiences in iraq the author was a soldier there in 2004 and 2005 as those around him disintegrate under the pressure of the heat the blood the gut wrenching danger and the pointlessness of it all i felt reading this that for the very first time i was getting an unmediated view of life on the front line of this unloved war on the back cover tom wolfe describes this the all quiet on the western front of america's arab wars i had my doubts it would live up to this hype but it did don't believe me here's an example of powers' prose when we neared the orchard a flock of birds lit form its outer rows they hadn't been there long the branches shook with their absent weight and the birds circled above in the ruddy mackerel sky where they made an artless semaphore i was afraid i smelled copper and cheap wine the sun was up but a half moon hung low on the opposite horizon cutting through the morning sky like a figure from a child's pull tab book

raw_text.1663: this debut from kevin powers is haunting heartbreaking and beautiful the violence and coming of age of boys in war are handled delicately and intricately the metaphors are rich and exceedingly true and each encounter character dream place essentially every 'thing' is described masterfully i can't tell if powers is a poet or a novelist first but the book is exceedingly wise and offers a new perspective and treatment of war that will surely endure to give just one of many examples or proofs of this the novel proceeds with an urgency that is at odds at times with its protagonist and the result is fiercely compelling powers presents the juxtaposition of a war whose sole purpose is to go on only to go on and a young man who feels that going forward seems impossible not for a lack of will but a lack of space there is so much more i'd like to say about this but i don't ever prefer spoiler reviews certainly the best debut i've read in a decade

raw_text.1691: i wanted to like this novel i was supposed to like it after all the reviews in the mainstream media called it "the first american literary masterpiece produced by the iraq war " plus the yellow birds was a national book award finalist the sensibility of the narrative voice didn't work for me it seemed too refined and poetic and complex for the character who was supposed to own it i don't doubt its authenticity but it was more like the musings and emotions of an army veteran with an mfa and a poetry fellowship i e the author than like the rougher less sophisticated type the novel offers us as protagonist "war is the great maker of solipsists" p12 a notion well above a lowly private's rank for me almost every scene came off as over written and self consciously "heart of darkness" stark it's a war story and relatively simple although the novel cuts back and forth in time over several years the novel describes a 21 year old army private's one year deployment in iraq and its aftermath before shipping out private bartle bartleby rashly promises an anxious mother that he'll look after her 18 year old son and see him safely home his failure to keep that promise is predictable and unavoidable after all pvt bartle has no more combat experience than his little buddy murph events in his 2004 deployment ultimately has a destructive effect on the psyche of the decent young virginian who tears himself apart with survivor's guilt and confusion over the war's harrowing contradictions bartle's and murph's squad leader sgt sterling is the best hope of keeping the two men alive in this as they patrol the scary deathscape of al tafar he's a familiar type in war stories what anton myrer called a "cadmus soldier" who thrives on the brutality violence and lack of societal restraints the yellow birds is a sad bleak angry and dispiriting novel powers shows the iraq war as meaningless and macabre and dehumanizing pvt bartle returns home to praise u0026amp thank yous but he thinks p144 "i don't deserve anyone's gratitude and really they should all hate me for what i've done but everyone loves me for it and it's driving me crazy " this is very different from the homecomings of vietnam war veterans but emotionally difficult for pvt bartle the rote public expressions of admiration seem psychologically impossible to accept for a young warrior ashamed of his actions and tormented by his failures as a man a soldier and a protector the yellow birds is far from a masterpiece in fact it's a flawed and unsatisfying novel undeserving of the premature comparisons to the works of tim o'brien national book award for fiction in 1979 for the vietnam novel "going after cacciato" but hopefully powers has more to say and won't let us forget the full price tag of the conflicts in iraq and afghanistan

raw_text.1696: utilizing his poetic sensibilities powers draws beauty from the most horrendous of settings finds color in a place where the color has tthe yellow birds by kevin powers is the story of pvt john bartle and pvt daniel murphy told from bartle's point of view the story follows these two soldiers as they patrol small towns in northern iraq after a particularly devastating bombing rattles murphy bartle who has promised murphy's mother that he will watch murphy leaves the troop to find him tutilizing his poetic sensibilities powers draws beauty from the most horrendous of settings finds color in a place where the color has literally been scraped and burned away and instills a sense of calm and order in the midst of devastation and trauma but aside from powers' exquisite prose the novel is an invigorating example of narrative time and sequencing with the crux of the story hinged on the circumstances surrounding murphy's death--and the reasons bartle disposes of his friend's body instead of bringing him home--powers structures his narrative in two alternating threads one thread is rooted in an immediate past which includes bartle's changed life after he returns from iraq his struggles with ptsd his knowledge of what happened to murphy and his failure to keep his promise while the other thread is rooted in a more distant past that includes bartle and murphy's war experiences powers finally merges bartle's past with his present not to demonstrate the beginning of a better or worse future but to bring him into a new reality where he doesn't need to find an explanation for murphy's death tpowers' novel is a tightly written and necessary narrative one which so deftly confronts the shape and dimensions of war the war is everywhere and nowhere an omniscience that swallows identity an arbiter that does not explain its justice but rather than designating his characters as victims of war powers crafts characters who are determined by their experience one of those characters remains in the past but the other continues moving through a present into which he will fade and ultimately disappear

raw_text.1703: every war it seems spawns an author or two who capture its spirit in literature crane remarque trumbo hemingway mailer o'brien critics are suggesting kevin powers' name be added to that list for the iraq war i wouldn't disagree for a moment at once poetic and bloody the story of 20 year old pvt john bartle and his 18 year old buddy pvt murphy evokes the hideous consequences of a war that consists of continuous battle with no target objective beginning or end the bartle murphy unit takes and retakes the same area never knowing when or how they will be attacked at one point there is a booby trapped corpse to contend with guts scraped out to make room for explosives murphy becomes increasingly unmoored and bartle's stateside promise to look after him increasingly difficult to keep all fine and good but what lifts the yellow birds above the generic war novel is that it recounts not only the battlefield combat but the mental and emotional fight of the returning veteran private bartle returns to his mother's virginia home and tries to become once again the part of the world that he left nothing doing everybody is so fucking happy to see you the murderer the fucking accomplice the at bare minimum bearer of some fucking responsibility and everyone wants to slap you on the back and you start to want to burn the whole goddamn country down you want to explain it but it's just like fuck you but then you signed up to go so it's all your fault really because you went on purpose so you are in the end doubly fucked so why not just find a spot and curl up and die and let's make it as painless as possible because you are a coward and really cowardice got you into this mess because you wanted to be a man and in a more poetic vein i didn't want to broaden the evidence of my existence wider than brief footprints of moisture on the floor of my mother's kitchen i looked out the window beyond the woods the county of which they were a part until it all dissolved into the larger thing" my mother's house becoming every other house as i once had seen it sitting atop the southern end of a broad river valley and close enough to ocean that those early english settlers took it as the farthest point they'd go upriver "we are lost therefore we will call this home " we learn only gradually of the incident that evokes bartles' depression and by the time we finally know it's become not just an event in itself but emblematic of the physical and psychological destruction that characterizes the whole iraq enterprise both over there and over here the predicament in yellow birds recalls the situation in the superb film the valley of elah in which the excruciating circumstances surrounding the death of a child also revealed bit by bit haunts the returning veterans involved to the point of insanity the yellow birds is an intensely personal yet intensely universal account of what was till afghanistan overtook it our longest and perhaps least honorable war you will not forget this book and though this is not its primary intent it will not make you proud to be an american

raw_text.1723: i had not been aware of the apparent hype for the yellow birds before picking it up what's more i'm generally not interested in contemporary war novels most of these novels only disappoint anyway can anything compete with catch 22 and the things they carried and yet i happened to glance at one review of the yellow birds and saw a quote that caught my eye i had no context for it but it nonetheless resonated with me so much that i had to seek out the book "...i was full of time as my body would allow but looking back from where i am almost thirty old enough i can see myself for what i was barely a man not a man life was in me but it splashed as if at the bottom of a nearly empty bowl" p 38 9 how beautiful is that the premise is pretty simple the yellow birds gets you inside the head of a young private john bartle as he looks back on time he spent in iraq and the relationship he had with one of his fellow soldiers that came to head in a traumatic way he struggles to find some peace in that experience to be able to move forward in life after war while in its outline it's a conventional story what's remarkable about the yellow birds is the achingly beautiful and haunting way in which kevin powers tells this story i was reading a library copy and i knew instantly that i should've bought my own copy so that i could mark all of the stunning language that i came across during that first reading of it but don't be fooled this is about more than showing off pretty sentences draping with glittery but meaningless metaphors and similes instead the author marshals the beautiful language to illuminate new ways of seeing life and it reminds you of the things you already knew but might've forgotten or didn't have the ability to articulate as well look at how he strikes at the heart of how we conceptualize our place in the world "in that moment i disowned the waters of my youth my memories of them became a useless luxury their names as foreign as any that could be found in nineveh the tigris or the chesapeake the james or the shatt al arab...all belonged to someone else and perhaps had never really been my own...and if i ever floated there again out where the level of the water reached my neck and my feet lost contact with its muddy bottom i might realize that to understand the world one's place in it is to be always at the risk of drowning" p 125 the narration weaves back and forth between the time bartle spends in iraq and the period after he returns home and as the story unfolds powers digs a bit further into bartle's psyche chapter by chapter for such a slim novel the character development had enough depth to convey in an organic manner all of bartle's conflicting emotions the alienation relief guilt emptiness to such a degree that i felt like i was being let in on a secret somehow this slayed me "you want to fall that's all you think it can't go on like that it's as if your life is a perch on the edge of a cliff and going forward seems impossible not for a lack of will but a lack of space the possibility of another day stands in defiance of the laws of physics and you can't go back so you want to fall let go give up but you can't and every breath you take reminds you of that fact so it goes" p 134 ben fountain's novel billy lynn's long halftime walk was also about an introspective soldier serving in the iraq war but it couldn't move beyond trite superficial characterizations which drove me bananas what happened to bartle's friend private murphy is hinted at throughout the book but you don't see the full picture of the circumstances until we get through over three quarters of the book so there's some suspense there but it's not really a plot driven book powers doesn't quite nail the ending but since most of the book is so great i can forgive the bit of sentimentality at the end i will never know what it's like to fight a war no amount of descriptions of what positions soldiers are taking what kind of weapons they're using or where the enemies are advancing will ever come close to approximating what it's like to be in the middle of one i don't read books about war for the action i read books about war to understand the nature of war and of the human condition the mindset of those who are at war and those who survive war the yellow birds was an immensely satisfying read in this regard

raw_text.1747: this quietly compelling novel tells the story of two contemporary american every men actually man boys who find themselves fighting for survival amidst the chaos and cultural upheaval of the 2nd gulf war in iraq 2005 nothing in their backgrounds or experience has prepared them for this circumstance neither urban nor worldly they might as well be marching on the far side of the moon the story is narrated by private bartle 21 at the time of his service focusing on his friendship with private murphy 18 who he has unwittingly promised to keep safe as both soldiers deal with the heat the carnage the exhaustion and the alienation of their new normal it becomes clear that murph does not have the emotional armor to navigate this world private bartle's failure to return his colleague safely home despite his best efforts creates the tension and pathos of the story we see murphy unable to take in the menace and horror of this environment and translate his experience into caution and wariness bartle's personal journey of regret and cover up reflects america's own conflicted role in this war moving spare and emotionally engaging this novel explores the impossible emotional pressures young men and women face far away from home navigating the unnatural hierarchy of military service on one hand and the role of outsider stranger and enemy in a place very different from their own on the other replete with exceptional violence and ambiguity the characters never have the respite of a safe place very well done

raw_text.1789: after reading nelson demille's panther about yemen and watching the documentary higher ground about war veterans of afghanistan and iraq i was drawn to this novel it is beautifully written and heart breaking authored by a veteran of the war in iraq it offers a first person account of the daily life of a soldier on the ground author kevin powers presents the experiences and thoughts of one soldier bartle as he enlists serves and returns home from al tafar iraq the site of powers' real life service from the beginning the reader knows that bartle's fellow soldier murph meets a tragic end the story travels back and forth in time and slowly reveals both bartle and murph's stories i will have to admit that the story got very heavy for me at times i alternately read this novel with a lighter comedic book to provide some relief from the tension after watching the documentary higher ground and reading this book i have a better understanding of the troubles engulfing some of our men and women returning from the middle east and i don't think i will ever forget the significance of the title the yellow birds especially as it is presented on the opening pages of the book read it
raw_text.1790: powers writes with the authority of an iraqi war veteran and his experiences push the reader forward as we follow the journey of one young private through the war we bounce between his time in iraq and back at home we learn early that a promise made to a friend's mother that he'll make sure he returns will not be kept but how that end comes and the results because of it create a suspenseful story the book adds to the growing collection of war novels by veterans while it is often compared to o'brien's the things they carried powers is a little too freshly minted with an mfa at times the prose is too overwrought for a 21 year old private but those instances are rare and this is a book worth reading

raw_text.1820: this review has been hidden because it contains spoilers to view it click here the yellow birds is the debut novel from kevin powers a former american soldier who served in iraq in 2004 and 2005 like many first novels it's partly autobiographical and writing it clearly served as a healing process for some of the things powers did and saw while at war it can sometimes be hard to tell where the autobiography ends and the novel begins until it starts to go down some dark places towards the end the novel is narrated by john bartle a stand in for powers and features a b the yellow birds is the debut novel from kevin powers a former american soldier who served in iraq in 2004 and 2005 like many first novels it's partly autobiographical and writing it clearly served as a healing process for some of the things powers did and saw while at war it can sometimes be hard to tell where the autobiography ends and the novel begins until it starts to go down some dark places towards the end the novel is narrated by john bartle a stand in for powers and features a back and forth chronology that jumps between the bartle's time in nineveh province and his home back in virginia with a brief interlude on the way home in germany bartle's best friend in iraq - or maybe they were just forced together by circumstance - is murph a 19 year old private we learn early on that murph will not survive which is a problem for bartle since he promised murph's mother he'd bring him back safe at first it appears that this is all that haunts bartle back home until it's gradually implied that there's more to it than that - specifically about halfway through the book when bartle's mother mentions that the military's criminal investigation division is looking for him the yellow birds has been critically acclaimed and it deserves to be anderson is a gifted writer with a talent for beautiful prose and the novel is littered with insights that could only come from somebody who has genuinely been through hell and lived to talk about it that's what the yellow birds is ultimately about - survival not death after all more american soldiers in iraq lived than died but the people who came back certainly weren't the same ones who went there in some years more us troops have died from suicide than combat throughout much of the book bartle expects to die and seems bewildered when he doesn't he comes back to america a scarred and broken man with a terrible secret some have called it the definitive iraq war novel which i disagree with it's too early for there to be one for a start but in any case the yellow birds isn't really a novel about war - it's a novel about coming home after being at war in that category at least it's a brilliant accomplishment and i'll be very interested to see what kevin powers writes next i would leave it at that but there's one more thing i want to discuss since it involves the ending of the plot i'm placing it below a spoiler warning and i do strongly recommend you read this book so don't peek spoilers spoilers spoilers avert your eyeswhat bothered me about the ending was that bartle is far far more wracked with guilt about what he and sterling did with murph's body than he is about the fact that sterling casually murdered the cartwright to cover it up robbing a mother of the closure of her son's corpse is a dreadful thing but killing somebody who didn't have to die is far worse what about his mother what about his family this would be understandable if bartle had been portrayed as a gung ho fuck em up gi joe figure who only cares about americans and doesn't give a flying fuck about "hajjis " but he wasn't there are multiple points in the book where he expresses guilt and remorse about killing iraqi insurgents in the heat of battle - yet he expresses no qualms about being accessory to the murder of an iraqi civilian in cold blood even if he is understandably more upset about an action which affected those he personally knew and which he had a slightly more direct hand in and which he had to suffer through the ramifications of i still found it odd and out of character for not a single sentence to be expressed in remorse about the killing of the cartwright the fact that the scene easily could have been written without the cartwright only adds to my confusion powers deliberately included this casual shooting but i can't figure out why it seems to be at odds with the rest of the novel more

raw_text.1852: the first novel of kevin powers the yellow birds is an inspired and lyrical piece of writing that is startling in its ability to employ the elegance of language to describe the disfigurements of war the narrative recounts the experience of a twenty one year old american solider john bartle fighting in the iraqi province of nineveh in al tafar in the fall of 2004 as the death toll of u s soldiers hits 1 000 and bartle and his buddies are counting the two hundred pages of story communicates the dehumanizing and moral consequences of war and the sense of displacement and guilt that bartle feels when he returns home to richmond virginia as a survivor but the book is something of a paradox the writing transmutes the banal horrors of combat into something terrible but elevated however harsh its judgements the writing creates meaning for the senseless losses of battle that bartle describes at least for the reader but this would be rejected and unrecognized by bartle he muses i was a curator of a small unvisited museum if i could not forget i'd hope to be forgotten there is nothing redeeming in his experience it is pure salt fear and solipsism he is left numb adrift and isolated and memories of the emptiness of the desert amplifies his sense of separation from others for bartle there's no escape he leaves his buddy murph behind like bright yellow canaries being let loose with no where to go but to return to their cages he is helplessly enmeshed in his past even after returning home home it just gets worse home life turns the social recognition of his service on its head in ways that are not entirely explained but it's clear bartle keeps paying for mistakes in iraq the yellow birds is pointed in its final judgment it's only murphy who does not survive who escapes powers who fought in al tafar in 2005 promises to be the voice of a generation of combat vets every bit as authentic as tim o'brien or tobias wolff this is a must read

raw_text.1870: taken from my blog at www takemeawayreading comi haven't read many war books so i can't compare this to any though critics and readers alike have made comparisons to tim o'brien's classic the things they carried i can say though that i could easily see this becoming a modern classic in its own right kevin powers an iraqi veteran deployed to al tarf in 2004 describes the experience of being at war through the eyes of 21 year old private bartle i hadn't given a lot of thought to actually going to war but it was happening now and i was still struggling to find a sense of urgency that seemed proportional to the events unfolding in my life i remember feeling relief in basic while everyone else was frantic with fear it had dawned on me that i'd never have to make a decision again that seemed freeing but it gnawed at some part of me even then eventually i had to learn that freedom is not the same thing as the absence of accountability nook pg 24 the yellow birds jumps back and forth in time starting with a scene from in al tafar in 2004 returning to 2003 just before deploying and then moving forward to the after effects in 2005 and beyond i was afraid this would confuse me but it was always clear what was happening and when after reading this i truly feel like i gained some insight into what it's like being at war private bartle reflects on the attitude he has to take on war such as emotionally distancing yourself from feelings related to death since the death of people around you is expected bartle meets 18 year old daniel murphy at training prior to deployment and makes a promise to murphy's mother that he'll protect murphy and bring him back home we learn early on that murphy doesn't in fact make it home this is not a spoiler this is a situation for which bartle feels extreme grief and guilt especially at how it all happens we don't find out until later on what exactly happened out there so in a way the story takes on a mystery element as we figure it out in bits and pieces bartle also reflects though on the differences between how he and others take on the war and how this affects their ability to survive physically and emotionally the yellow birds expertly depicts the thoughts and feelings of those soldiers in the war without overstating anything surprisingly i thought there was pretty minimal detail related to gore or killing or anything you'd think you might find in a novel about war it says and shows what it needs to and leaves it at that it's no wonder this book was a finalist for the national book award the passages were beautiful i bookmarked my way through my reading this is the kind of book i can definitely see myself returning to for a re read this was one of my favorite reads this year with that i'll leave you with another quote i liked maybe if things had happened a little differenty in al tafar it could have been like that but things happened the way they happened without regard to our desire for them to have happened another way despite an age old instinct to provide an explanation more complex than that something with a level of profundity and depth which would seem commensurate raw_text.1879: i am not an avid reader of books about armed conflicts yet i found this to be an incredible book about our war in iraq the story is that of two young soldiers private murphy and private bartle the two meet in boot camp and become friends the events of the book occur before they go to war after they return from the war and while they are in iraq we are told early in the book that one of the soldiers is going to die the language of this book described the scenes the emotions and the events of these two lives with an insight that can only be held by one who has experienced the horror of war the disconnect of emotions is well described in all of the characters a side effect of the conflicts to which they were exposed i was fascinated by the soldiers honest talk about death and how none of them wanted to experience it although they all were acutely aware of it's impending possibility in their lives this book by a first time author really impressed me

raw_text.1888: the yellow birds has been reviewed very favorably and included on a good number of best books lists i thought it terribly over rated because it adds very little to the war novel men in combat genre and in fact it is very simple compared to the complexity of say karl marantes viet nam novel matterhorn or juris jerevics very excellent book red flags it also lacks the intrigue and context of tatjana soli's great 2010 book the lotus eaters perhaps this book since it is rather short ought rather be characterized as a long short story or novella and held to a lesser and different standard in terms of plot complexity breadth of characters insight into the iraq war the experience of war and combat on the young soldier and the experience of the young infantryman as opposed to the nco and officer corps in an indirect way the yellow birds is a political statement on the lack of purpose in our whole effort in iraq as experienced first hand by our military and observed at a distance by many critics and pundits the book does convey the young soldier's indifference to any sense of mission or purpose other than the very worthy and understandable goal of survival for himself and his seemingly only other friend in his unit i guess the book also furthers our understanding of why the basic infantryman is typically so young it would be unrealistic to expect especially now that older more mature men in great numbers would be willing to be combat infantry soldiers especially in iraq or afghanistan
raw_text.1889: not only one of the most beautiful and moving novels i've ever read the yellow birds is perhaps the best depiction of the realities of the iraq war i've encountered in contemporary media at once horrifying beautiful contemplative poetic this novel is everything you would want out of a book it gripped me from the first chapter and tugged me along the chronology is interesting and effective never distracting as the novel chronicles one soldiers experiences in the war and his experiences after the war simultaneously the one central relationship of the novel between our protagonist and his friend daniel murphy is fantastic and moved me to actual tears which books rarely do i highly recommend and think that it deserves all the accolades it received at the end of 2012
raw_text.1890: the yellow birds by kevin powers is to quote ann patchet inexplicably beautiful as difficult as books about war are to read i feel that reading them is a necessity especially for those of us who have never witnessed combat in powers debut novel we get a beautiful heart wrenching look at the iraq war through one veteran's eyes in evocative lyrical prose we witness the iraq war and its aftermath through the eyes of pfc bartle switching chapters between present day american to iraq 2004 05 we see the damage that war does to those who fight it and to those family members left behind powers descriptions of the brutality of war and the effects on him are fierce but also occasionally beautiful he also details his friendship with murph an 18 year old private who he has promised to bring home safely he describes their relationship throughout their time together in iraq and how utterly unprepared they are for the war the aftermath of war effects bartle deeply and the reader truly gets a sense of how difficult it is for a soldier to return to a normal life this novel was most deservedly nominated for the national book award it is a must read for everyone

raw_text.1908: good first novel by iraq war veteran kevin powers from the beginning his eloquence charms and jars you simultaneously the war tried to kill us in the spring as grass greened the plains of nineveh and the weather warmed we patrolled the low slung hills beyond the cities and towns the plot centers around 21 year old private bartle who is ordered to look after 18 year old private murphy in battle ridden al tafar iraq bartle resents having to look after this younger soldier and doesn't want to even get to know him because he is convinced murphy is too inexperienced to survive but he does eventually become closer to murphy and as the war takes it's toll on the 18 year old bartle must deal with a war within as well as the war raging in the desert the premise for the novel is a good one and powers is a gifted writer however i found the characters lacking the depth required for the reader to be truly sympathetic as a result the book was just okay for me

raw_text.1910: this was a book i didn't want to put down at first i struggled with the distance i felt from the narrator it seemed that there wasn't enough detail for me yet it was written poetically enough to engage with the plot although at first i felt the book lacked a level of detail that would have helped me visualize more as i continued with the book i actually found this poignant whether intentional or not this book is about a young man who faces traumatic experiences and therefore one can not expect a clear telling of the story especially at the end of the story where he is tortured by his experiences this led me to greatly appreciate the book it helped me to understand that it's not the details of what happened but his personal response his emotional dis connection resiliencies coping behaviors etc is what is important to focus on and if the level of detail for war was more significant it might have felt somewhat disturbingly vouyeristic and overshadowed the actual impact war had on this one person this should be a must read for high school students helping professionals and families of military personal as well as anyone who either ignores a person in uniform at the airport or thanks them for their service there is a great scene about airport interactions
raw_text.1911: whoever said war is hell penned an absolute truism but what many don't think about is that coming home after the war can also be hell john bartle a twenty one year old is serving a tour in iraq he befriends another soldier eighteen year old murph they survive much but in the end when the unspeakable happens john returns home full of uncertainty remorse and ptsd the short novel explores the what and how john's experiences influence not only john but also those who know and love him it is difficult to like a book like this but i was intrigued and eager to see how events would end finishing this book over memorial day weekend has given me a great deal to think about more so than in other years how anyone fighting an active war can come home unscathed is beyond me and how grateful i am for those who have served in the military and to those who are currently serving

raw_text.1913: kevin powers served in iraq with the us army in 2004 and 2005 the book is written from the point of view of private bartle who is serving in iraq during the same time period as powers actually served it weaves between time periods jumping back and forth between iraq and then the us after bartle returns from the war every chapter jumps to a different period of time and while this could easily be disjointing power has woven a story that flows easily i don't normally read books about war and this was stretching me outside of my normal box the details are disturbing and because they are written by someone who has seen first hand the realities of this war they are graphic at times i found myself drawn into the story feeling more than just my own emotions but also those of the characters the connection between bartle and murph is complex and touching while i knew early on that murph had died i didn't see the ending coming until it did and it added a whole new layer for me to the story and the character in reading about the thought process in deciding what to do with murph's body i saw parallels to other decisions where we might guess what might be best for another sometimes we are wrong but the thought process and emotions going into the decision are important and fascinating all in all yellow birds drew me in far more than i thought it would i love books where i can identify with the characters in this book i was in a unique position as i have no personal experience going to war or actively sending a loved one off to war and yet i felt that powers made the characters relatable to me even still it is not surprising to me that he is a poet his way with words was outstanding

raw_text.1977: american literature has a history with war over time it has led to beautiful tragic honest works the civil war led to the red badge of courage wwi to a farewell to arms wwii to the naked and the dead the vietnam war to the things they carried and now perhaps kevin powers has added to this literary tradition with his debut novel the yellow birds in 2004 twenty one year old private john bartle serves in the u s army he and his platoon are stationed in an iraqi town called al tafar where they endure firefights mortar fire and quasi general patton speeches from sergeants with camera crews still for bartle and his friend murph an eighteen year old soldier priority lays in a single thought we didn't want to be the thousandth soldier killed this goal becomes a reality neither is the thousandth killed but as bartle mentions repeatedly revealing little by little throughout the novel murph is in fact killed complicating things before leaving basic training at fort dix at the family goodbye party bartle promises murph's mother that he will protect her son that he will bring him home alive the story is told in retrospect by bartle himself now almost thirty years old living in the gift of quiet quarantine in a cabin in the hills below the blue ridge from this point of view bartle moves past a simple action packed war novel and instead now that he can see him self for what he was examines his psychological damage and inability to recapture his humanity any attempt at returning to his past self who he was before the war appears as hopeless and futile as the repetitive battles he speaks of "seems like we're fighting over this town every year and his attempt for a return to normalcy appears near impossible when the cid criminal investigation division begins to uncover a secret from bartle's time in the war the yellow birds is a product of classic american war literature one hears echoes of crane hemingway o'brien one finds muses on their themes such as cowardice manliness guilt one even sees in bartle elements of henry fleming nick adams and paul berlin but while sharing in this literary tradition the yellow birds digs out its own place as one of the best and strongest books to come out of the iraq war head to www everydayebook com for more ebook reviews

raw_text.1979: kevin powers enlisted in the army and served as a machine gunner in the iraq war he brings an authenticity to the sounds heat smells death and reaction to american force that gives the reader a sense of what we all felt but never saw on the filtered news one example is he speaks of dead people everywhere we never saw that or the on the ground brutality he gives us a visceral tour of the ravages of war on the body mind and spirit the protagonist twenty one year old pvt john bartle promises the mother of eighteen year old private daniel murphy that he would bring him back alive overhearing bartle's promise provokes sergeant sterling to punch him in the face later bartle doesn't understand he will later they are there only to keep themselves alive bartle murphy and sterling are the boots on the ground they disdain the press or senior brass who drop by or in but are there for themselves or a photo op or a story to take with them home there is no purpose or destination to the war there's no way to win it appears bartle and sterling had no purpose in their lives before they joined up there's an isolation in each bartle is intellectual and internally conflicted while sterling understands the war they're fighting and what he needs to do to keep his men safe he also understands the psychology of who breaks and who doesn't under the numbing violence he is not only capable of anything he's probably done or at least seen it all sterling brings the story to life and is a great bookmark to the narrator bartle who is trying to understand the puzzle that has led him into the maze of hopelessness he's fighting to survive caring for and staying close to murphy gives him his only purpose bartle is conflicted about sterling sterling excels at killing but sterling is unshakeable in the face of terror and it is his bravery that keeps his men going although they are all indifferent to the death and destruction around them until a young nurse is killed this pushes murphy over the edge and sets up the conclusion in a book that gets better and better as it goes on the writing is poetic the world was paper thin as far as i could tell and the world was the orchard and the orchard was what came next but none of that was true i was only afraid of dying " if there is a fault in the book it does go on at times with long descriptions but this is a minor complaint in a powerful compelling read the story is told from bartle's memory in large fragments in a non linear structure that reminded me of the best of robbe grillet the iraq tragedy is a puzzle we will be fighting for the rest of our lives even though most would like to forget it happened and move on it takes an artist to shine a light and make some sense of that conflict and what it means in human terms

raw_text.1984: kevin powers' book is a gritty and harrowing novel set around the iraq conflict central to the book is the relationship between privates john bartles and daniel murph murphy we learn very early on however that murph has been killed and the book focusses largely on the effects on john of his loss the story is told from john's point of view in a memoir like style and vividly describes the conflict that takes place around him as well as telling of how he was asked by murph's mother to keep her son safe the story is not told in a linear style and it jumps back and forth in the timeline however the beginning of each chapter indicates where the reader is in the chain of events so one moment john will be talking about losing murph and then there will be a chapter about him and murph both fighting in the war and then there will be a chapter set after his return from the conflict one of the most profound an enjoyable and profound moments was the depiction of his arrival home and his descripton of how he goes up to his bedroom slowly undresses and then puts his dog tags back on and stands looking at himself in the mirror i noticed also that when senior officers are mentioned they seem to come across as uncaring and unpleasant the dialogue is very descriptive about john's feelings throughout including his friendship with murphy and both characters are easy to care about very quickly amongst the depictions of events there are several moments where the narrator talks at length about his thoughts about what has happened while the narrative slowly builds towards the moment when murph was killed overall i loved this book it wasn't particularly long but i found it to be incredibly thought provoking as a depiction of modern warfare and its effects on individuals plus the struggle to overcome the loss of a friend

raw_text.1988: the war tried to kill us in the spring so begins a book about what happens to boys technically men but really just boys when they go to war not what boys do though they do do things and not what happens to them physically though they are wounded and scarred and killed no this is a book about what happens to them mentally how even if they return they're never really back the story by first time author kevin powers alternates between john bartle's experiences in iraq and shortly after leaving some reviewers have criticized the time shifting but i thought it was used to great effect we feel the trauma that bartle the narrator has endured but we don't understand until the end powers served as a machine gunner in iraq and holds an mfa from the university of texas his knowledge of the region and of life on the front is reflected in his fine prose he expertly captures the tension and tedium of deployment the opening sentence deserves all the plaudits it gets but it is not the only one engaging disturbing and powerful it reminded me of heart of darkness and for whom the bell tolls particularly the parts where robert jordan is most introspective

raw_text.2007: this book will break your heart but i loved the writing you know from the start that any novel that deals with young u s soldiers in iraq is going to be a downer but this left me feeling like all the pain i vicariously went through with the main character was worth something and also very grateful that i have not really experienced any of this but full of sorrow for those who have i saw this headline today in the satirical online newspaper the onion nation horrified to learn about war in afghanistan while reading up on petraeus sex scandal it feels in so many ways that people have forgotten that there are still soldiers in iraq as well reading the yellow birds will crack you open the author is a poet and the images that appear throughout the book are devastatingly beautiful the field of hyacinths and the dream horse that nuzzles bartle as he lies drunk and nearly drowning in a lake after returning home the novel paints in one reality of the war in iraq another book night draws near iraq's people in the shadow of america's war a work of non fiction by anthony shadid shades in more of the picture i think they go together each echoing the cry in the other a chorus that one hopes will lead to understanding

raw_text.2010: what i appreciated most about this book is how utterly different it is from any other war fiction i've read stylistically it could not be more different than say tim o'brien's the things they carried really it's more poetry than prose and powers' figurative language and love of the run on sentence meant that i had to read many sentences two or three times just to understand what he was talking about but it sings it really does which is amazing for a story so full of desolation so void of hope so completely despairing there is just enough mystery about the past which is revealed piece by piece to keep the pages turning although ultimately it's a story about ptsd about a soldier rebelling against the illusion of normalcy on his return from service in iran
raw_text.2011: this story deals with post traumatic stress that follows a soldier that has experienced the 'under belly' of war in this case in iraq it deals with the raw emotion of living far away from home in a foreign environment where the 'foreign' concept of deliberately inflicting harm to life u0026amp limb is the order of the day the sleep deprivation the extreme weather conditions as well as the real danger of being killed wears down the individual to the point where it provokes serious doubt about one's moral fiber this negative experience of war is then feted when the soldier comes back home to a hero's welcome except he is feeling like a loser usually i do not enjoy a story that skips back and forth in time but found that it helped to relieve the emotional tension each time the story is told with amazing sensitivity and depth of feeling there is no conclusive ending but this underscores the fact that a life experience like war may diminish in time but will be an unforgettable memory kevin powers writes so beautifully here is one particular passage i found incredibly profound all pain is the same only the details are different another passage describing the character's feeling about the wanton killing because it felt like there was acid seeping down into your soul and then your soul is gone there is no making up for what you are doing this is a compelling read the remarks on the book cover are quite conflicting deeply compelling inexplicably beautiful devastating yet all are applicable

raw_text.2028: yellow birds recently won the pen hemingway award so i moved it up on my to read list i am not a fan of war novels and i did struggle with this book at the beginning a story of two young men fighting in the iraq war the novel brings us into the battlefield but the real story happens in the mind of private bartle as he struggles with the atrocities of war the choices he is forced to make and a broken promise one he never should have made and couldn't control i found that i don't like to read about war because really i find it intolerable to think about the thousands of men and women who have sacrificed their lives whether physically or otherwise in an intractable war this book made me realize just how much i have kept the iraq war at bay i could not visualize powers' chapters that took place in battle it really was hard for me to put my head around so when i started this book i didn't know if i could finish it but the way he captured bartle's internal struggle with ptsd was profound the book does leave me feeling heavy hearted and i can't help to think about the support needed for our returning veterans
raw_text.2029: kevin powers' novel is a powerfully evocative story showing the psychological effect of war on young men describing in graphic and necessary detail what they are asked to carry out in the na me of national security written in lyrical prose that is full of searing images and with every sentence carefully constructed it switches between the main protoganist's tour of duty and it's aftermath when he is discharged the horror is leavened with passages of tenderness as the narrator tries to make sense of the brutality he undertakes during periods of leave powers uses an interesting reveal device as he leaves clues to a major incident that is going to occur later in the narrative and the effect it has it's as if he needs to explain what led to the almost unspeakable horror of what is to come by writing truthfully and poetically and by not glorifying conflict like remarque and sherriff powers has written something that is neither pro nor anti war but nevertheless leaves the reader with no delusions about the price paid in lost and damaged lives

raw_text.2045: the yellow birds kevin powers first book has received a lot of positive press a young veteran with a strong family history of military service powers attempts to tell what the iraq war was really like in novel form powers is a poet the main character of the yellow birds private john bartle also loves poetry and literature he sees the world lyrically describing color smells movement and the incongruous sometimes this tendancy to think in snatches of experience gets in the way of a smooth flowing storyline and bartles soldiering while this may come across sometimes as being a bit stilted and chaotic it does successfully convey the moment to moment existance of bartle's life bartle's trouble begins when he enlists against his mother's wishes troubles escalate when he promises the mother of a new enlistee daniel murphy that he will bring him home to her bound by his promise bartle attempts to protect a soldier who lacks the temperament for war powers writes about soldiers responsibility towards one another the psychological devastation of war and the connection that soldiers develop with the place and the people that they fight against through bartle's relationship with the character of ladonna murphy powers describes the difficulty that the military has with the american public the american public demands explanation and cleaniness while the military has gotten better at letting the public know the full impact of war there are some events that are too horrific or morally ambigious for service members to share private bartle buries the truth to protect ladonna murphy and us from a comprehensive understanding of what war means this is not a call of duty battlefield or medal of honor take on war instead it is a story of good intentions conflicted feelings and unhinging read it if you are seeking emotional connection not battle scenes

raw_text.2054: the basics set in iraq in 2004 and the months after the yellow birds tells the story of two soldiers private bartle and private murphy who meet at training camp my thoughts this novel's opening chapter is a visceral depiction of war as i read it on the bus i found myself crying and trying to breathe deeply to calm myself i was grateful when the time shifted in the next chapter powers continues this powerful alternation between the war in iraq and bartle's attempts to deal with its aftermath the reader learns early on that murphy doesn't survive the war yet the tension leading up to the how and why of his death is a literary marvel i was eager to begin a chapter away from the war but as the novel progressed and bartle struggled i soon found the iraq chapters less emotionally challenging bartle is 21 while murphy is 18 as i read i had to remember how large of a difference it is between age 18 and 21 particularly when you're killing to try to stay alive their age difference plays into the power dynamics of their friendship and adds a wrinkled layer to the events of murphy's death to which powers slowly builds up favorite passage half of memory is imagination anyway the verdict the yellow birds is a quiet haunting and deeply moving depiction of the two soldiers and the impact of war it's astonishingly well paced and gets better as it goes on leading up to one of the best endings i've read this year rating 4 5 out of 5
