raw_text.2061: my dad was a cold warrior serving in the air force from before my birth to well into my adult years part of that time was spent serving in vietnam and thailand and yes there was combat in thailand at the time where he was a radio operator who also served on base defense whenever his base was attacked apparently this happened a few times in his stay in southeast asia as a boy being a boy i asked my dad dad did you ever get a purple heart he responded no way i kept my ass down that's what the army's for when i insensitively broached the question did you ever kill anyone he responded i don't know i shot at a few people but i was too busy keeping my head down to see whether or not i hit them the security police and army detachments did most of the dirty work we just laid down fire to keep the enemy pinned still dad felt the after effects of combat when we lived in the philippines there was a collision at an intersection where we were waiting at a four way stop dad more scared than i've ever seen him before or since opened the car door and hid under the steering column even at that young age i knew that this wasn't normal dad's fine now has been for years but i've often wondered what he would be like had he been in heavy combat for longer periods of time now there are plenty of people who have seen combat and come out unscathed perfectly healthy physically mentally and emotionally i'm not an alarmist about what combat may or may not do to a person's psyche no one is doomed to an unhappy life for having been on the front lines on the other hand i've personally seen some bad cases of ptsd some stretching out for many many years some of my earliest memories are those of seeing wounded soldiers incoming from vietnam getting off the medivac helicopters at the base where we lived in the philippines it took years before i realized why they were all bandaged up some on stretchers some with gauze completely covering their eyes now i realize that red and white are not colors you want to see on a soldier thankfully these guys were already stabilized on the hospital ships out in cam ranh bay and were going home now or at least back to the states where they would try to pick up their lives again with what was left of their bodies and souls so when my son's best friend stated that he was joining the marines i was concerned it's probably the right decision for him and he's going to be a helicopter munitions crewman not the most dangerous job to say the least still i worry about him the yellow birds didn't help this is as disturbing a novel as you'll read about war the horrors of the iraq war were bad enough to see from news reports flashed into my living room but to see it from the inside out as it were from the perspective of a soldier in the thick of it was difficult to digest mechanically the book is outstanding my only complaint was that the poetic framework of the book was sometimes exposed as in the multiple rapid fire use of the word and to try to push the narrative down into a stream of consciousness channel and and and powers seemed like he was trying too hard to be poetic it was too clever too contrived thankfully this only happened a few times but there is some beautiful prose in this novel prose that contradicts the ugliness of the situation the very personal voice of the narrator is buried in the impersonal unfeeling circumstances i'd been trained to think war was the great unifier that it brought people closer together than any other activity on earth bullshit war is the great maker of solipsists how are you going to save my life today dying would be one way if you die it becomes more likely that i will not you're nothing that's the secret a uniform in a sea of numbers a number in a sea of dust and we somehow thought those numbers were a sign of our own insignificance we thought that if we remained ordinary we would not die we confused correlation with cause and saw a special significance in the portraits of the dead arranged neatly next to the number corresponding to their place on the growing list of casualties we read in the newspapers as indications of an ordered war of course we were wrong our biggest error was thinking it mattered what we thought it seems absurd now that we saw each death as an affirmation of our lives that each one of those deaths belonged to a time and that therefore that time was not ours we didn't know the list was limitless it's this sense of being caught up in something bigger than oneself that informs the entire novel there is a feeling of inevitability to the events that occur an existentialist cosmic mockery of the individuals who think they are their own agents that they control their own destiny shades of orwell's 1984 and the works of lovecraft though this fiction feels closer to a memoir than to the fantastical hyperbole of its more speculative cousins this is grounded in the banal this feels real i thought of my grandfather's war how they had destinations and purpose how the next day we'd march out under a sun hanging low over the plains in the east we'd go back into a city that had fought this battle yearly a slow bloody parade in fall to mark the change of season we'd drive them out we always had we'd kill them they'd shoot us and blow off our limbs and run into the hills and wadis back into the alleys and dusty villages then they'd come back and we'd start over by waving to them as they leaned against lampposts and unfurled green awnings while drinking tea in front of their shops while we patrolled the streets we'd throw candy to their children with whom we'd fight in the fall a few more years from now from the foregoing quotes you might think that this book is short on hope you'd be right it's a downward spiral into meaninglessness and despair a vortex of emotional numbness this is not for the faint of heart but i still recommend it it's difficult to review this book without becoming a little pedantic so please excuse me for a moment as i point out one of the reasons you should read the book read it and the next time it's election day ask yourself whether or not you should go vote and think carefully on the consequences think on the blessing of freedom including freedom from war and its effects this book might just cause you to more carefully weigh the alternatives at your disposal and choose wisely who knows with your marker hovering over a check box in the voting booth or with your hand poised over the phone and the phone book open to your congressman's number you might just be preventing the sequel to this book from ever having to be written though i have little faith that there will be a cessation to the series of war one of these books is enough for a lifetime

raw_text.2083: the war tried to kill us in the spring this is how the yellow birds a national book award finalist by first time novelist kevin powers opens the yellow birds is a harrowing story of a young american soldier fighting in iraq in 2004 who finds himself isolated and confused back home it's a story of friendship the keeping of a promise and survivor's guilt the novel's narrative moves back and forth in time and place offering vivid descriptions of battle and daily life in a war zone during the fall of 2004 when the story's main character and narrator army private bartle is serving in irag's al tafar province and one year later at home in virginia before deploying to irag bartle is asked by the mother of his friend murph to keep her son safe not knowing what else to say bartle hastily agrees setting up the story's central dilemma in time the daily violence and fear set upon the young soldiers proves too much for murph to bear murph eventually comes unmoored after witnessing the death of a young female medic he admires wanders off alone and unarmed eventually falling into the hands of iraqi insurgents the novel makes it clear early on that bartle is unable to keep the promise he made to murph's mother upon returning home a year later bartle becomes a recluse and a more than casual drinker at the urging of his mother who's worried about her son's state of mind bartle attends a swimming party at a river with friends unable to mix with his friends bartle sits aloof drinking and pondering the stark ironies of his new life he hates himself for what he's done and for what he's witnessed while those back home heap endless praise on him for his service to his country i had become a kind of cripple i feel like i'm being eaten from the inside out and i can't tell anyone what's going on because everyone is so grateful to me all the time and will feel like i'm ungrateful or something the novel plumbs the depths of the emotional destruction of our current wars wars that have endured while requiring the personal sacrifice of relatively few americans it's a novel that serves as an uncomfortable reminder to those of us who have had the luxury of detachment from war's violence and the emotional toll it claims from combatants and their families the descriptions of combat and its aftermath are brutal and honest without being gratuitous the yellow birds is that rare novel that delivers a timely and important story and does it with beautiful prose the writing is melancholy and lyrical eschewing unnecessary adornment or sentimentality powers deftly avoids the conventional narrative ploys to which too many war stories fall prey in this war story there are no obvious heroes no children saved from burning villages no rape victims avenged just young americans trying to cope with chaos trying to stay alive the yellow birds presents neither a justification nor a repudiation of the iraq war instead it paints a picture and in doing so leaves us the citizens in whose name the war was undertaken with a clarified vision of the sacrifices paid by its participants kevin powers himself participated in the war he so affectingly portrays and his reflective and haunting novel bears the scars as with all good art the yellow birds stays with you long after you've put it down

raw_text.2097: the modern era war story poignantly wand beautifully written this is what people will talk about 10 20 30 years from now not those garbage memoirs about killing osama or holding the highest number of kills
raw_text.2098: this really is something special told as a first person narrative by bartle 21 years old and on his first tour of duty in iraq 2004 this documents his friendship with 18 year old fellow american soldier murphy and his desperate attempts to hold on to some remnants of humanity and compassion in the midst of war this is a beautifully written novel which recounts the brutality of war in lyrical almost poetic style from the opening war itself is personified as something with an agency and life of its own i really liked that this is in lots of ways a quiet novel it's not full of daring action or obvious set pieces though the central `event' which the narrative seems to almost want to shy away from is appropriately violent and heart rending while this is set in iraq it's a novel about war in more general and conceptual terms and eschews localised politics for a depiction of the way in which combat ravages the spirit striving to strip men of what makes them human the only victory in this book is that bartle resists giving in to violence cruelty and inhumanity and maintains a sense of care and very human sympathy the descriptions of iraq as ninevah give this a mythic air at times and help to ground the book away from the specific this isn't always an easy read in that it's painful and heartfelt but it is an outstanding one harrowing and beautiful this is the sort of novel which deserves to win literary prizes

raw_text.2101: a tremendous insight into the psychology of modern war i read the yellow birds in one sitting over the course of an afternoon and was unable to clear my head until much later that night protagonist john bartle's ordeal stuck with me in a way i couldn't quite explain i felt that like bartle i had been to war and back and had left a part of myself behind upon return author kevin powers uses clean swift prose and just enough detail to craft a story that one might mistake for an autobiography indeed i had to remind myself from time to time that i was reading a novel and not an account of the author's own military service in iraq this i think is powers's greatest accomplishment he makes us believe that bartle murph and sergeant sterling are real -- that they exist somewhere far away and though we have never met them we know them well it makes their ordeal all the more harrowing and reminds us of the actual soldiers who have fought and died overseas highly recommended

raw_text.2118: yellow birds is a novel about the second iraq war written by a veteran of that war it was the one book one philadelphia selection in 2014 evidently someone thought this was a good book personally i think it's solidly the second worst book i've ever read the book has gotten some positive reviews but though i've tried i can't figure out why maybe people feel sorry for a veteran who turned to writing and want to provide positive reinforcement - the kind you give the slow kid on the track team i'm not buying it as a writer kevin powers is just simply a fraud so here's why yellow birds is one of the worst books i've ever read *tnothing happens there is no plot just some scenery it's boring *tthere is no character development through time the protagonist starts the novel as a loser is a loser in the middle and remains a loser at the end *tnothing is all that special about protagonist or his plight his conflict feels imagined and contrived for all the ripe material he must have had to work with the story line powers chooses to go with is immensely disappointing i felt a much more visceral connection to the events of the iraq war reading newspaper articles about it at the time the news was more real and more poetic the news had more perspective *ti'm not buying that the narrator's speaking from different points in time over the course of the book is as some reviewers say a symptom of his trauma and a literary device used to get the reader inside the head of a guy with ptsd i think it's just a poorly structured narrative *tthere is no mind changing or paradigm shift from the start of the narrative to the end for this author war is was and always will be hell and there are no redeeming points war is presumably pointless and all it's characters are dishonorable wretches *tthe prose is just plain boring other reviews have said the style is "lyrical" i disagree using big words and poor sentence structure does not make a novel lyrical any more than big sneakers and a poor sense of balance makes an athlete needless to say i won't be reading anything else by kevin powers i'm questioning whether i should read any more of the one book one philadelphia selections
raw_text.2119: the yellow birds sees author kevin powers marry this old life as a serving soldier in iraq and his new one of writer and poet with award winning success not to mention a great many strong review on this site and others it is a story of a soldier's life in training and in service but more than that it is about friendship the disconnect between life in war and at home and the psychological trauma suffered both in the field and after important themes lent added weight in knowing the author's personal experience of such things but that doesn't mean it translates into a truly effective novel at least for me this is a war story written by a poet but with the emphasis on the latter rather than the former the prose is at times lyrical at times sparse at times confused so much so that at times the plot seems to be playing second fiddle to the style and there isn't much space for characterisation either the structure jumping forward and back in time frames only adds to the dreamy hazy that pervades the novel this numbness might reflect the effect war has had on the narrator but equally it deadens any humour fear threat anger or joy that's not to say there isn't any grit or realism the author's experience as a soldier does shine through at times but this is no straight memoir or traditional war story much of it is beautiful the opening line is a classic and there's plenty more in the same vein however i found it less effective at novel length and while this is a book that deserves to be read i found it tougher to enjoy

raw_text.2122: this book was even better than the excellent the things we carried i am a vet and i was almost overwhelmed by the raw power of this book the descriptions the feelings that a soldier carries in his soul while it still lives kevin powers has a lot of it oh so right and very little wrong i know that this is not a book that will be an easy read nor will it appeal to everyone but it is a book that should be read when i was in vietnam i had a platoon sergeant who used to say that war is 90% sheer boredom and 10%sheer terror during the long hours we spent together we used to talk a lot about what we going to do when we got back to the world about what we thought people were doing back in th world while we were away fighting the war imagine how stunned we were when those of us who made it through finally got home we're actually back in the world and found out that we no longer belonged that we were never going to be the idealistic young men we were when we left and that we could not tell anybody we knew how it felt to go to war or how it felt to come back to peacetime america and discover that the world had gone on without us and there was no getting it back kevin powers understands all of this and this is what his book tells us if we can understand

raw_text.2139: the yellow birds is a beautifully written book with an attention to language more often expected from a poet than a novelist kevin powers builds his engaging story through an accretion of detail and a non linear plot that absorbs a reader into a very simple tale of life in wartime - in this case a profoundly meaningless life in wartime that corrupts and drains everyone involved the author spent a tour of duty in iraq near the height of the war whether the story he tells is one he lived or heard about or completely invented it's impossible to deny its elemental truth and one can only marvel at the elegance of how it's told

raw_text.2142: i highly recommend kevin powers' the yellow birds it's powerful opening line the war tried to kill us in the spring launches a steady string of poetic prose most oddly fitting to follow its protagonist from indoctrination to war then home again normally i read books on kindle to highlight passages but powers the artist defeated me as he ran paragraphs into pages of vivid and poignant descriptions i resorted at last to the page tag marking regions instead the war is tal afar iraq where powers actually served as an army machine gunner from 2004 2005 before later earning an m f a in poetry from u t austin war is horrible for anyone especially one so sensitive as i imagined powers allowing his characters to remember the hyacinth fields the chapters alternate evenly past and present both arriving to explain what had happened and what is happening as a result the book is not a war commentary descriptions of horrific incidents in the book are brief and most matter of fact whether an elderly couple driving into the middle of a battle or a body bomb on a bridge it is the battle within the minds of his character that merit his attention he does not describe war as if we are observing alongside his characters instead we feel the war as if we are his characters scenes of duty honor and destiny transcend into nobler challenges of getting along and surviving

raw_text.2159: this novel is beautifully written it tells the story of 21 year old soldier john bartle's experience in iraq in 2004 2005 and the aftermath when he returns home as bartle recounts his memories of his time in iraq the story flips back between al tafar in northern iraq and richmond virginia in iraq he befriends murph a 17 year old soldier from a coal mining town in west virginia bartle tries to comes to grips with what happened to his friend and how he could have kept the promise he had made to murph's mother it is a very moving story and one that definitely needs to be told ten years after the us invaded iraq we as a society are still struggling to come to grips as to why we went there in the first place what impact did it have on us and what was actually achieved the voice of the poet soldier definitely comes through in this book although the events in the story are not based on what happened to the author the emotions and turmoil that he felt are sometimes the poetic language can be a bit distracting from the plot but it is also part of what makes this book so moving you could definitely tell that he needed to write about what he went through physically mentally and spiritually when he served and he is to be greatly admired for having the courage to do this and to have done this so eloquently is truly admirable he has done his fellow comrades a very valuable service by providing the world a glimpse of the horror of what they went through he also reminds us that it doesn't end when they come home the yellow birds was shortlisted for the national book award and in my view it was much more worthy than the round house by a lot

raw_text.2161: kevin powers enlisted in the army straight out of high school and served as a machine gunner in iraq for two years his debut novel the yellow birds takes us to that time and place it should be required reading for every elected official voting to send 18 year olds off to war compared to the red badge of courage and all quiet on the western front powers' compact novel is brutal and beautiful i wasn't surprised to learn that powers first love was poetry he was the michener fellow in poetry at the university of texas in austin there are scenes in the yellow birds that are so powerful and iridescent that i frequently found myself rereading whole passages

raw_text.2164: this is a bereaved look at a soldier and his world calling it tragic would be too narrow a description this book will not be appreciated enough until years or perhaps decades from now because it is so readable so far it seems the yellow birds has been micro marketed as a war novel which is true but also dismissive of the power of pain it calls forth it's easy to miss the sour and unbearably distraught irony that haunts beneath the beautiful prose only bursting to the surface in moments of calm or confusion lyrically it sprints taking stops in almost every paragraph to depict some color or dust i hope every american reads this i hope we discover the national cure for endless war i hope our soldiers forgive us

raw_text.2167: i read this book because it was listed as a national book award winner and was well reviewed being a story about war it was a significant departure from my usual fare but frankly i wonder sometimes if reading either nonfiction or well written fiction tales of our newest wars those not steeped so far in history as to be considered fought by them and not us should be required reading for all our populace so i read it it was so excellently written i was amazed i wish i could write like that i kept thinking the sentences were so well constructed the characters observed the world in such a simple yet profound manner this book was the first novel by this author a former army machine gunner and veteran of the iraq war and it was awesome what will he come up with next i enjoyed this book in spite of its sometimes gruesome always morally questioning story a story most of us would just as soon not consider since it's so much easier just to let the military handle all our fights for us they volunteered didn't they but the yellow birds clearly demonstrates all over again that fighting the bad guys is not as simple as it sounds and our returning heroes may not feel like heroes at all if you ever wondered why there seems to be so much ptsd this is your book you'll never wonder again

raw_text.2172: the war tried to kill us in the spring as grass greened the plains of nineveh and the weather warmed we patrolled the low slung hills beyond the cities and towns we moved over them and through the tall grass on faith kneading paths into the windswept growth like pioneers while we slept the war rubbed its thousand ribs against the ground in prayer when we pressed onward through exhaustion its eyes were white and open in the dark while we ate the war fasted fed by its own deprivation it made love and gave birth and spread through fire 3 so begins kevin powers' powerful and lyrically written novel of two friends trying to survive the battles in al tafar a city in iraq the yellow birds is a book which tells the story of privates bartle and murphy two very young men sent into battle for the first time bartle the elder of the two by three years rashly promises murphy's mother that he will keep murphy safe and bring him home--a promise he himself doesn't take seriously and regrets making the novel moves between the present and the past slowly revealing the painful truth that keeping a soldier's body safe doesn't matter when his mind is unable to process the violence and horror of war i was very moved by this book powers tells a very a violent and sad story in beautifully composed sentences it's obvious he is foremost a poet and he is also a soldier he served in al tafar despite how well written the book is it's not a pretty story it's tragic and brutal the book is told from bartle's point of view and he is not optimistic about his or anyone else's chances of survival he and murphy agree that it's okay if they die they just don't want to be the thousandth killed they don't want the notoriety of having that number he and murphy have an interesting way of thinking about the dead soldiers that they are in some way destined to die because the war is orderly and death is orderly and that the list of the dead soldiers has been planned already "we had a sense something we only felt in the brief flash of synapse to synapse that these names had been on the list long before the dead had come to iraq that the names were there as soon as those portraits had been taken a number given a place assigned and that they'd been dead from that moment forward" 12 he called them the walking dead men and women who were invincible--until they weren't there is a lot to comprehend in this book and i think that i read it much too quickly mistaking its brevity 226 pages for lack of depth it's only now as i write this review and think about what i read that i realize i will have to one day read this book again and give it the attention it demands this book reminded me of sebastian junger's exploration of war in his phenomenal book war private bartle expressed thoughts similar to those of the soldiers junger was stationed with when researching his book i found it a bit eerie this book is probably not everyone's cup of tea particularly if you like your books to have definitive endings and little or no abstract language and philosophy however anyone looking for a book that explores themes of war and loss and love and what it means to be a survivor the yellow birds is an excellent place to start

raw_text.2177: an intense read powers has an mfa in poetry which aided him in giving me i hope the most life like depiction i'll ever get of what it feels like to be engaging on the ground in a war in our time at times the writing got too abstract for my taste but there were far more amazing passages that engaged my senses tangible descriptions the smells powers wisely structured the story to alternate between iraq and the us which gives the reader room to breathe powers's description of "what combat felt like" on page 93 of the hard cover edition was so visceral for me that i had to put the book down and walk away "...like a car accident...that instant between knowing that it's going to happen and actually slamming into the other car...like that split second...except here it can last for goddamn days "i'd recommend yellow birds to those looking for an experiential and poetic read the reentry of veterans into civilian life and their mental health is much in the news powers quoted a vet as having said that "the army does a great job of making us killers but don't do a good job when we get out of making us nonkillers "

raw_text.2182: i am leading a book club tomorrow discussing this book so i finally sat down and read it i started it over a week ago but i only got about 15 pages in before abandoning it for my current love contemporary ya novels i was afraid i was going to have to force myself to sit and read it today but once i got into it i managed to speed through it in less than two hours it is a brutal book i tend to avoid war stories with a few notable exceptions slaughterhouse five the things they carried etc so i went into it thinking i was going to hate it the writing is vivid and beautiful and lyrical even though the words are describing some of the worst of humanity i was totally entranced by the writing it is a story told time and time again the horrors of war and those who survive it then struggle to readjust to the real world i have no personal experience with war but i felt like i walked away from this novel with a slightly better understanding i will never fully 'get' it but i appreciate kevin powers's excellent effort to describe what it feels like to be a solider in a horrific war
raw_text.2183: before heading to iraq with the us army in 2004 private bartle promises to private murphy's mother he'll bring murphy home the war in iraq is brutal horrific and numbing and bartle struggles with this promise they are lead through endless patrols and gruelling firefights by the nasty veteran sergeant sterling i hated him sterling i hated the way he excelled in death and brutality and domination but more than that i hated the way he was necessary how i needed him to jar me into action even when they were trying to kill me p19 powers we understand served in the same place tal afar during the same period as the story is set so the detail is presumably realistic it certainly feels it the nastiness of death the callousness of nearly all involved bombs hidden inside dead bodies of a gut shot soldier snot ran onto his upper lip and the shaking of his body threw small flecks of spittle over his chin i realised he had been still for a while and he was dead i thought he was going to say something p119 these observations are spun together with fine writing as the narrator bartle slowly disintegrates albeit possibly at a slower rate than some around him themes develop in fact one hits you in the first sentence the war tried to kill us in the spring the idea of the war as a massive unfeeling all consuming monster thus there is no fate no bullet has your name on it the war will take what it can get your superstitions and thoughts are irrelevant your actions nearly so our biggest error was thinking that it mattered what we thought as horror mounts upon horror the soldiers numb and their memories haze truth becomes a mix of uncertain memory imagination and wish much of the story is set in the usa both before and after the soldiers' tour and the effect of the war on the families of the combatants is keenly explored we already knew that there are few winners in war and this story brings stark emphasis to that worn truism

raw_text.2188: there is no way i would pick up a book about war even if it is fiction but yellow birds was a suggestion when we were choosing the years books probably made by our library director who actually reads professional reviews i've been wanting to read matterhorn for a long while but it's so big yellow birds is only 226 pages i like to read something once in a while that's been recommended that i wouldn't normally pick up i feel an aversion for war movies as well i just noticed that matterhorn is described as a book about going to war i think yellow birds might be more about coming home from war although most of the story actually takes place on the battle field which by the way is a city with lots of buildings and innocent people it is first a description of what being a soldier in this situation in iraq is the first sentence says it all the war tried to kill us it tried to kill us every day it is this instinct to cling to each other to help each other to stay alive normal emotions must be under control to the point of ambivalence i was not surprised by the cruelty of my ambivalence then nothing seemed more natural then someone getting killed there is the simple truth that things happened just the way that they happen despite how you would have liked something else you try to find meaning non the less to your situation no matter how you are feeling but once you give up once it is all senseless you are changed your experience has changed you and you still want to survive yellow birds is full of meaningful attempts at breaking down the helplessness that war produces in people the author kevin powers deployed as a machine gunner recounts his struggles with the rhythm of a poet which he is he is adept at using the beauty that words can not explain but maybe release the heart a powerful story written with thought provoking awareness and poetic emotion wow i didn't realize how good this book was to read i have to give it 5 stars i didn't think that would happen
raw_text.2189: kevin powers' novel the yellow birds is extraordinary in its composition the language on every page is lush lyrical and inventive among the gorgeous descriptions powers finds perfect ways to drop brilliant simple sentences for example "we stayed awake on amphetamines and fear " the story centers primarily on three soldiers bartle murphy and sterling what befalls them during their 2004 tour in iraq is unforgettable powers examines the choices these soldiers make and the consequences of their actions told through fragments of haunting memories from bartle's perspective the dreamy narrative builds with tension towards its eventual blistering revelations readers will feel both the suffocating atmosphere of the war and the crushing sadness guilt and remorse of how events play out for the soldiers the sincerity of the story and the craftsmanship of the prose make for a remarkable novel that deserves mention alongside some of the great modern works of war literature such as tim o'brien's the things they carried philip caputo's a rumor of war and anthony swofford's jarhead powers' stellar debut leaves me excited to read his next book to see how he utilizes his literary talents to develop another engrossing story

raw_text.2191: i want to love this book it's been on my tbr almost since it was first published yet here we are a two star rating 2 5 if we're being fair and a deep sense of meh while i can intellectually process and admire what powers attempted to convey with this book i gotta say i feel nothing at no point did i get the whole body aching reaction that i expected from a novel depicting the lives of those both living a war torn existence as well as those left behind perhaps this wasn't the right time for me to pick this book up but it fell flat for me i am left with a feeling that i as the reader am an unsympathetic snot ball for being able to read this story and yet not experience it and frankly i hate books that make me feel like i missed something my utmost respect and admiration still goes to kevin powers for what he must have endured while in iraq and subsequently what he must endure on a daily basis since but seeing as this is a book review and not an author review i have to be honest that this novel just didn't leave me feeling well anything which i suppose actually makes me feel rather sad
raw_text.2192: this is a haunting character study of a us army private on tour in iraq john bartle's lyric observations of the simultaneously horrifying and mundane nature of his surroundings seem to be his most effective weapon against insanity his buddy murph is unarmed in that fight bartle speaks of the same battles fought in the same place each year as if to mark the passing of the seasons the repetitive normalcy of the violence leads to murph's terrible beautifully depicted unraveling i struggled with bartle's thinly reasoned response to murph that brought about his own denouement bartle's character seemed too rational to respond as he did and there seemed to me a larger connection between the futility of the fighting and bartle's observation upon meeting murph's mother that ' everyone stopped listening to her when america forgot her little story moving as it does so quickly on to other agonies ' the idea of a public that wanted war but is too easily distracted to pay adequate attention as the lives of kids like murph are destroyed gets limited play but the book is not about politics it's about fear and the sad reality that living through something is not the same as surviving it i read an electronic arc of this book via net galley courtesy of the publisher

raw_text.2195: i have recently in the past week or so become addicted to this little show called homeland in fact my boyfriend and i spent one afternoon watching over 5 hours of the show and i swear our eyes began to bleed from our sockets i had just finished reading "the yellow birds" the week before and i couldn't help but see the parallels brody was sent to afghanistan in 2003 the same time that private bartle was in iraq both these men are disillusioned war veterans who see the pointlessness of killing and are broken both have major secrets that are driving them crazy omg i need to watch season 2 asap but unlike homeland "the yellow birds" is heavy so heavy in fact that while reading his novel i sometimes feel like sisyphus destined to rolled that damn boulder up that hill for all eternity which clearly by my star rating is not a bad thing butit can be a bad thing when you decide to get the audio book instead of the hard copy and therefore have some form of "cryface" everywhere you go not too fun when you walk into meijer looking like you were just dumped on the ride over "the yellow birds" is mostly about two young men who enlist in the army around 2003 they are sent to al tafar iraq where one of them dies a tragic death as the reader we are informed right away that private murphy dies and somehow this does not lessen weight of his death surrounded by mystery just like homeland several events foreshadow the events that lead to the tragedy which did catch me off guard what a twist so i recommend this book to anyone who likes a tear jerker and not a romantic kind of tear jerker and also watch homeland but just be prepared because it will consume your life

raw_text.2206: kevin powers knows what it's like to go to war he knows the relentless brutality of al tafar in 2004 05 he gives us glimpses of the camaraderie among soldiers and the suppressed emotions of survival he made me think about how the walking dead could be identified by those who were able to adjust to military life he had an authentic voice that needs to be heard the way he told the story is unforgivable this man has an mfa and is a poet he can write he can write way too much he piled one metaphor on top of another why would one simile suffice when he has three more in his head some of the sentences went on forever here's one of many i'd think of a time when we sat in the evening in the guard tower watching the war go by in streaks of red and green and other briefer lights and he'd tell me of an afternoon in the little hillside apple orchard that his mother worked the turn and flash of a paring knife along a wrap of gauze as they grafted uppers to rootstocks and new branches to blossom or the time he saw but could not explain his awe when his father brought a dozen canaries home from the mine and let them loose in the hollow where they lived how the canaries only flitted and sang awhile before perching back atop their cages which had been arranged in rows his father likely thinking that the birds would not return by choice to their captivity and that the cages should be used for something else a pretty bed for vegetables perhaps a place to string up candles between the trees and in what strange silences the world worked murph must have wondered as the birds settled peacefully in their formation and ceased to sing this sentence was tortured beyond belief this could have been a beautiful book had his editors been more adept at keeping him focused on the compelling narrative if they had told him to save some of the fluff for another novel we could have stopped to wonder rather than being bombarded with imagery the reader needed some space to breathe and visualize this might have been better written as a memoir for me it also needed a more chronological path or at least clearly defined flashbacks an example of overpainted imagery i remembered late novembers needles browned by the warm virginia air collecting like discarded blankets on the shore taking the warped steps down the back of the house on the cusp of morning the sun slouching behind the tallest trees on the hills above the draw of where our house sat and on and on for hundreds more words a few take aways barely a man not a man life was in me but it splashed as if at the bottom of a nearly empty bowl truth does not depend on being believed thanks father you can pray whatever you want i guess whatever you don't think will be a waste of time freedom is not the same as lack of accountability there is a sharp distinction about what remembered what is told and what is true
raw_text.2207: finished "yellow birds" by kevin powers yesterday and just want to say a few things about the novel overall was an enjoyable novel never read a novel which portrayed the iranian war from an american's point of view so it was an interesting read i must admit i got confused at certain points in the book especially as he explains certain war fare such as guns or positions in the army but with the help of google i began to understand and learn a few things i loved the way powers expresses the waste of war and the idea that guilt is carried no matter how much praise has been given or medals been thrown at one killing is never right death is a horrid image and powers describes that so lyrically and beautiful his prose is full of strong and direct imagery that hits the reader straight away i also enjoyed the description of the idea that one will never know what is a lie the truth a memory or just a nightmare there was a sharp distinction between what was remembered what was told and what was true and i didn't think i'd ever figure out which was which

raw_text.2212: i read it twice to teach it the first time through it really felt like a list i had little sympathy for the narrator bartle and found his insights into life in the military limited i was engaged at times by the poetic style of the writing the question of what happened to murph drives the story as do questions about what bartle did to disgrace himself and the lack of care of returning veterans at the end of their service the second time through i am equally frustrated by bartle and even more so by the lack of discussion about why the us was at war in iraq in the first place the military industrial complex which compels some to enlist because there are no other jobs or options also gets no discussion these absences are telling the second time through the language reads a bit more poetically and the images are more engaging but the underlying questions about the role of the us in the middle east and the role of the military in the political economy continue to bother me i am also confused as to why in a military that is overwhelmingly black and brown none of the character in yellow birds are people of color i am deeply troubled by the decision instead to make the iraqi's the only people of color in the text since they are reduced to the status of the enemy these characters are without depth or value except as targets for all the hype the text does not address several critical issues even in passing it is no contemporary all quiet on the western front as it has been hailed by some

raw_text.2219: real emotional powerful these words are the best that i can come up when considering the impact this debut novel had on me i am an iraq veteran and found myself writing as a way to deal with the experiences that i had while in iraq even though this book is fiction kevin powers is an iraq veteran himself and i can't help but thinking that what private bartle thinks powers himself at some point or another must have thought the same i know that i could relate with private bartle throughout the story and the chapters where he is at home failing to fit in were for me the most powerful and personal parts of the story thank you for sharing and for writing this novel that i hope inspires other iraq and afghanistan veterans to write as a way to heal and a way to move on with their lives
raw_text.2220: i should have gone with my first instinct about war stories unless of course they are written by hemingway the yellow birds by kevin powers is no exception although the synopsis speaks to a friendship i can't see it through the protracted narrative i'm not into stories about war unless the story arc is truly riveting so i didn't finish the book maybe i'm not part of the target audience since most of the critics listed in the back jacket of the book are men but i gave it a chance i began to doze off not much could jolt me out of my reverie i couldn't focus it's not only that the first hundred pages are mostly tell with no show it's also about the dense narrative that periodically and not frequently goes into dialogue the action is masked by metaphors as if kevin powers pulled them out of his roster to fill up the pages i would have given this story a 2 5 but i couldn't so a three is stretching it
raw_text.2221: a few thoughts on the yellow birds this is a very literary novel heavy with descriptive passages which i felt sometimes interrupted the flow of the story to me the style and subject matter didn't sit entirely comfortably together undoubtedly kevin powers is an incredibly talented writer and for that he fully deserves the four stars i gave the novel however i found the story itself tough going distressing in places in particular the discover of murph's body and the aftermath there are some particularly fine passages in the novel which brought me close to tears they were so beautifully written imbued with such pain and suffering and self loathing the scene at the bridge just over half way through the novel when bartle admits he wants to die but doesn't have the guts to kill himself is one of the finest pieces of writing i've read in a long time what i didn't like was the lack of chronological order to the novel it jumps around from chapter to chapter september 2004 back to december 2003 on to march 2005 back to september 2004 and so on the memories flow and the story builds slowly but it is easy to forget quite where you are in the timeframe the reason begins to emerge as to why bartle is in the state he is back home in america he did something very bad in iraq covering up for his friend murph's death and ultimately is called to account for it that's something he will have to live with for the rest of his life i think it is destined to be a modern classic war novels have a special place in literary history it's an honest and brave depiction of the realities of modern conflict i'm glad to have read it and the memory of it will linger for a long time

raw_text.2224: iraq war veteran kevin powers' first novel the yellow birds is a gritty powerful and moving story of two young men who are thrown into a horrific war in iraq 21 year old bartle is the narrator who promises 18 year old small murph's mother that he will bring her son safely home to her story unfolds thru alternating chapters bartle's view while in iraq as he endures 120 degree heat mutilated corpses ever present fear constant losing and retaking of the same territory witnessing atrocities and bartle's view once safely back in the us with post tramatic stress syndrome and his feelings of guilt as he tries to understand and accept murph's death and his complicity in covering up the circumstances the horrors of war are explicitly detailed but it is the friendship of these two men and bartle's inner turmoil that are the heart of the story which is accurate dramatic engrossing raw intense and haunting

raw_text.2241: so far the two major fictional works dealing with the iraq and afghanistan wars are billy lynn's long halftime walk and the yellow birds billy lynn is satire focused on how the war was sold on the home front and the soldiers who were caught in the middle as such it often teetered on the precipice of being glib the yellow birds is focused on the experience of being a soldier witnessing war and recovering from it as such its challenge is to avoid being maudlin or cliche like lynn it's largely successful there are moments when it strains a metaphor about distinguishing shades of grey comes to mind as being a bit on the nose but on the balance it accomplishes what it sets out to do and does so economically and with a great deal of pathos i think it's increasingly difficult to say anything about war that hasn't been said before especially when writing a book in a realist mode war is hell it makes people do horrible things and the damage follows those people back home when it's over if there is something new or exciting to say it isn't said in this book but maybe these are lessons important enough that we should keep repeating them over and over again until we actually learn them

raw_text.2264: 3 5 maybe i want to talk to someone about this book before i really feel fit to review it yellow birds is lyrical poetic befitting the fact that its author was a poetry fellow before deploying to iraq it's also powerful evocative so much so that it makes me wonder how much i might consider it symptomatic of broader cultural feelings and reactions to the war in iraq if it is symptomatic though then it's symptomatic mainly of confusion of place names and chronologies that remain unmapped and unclear to most americans of uncertain causes and reactions of a lack of clear and certain rationale behind the war itself the narrator of this novel does not know why he's at war or why he joined or why the army is fighting in a particular city for the third autumn in a row what strikes me about this description though is that it is the same basic description that i might give of wilfred owen or late thomas hardy poetry of erich maria remarque of nearly all ww1 literature that i have read what should make this novel different is its awareness of the other the iraqi the terrorist and yet this novel could perhaps exist without an enemy an enemy that exists only in shadows and does appear to even be an enemy i'm not sure whether this absence is in itself symptomatic of something about the current wars or whether it is a damning absence that deserves much greater criticism

raw_text.2273: this book is perfect in the way only a small book can be perfect like we have always lived in the castle ethan frome and the road it knows how to boil a story down to its most potent and affecting parts it is itself an essence a war story that could have been told around a campfire or more likely inside a confessional booth here we have privates john bartle and daniel murphy narrator and tragic figure respectively both with a single foot barely in adulthood thrust into unknowable warfare we are ripped back and forth in time and space from 2003 to 2009 and from richmond virginia to the nineveh province of iraq to fort knox kentucky but the novel revolves around one terrible event from which the reader cannot help but to simultaneously run toward and shrink away the death of private murphy kia powers' prose hits the reader with a biblical resonance incorporating symbols and metaphors to great effect but with the simplicity of cormac mccarthy and ernest hemingway that depicts brutality so well it's with this austere prose that bartle meanders through the horrors of war eventually leaving the battlefield but never escaping capital w war which haunts him years beyond the term of his field duty i can't recommend this book enough to readers interested in the effects of war and the way people respond to incredible circumstances

raw_text.2282: in a meandering cliche filled story exploring nearly every war novel stereotype since the genre came into existence kevin powers makes a dramatic - if fractured - case against the war in which he fought and ambitiously war in general he attempts to comment on the war itself the psychological effects of the war and the way in which it is run his storytelling is hampered however by incessant use of overly dramatic language and shockingly hackneyed prose his argument which falls along nearly the same lines as those made by the authors of "the red badge of courage" from which he borrows the themes of courage masculinity and fear on the frontline "through the wheat" from which he borrows his fractured narrative and imprecise dialogue as well as a melodramatic and quickly developed acclimatization to death "the marines of autumn" from which he borrows the flashback format and a quentin tarantino esque timeline and "the things they carried" from which he borrows the style of stringing together stories at random that are only tangentially related to each other as well as a bizarre commentary on reality truth and perception in combat attempts to characterize war as a fruitless endeavor that robs men of their manhood innocence and futures and devastates the land and people around which it is fought tpowers quickly inserts into his storyline the typical authority figure both loved for his skill in combat and effective if rough style of leadership - a la "through the wheat" and hated for his abrasive personality and somewhat odd superstitious or irrational behavior - a la "the things they carried" just as blithely and without ceremony he begins to insert - from page one - unsupported potshots at the war nominally disguised as poetically abrupt observations "the war had killed thousands by september " "the war tried to kill us in the spring " just as abruptly and with a generous amount of pseudo intellectual or psychological foreshadowing and discussion powers kills off the company's interpreter not so subtly juxtaposing the iraqi's death with a flowery and pompously idyllic speech about his mother's flower gardens delivered just before he's shot - covering his american colleagues with his own blood fourteen pages into the novel powers has exhausted the traditional amount of commentary on emotional decrepitness and war horror typically allotted to a single narrative tthis does not prevent him however from gamely charging on in the same style for an additional two hundred and twelve pages apparently satisfied with his portrayal of the war itself i e the battlefield experience thereof powers begins to clumsily set the stage for the central conflict of the novel - the mysterious events surrounding the inevitable death of the protagonist's bartle's best friend a trope well employed by every other mediocre war novelist in recent history in a vain attempt to engender empathy and fear in the heart of the reader powers describes at length the promise that bartle rashly makes his friend's murph's mother - the substance motives and result of which the reader could most likely have guessed within the first four pages of the novel - and the apparently endless and circular internal dialogue in which the incredibly pessimistic and prematurely depressed main character indulges he utilizes this storyline well past its inherent usefulness as a means of criticizing the divisive and emotionally attritious nature of war in general talternating between chapters set in nineveh iraq in 2004 pregnant to bursting with monolithically repetitive internal dialogue on the nature of manhood the meaning of life and the weather and richmond virginia in 2005 chapters characterized by all too familiar and stereotypical descriptions of the painful adjustment veterans must make in order to acclimate themselves to civilian life a transition which of course bartle weighed down by the dramatic and mysterious guilt that haunts him is unable to make powers attempts to illustrate the effects the war has had on the tender mind of a once eighteen year old angsty boy now a 21 year old angsty man war takes the life from the men who fight it even if they survive - a theme liberally explored by writers since the greco roman era fighting through nausea at the typicality and repetitively over poetic prose which powers is all too willing to spew at the sight of a sunset death or an untied shoe the reader understands that the author is attempting to describe a myriad of negative effects that war has on the psyche and body of the soldiers it claims tsomehow managing to bring a story characterized by a suspiciously endless quality simultaneously to an abrupt end kevin powers - a poet who became an author in what might conservatively be described as the worst decision of his life - dramatically completes his case war has desensitized bartle and he has committed crimes in the name of the country he sought to serve or more accurately to escape war has taken his patriotism his connection with his friends and family his best friend and concurrently his honor and now his future the final chapter set as bartle sits in prison for covering up the death of his best friend does absolutely nothing to add substance to powers's argument but does succeed in exceeding even his own high standards for hyperbolic and caricaturishly typical storytelling tboth bartle and his best friend who finds himself walking naked through the streets in a style suspiciously similar to that of "catch 22"'s main character eventually lose their minds - and finally both have died though only one is buried war has claimed two more victims and the reader can let an audible sigh of relief at the close of the story escape lips hitherto screwed up in disgust at the style storytelling and themes of kevin powers's "novel"

raw_text.2303: 1 9 5 0 this book takes itself way too seriously unlike the best war novels of the last fifty years the yellow birds doesn't even try for irony instead powers gets grandiose and poetic dropping obscure botanical jargon and forced metaphors to convey the agony of life in war absolutely groundbreaking i know the prose is universally praised and i can see why powers can conjure strong images with brief simple phrases but none of it is particularly daring or innovative he does one of those breathless multipage sentences that everyone seems obliged to include when they're evoking a protagonist's trauma to date franzen's version in the corrections capturing chip lambert's existential woes is among sentences of this type the most clever the most organic and compared to whatever powers has given us it feels far less perfunctory the lack of levity and the lyrical tone lend the book a bleak baseline which never budges and because it doesn't depict the transition from triumph to loss electing instead to wallow in misery alone the book is less tragedy than pedantic melodrama exactly the narrative form that war never deserves shame on all the positive reviews this book is pretentious and dangerously aloof i didn't love ben fountain's billy lynn's long halftime walk but it's a vastly more affecting read

raw_text.2316: the yellow birds was a relatively short read but that didn't diminish the size of the message or it's power as a fictional memoir of the iraq war and one soldier's experience of the war and his return to the us it couldn't have been shorter or longer in fact by the time i reached the end of the book the horror of war and the consequences one young sensitive soldier experienced had touched me deeply i can understand why this book has won awards and been short listed for others i can also imagine how gut wrenching it was to write it why do we read books about war i wonder i personally am a pacifist and abhor even the thought of war yet i go to war movies and watch war stories on tv and usually cry my eyes out because i find the suffering so terrible there is something so intense and poignant about the spiritual suffering of war that i for whatever reason want to understand and maybe that's it i am searching for the reason that men and women go to war and if they do i want to understand that experience mourn that loss of innocence that war stamps on its purveyors i thought for a while when reading this book that it was going to be an anti war tract but no it was nothing of the sort and it didn't make war a grandiose thing this book brought the experience of war into an intimate and very personal language mr powers has managed to communicate one man's story in a way that leaves no doubt there is a personal price paid for all those who go to war and it is carried and paid for the rest of their lives this makes it all the more powerful when will we stop asking our young people to have these experiences

raw_text.2328: it is hard to write an enthusiastic review of yellow birds by kevin powers the problem arises not because the book itself is unworthy of praise but because its subject matter is the iraq war a scenario that remains utterly and perhaps unacceptably real and yellow birds despite being fiction treats its subject matter with admirable though often revolting veracity it is this often graphic and repulsive detail of reality that tempers enthusiasm not every reader will want to cope with these words but reading yellow birds is despite its myriad of challenges both rewarding and stimulating i hesitate to include the word informative because the leap of imagination required to link events with which we are all too familiar as a result of copious news reports with the obvious gory reality is not a great feat but yellow birds does stimulate us to revisit our own attitudes - perhaps both second order and received - to a conflict about which no doubt we all believe we have an opinion it was a war that was based on a premise that it would remove a dictator who was considered a threat via weapons of mass destruction or regional ambition to world peace and though the book does not really address either the history or the politics of the conflict's origins the book's vivid depiction of first hand experience of the conflict inevitably provokes the reader to revisit the background but the book also rewards the reader with the experience and contrast of simply beautiful if often arresting prose the book follows the experiences of three main characters bartle murph and sterling the story is told through bartle's first person and we visit his thoughts before during and after deployment in iraq but within a time frame that skirts around events that must be told with care conscience and guilt from the start it is clear that there is something that is going unsaid something is indeed very wrong and long before the end of the novel we know that the problem relates to bartle's friendship with a fellow private murphy with whom he shared a tour on the front line if the iraq war ever had any lines sterling is the non commissioned officer who accompanies them into the actions they face and indeed was the instigator of the developing relationship between bartle and murph he seems predictably but not shockingly hardened even brutalised by his military experience an experience that inevitably hardens all involved the interchanges between these soldiers are often crass crude and obscene as are many of their actions actions that are habitually matched in both brutality and cynicism by those of an opposition who cannot even be properly defined let alone identified whenever yellow birds relates the very mechanics of the conflict the reader receives a blast of images graphically portrayed in violent text life and death seem exceptionally gruesome and unforgiving neither rational but then quite paradoxically we have the mechanisms of kevin powers's text which describes the mental state of bartle in the light of what ha happened whatever it might have been his shell shock post traumatic stress disorder conscience regret guilt - call it whatever you wish - is examined via a lean spiky but always elegant prose whose twists and turns often bite so complete is the contrast between the near elegance of expression that describes bartle's mental state and the often offensive crassness of the soldiers' interactions that the reader may sense a naive schizophrenia at work a reflective man's complete inability to relate to actions he himself perpetrated but then even in war we can be victims of mere circumstance the single and great success of yellow birds is to confront the reader with the unanswerable question "in such circumstances what would you have done " it's unanswerable because as a question it could never be asked in the circumstances there would be neither time to assemble to words nor to mouth them neither indeed would the consequences be any more predictable do read this book but do expect a bumpy ride
raw_text.2329: phenomenal narrative about war and its impact on the human spirit
raw_text.2330: the yellow birds swoop down and capture you in the first lines 'the war tried to kill us in the spring as grass greened the plains of nineveh and the weather warmed we patrolled the low slung hills beyond the cities and towns and they never let go i loved kevin powers voice and style in this story of the iraq war it seems brutal and honest and tears your heart out murphy and bartle become best buds in boot camp and upon meeting murphy's mother bartle promises her that he will bring her son back there are some promises in life which should never be made this is a profound story of friendship made by war and how innocence and youth fare under its stresses it shifts back and forth between past and present and all the time with powers prose i disowned the waters of my youth my memories of them became a useless luxury their names as foreign as any that could be found in nineveh the tigris or the chesapeake the james or the shatt al arab farther to the south all belonged to someone else and perhaps had never really been my own i was an intruder at best a visitor and would be even in my home in my misremembered history until the glow of phosphorescence of the chesapeake i had longed to swim inside again someday became a taunt against my insignificance a cruel trick of light that always made me think of stars no more i gave up longing be cause i was sure that anything seen at such a scale would reveal the universe as cast aside and drowned and if i ever floated there again out where the level of the water reached my neck and my feet lost contact with its muddy bottom i might realize that to understand the world one's place in it is to be always at risk of drowning this is not an easy book to read but when reading it one understands why it has received such high praise i am hoping to read more from kevin powers in the future

raw_text.2333: u s army private john bartle has returned home from iraq--physically not mentally having done a tour in one of the deadliest cities for american soldiers in the iraq war bartle is lucky to be alive but does agonizing over a haunted past count as living a poetic exploration of ptsdfor those who might need a reminder that war is indeed hell there is the yellow birds by iraq war veteran kevin powers like most war fiction that focuses on characters who've returned home from war yellow birds is about the confusion of war and the pain caused by post traumatic stress and reverse culture shock you will have seen this story before about different men and women--about different places times and wars what makes yellow birds stand out from many of the others is kevin powers' poetic concise writing there's no padding for comfort here everything is bare and raw like a fresh wound the book opens with two quotes one a u s army marching chant about a yellow bird thus the book title the other a quote from sir thomas browne to be ignorant of evils to come and forgetfull of evils past is a mercifull provision in nature whereby we digest the mixture of our few and evil dayes and our delivered senses not relapsing into cutting remembrances our sorrows are not kept raw by the edge of repetitions the irony here of course is that post traumatic stress does keep sorrows raw by the edge of repetitions which is what this book is about partly when private john bartle returns home from iraq he's unable to stop reliving the events that took place before during and directly after his time there in particular he can't let go of daniel murph murphy a fellow private he somewhat carelessly promised to look out for murph became an unexpected friend who bartle now feels he failed desperate for relief from what turns into a living endless nightmare bartle withdraws from society and self medicates with alcohol his mind skirts around painful memories but subjects him to others he is never free i remember feeling relief in basic while everyone else was frantic with fear it had dawned on me that i'd never have to make a decision again that seemed freeing but it gnawed at some part of me even then eventually i had to learn that freedom is not the same thing as the absence of accountability there's a sense of randomness that clings to this story and bartle and not every reader will like that it's the randomness of enlisting on a whim of making impromptu promises one can't possibly keep of war itself if you're looking for answers for a clear beginning middle and end this is not the book for you there are no answers and one moment bleeds into another like the hues in a watercolor painting this is an existential journey powers' stylistic choices won't be to everyone's liking either but they shouldn't be misunderstood as they are perhaps the least random element found in yellow birds powers uses nonlinear storytelling to show the reader what post traumatic stress is like first hand chapter one opens to iraq in september 2004 chapter two jumps to new jersey in december 2003 there's germany in march 2005 for chapter three and so on you read exactly as bartle's mind wanders yo yo like from the past to the present pain and regrets surface in bursts of depression anger and regret bartle is rarely if ever telling you about the past he's showing it to you as he agonizes over it and relives it i've read articles and studies about post traumatic stress and a few fictional works i've read have included characters suffering from ptsd but i think powers' style in yellow birds does a much better job of presenting the obsession fear and depression that are tied up in ptsd aside the best auditory exploration of ptsd i've encountered is from npr's this american life some readers express frustration over bartle's inability to stay objective and focused but bartle is a slave to his past and unable to be a normal person i had become a kind of cripple they were my friends right why didn't i just wade out to them what would i say hey how are you they'd say and i'd answer i feel like i'm being eaten from the inside out and i can't tell anyone what's going on because everyone is so grateful to me all the time and i'll feel like i'm ungrateful or something or like i'll give away that i don't deserve anyone's gratitude and really they should all hate me for what i've done but everyone loves me for it and it's driving me crazy right powers doesn't want you to understand war even if it can be understood he wants you to understand the isolated soldier with invisible wounds you have to be in the right frame of mind to read yellow birds it's a short book--around 240 pages in paperback--and it has a rather small unsurprising plot but it still took me a while to read and process it packs a punch it should quotes from the book apply your own positive negative connotations war is the great maker of solipsists how are you going to save my life today dying would be one way if you die it becomes more likely that i will not he had nothing to fear he'd been invincible absolutely until the day we was not i thought of my grandfather's war how they had destinations and purpose how the next day we'd march out under a sun hanging low over the plains in the east we'd go back into a city that had fought this battle yearly a slow bloody parade in fall to mark the change of season we'd drive them out we always had we'd kill them they'd shoot us and blow off our limbs and run into the hills and wadis back into the alleys and dusty villages then they'd come back and we'd start over by waving to them as they leaned against lampposts and unfurled green awnings while drinking tea in front of their shops while we patrolled the streets we'd throw candy to their children with whom we'd fight in the fall a few more years from now

raw_text.2338: not since i studied the great soldier writers of world war 1 have i been so moved by a war novel this is a harrowing compelling story reflecting what i can only believe is the writer's real experience of part of a young american private's service in iraq the story captures the insufferable tension fear and dislocation of the experience and the moral and psychological challenges the young man confronts during and after that year spectacularly sensitive writing captures the contradictory beauty and mystery of the place of occupation and the complexity of the relationships formed with colleagues in particular a sergeant only slightly older than the protagonist and a fellow private a year younger 17 with whom he forms a peculiar bond and takes on an obligation that leads inexorably to failure highly recommended

raw_text.2348: this is an eloquent haunting lyrical work the writing is so poetical on every page that one has to be sure and not read too quickly in order to appreciate the powerful prose this is a superb example of the ability of great fiction to evoke a visceral gut feeling about an historical event to paint a picture and explain the often asked question about what it must might have been like for people living through and experiencing the event in a context and with a power that non fictional accounts about an event seldom achieve the experience of reading about what are often horrific happenings written so expressively sometimes leaves the reader stunned occasionally it seems like an oxymoron to be reading of such profound sorrow and disturbing actions that at the same time are so beautifully and carefully conveyed in words as the reader one can't help but be involved in the anguish and emotional trauma suffered by the compassionate narrator this novel is going to stay with me a long time the last time i can recall an extraordinary work affecting me perhaps equally as deeply was reading the non fiction book "bury my heart at wounded knee" by dee brown

to protect each other from the forces that press in on every side my reactionspowers moves the action back and forth in time from the fall of 2004 in iraq to dec 2003 at fort dix nj then back to iraq
